deck_excerpt: Combo festival deck that locks your opponent completely out of playing the game at all.
deck_description: Hello there.  I made this decklist inspired in another one really similar from the Public Decks in the MD Deck Create room, and it showcases that D/D/D Duo Dawn King Kali Yuga is a real problem if the combo made to summon it to the Field isn't stopped properly, just like many other cards in the cardpool (Herald, Rhongo, etc., you can figure the rest).  The problem is, this deck can make the full combo that stops your opponent for entirely playing the game alongside getting 8k+ damage for the turn 3 with only 2 specific cards or any 3 card combo that can leave Force Strix + ANY DARK EXTENDER. Obviously, you need to play uninterrupted, and that's why the deck is equipped with a full-on Crossout Designator package that includes Ash, Nibiru, Infimp, Maxx "C" (at 3, that card may be the best card in the entire game period) and Called by (which you obviously want to see in your opener too). 5/40 cards are there to stop your opponent from stopping you, since you can't make full combo and also get a negate before the 5th summon, and Nib absolutely screws your plans.  Anyways, Tribute Lanius (or Summoner Monk + Spell for that matter) + Raider's Wing is full combo. Normal Tribute, effect to send to GY, send Mimicry (the one you never want in your opener), Mimicry effect in GY to search Pain Lanius, Pain effect to summon itself paying 400 targeting Tribute, XYZ summon Force Strix, search Singing Lanius, Raider's effect to summon itself detaching from Force, Singing summon itself because you have an XYZ monster. You now have 3 monsters in the Field and 3 cards in hand.  Link summon Wise Strix using everything but Raider's Wing (to avoid banishing it in any case the combo fails), summon from the Deck any Raidraptor (here you want Mimicry if you couldn't mill and search from it before), XYZ into another Force Strix, search literally anything and activate the 2nd effect of Wise to set a  PK Rank-Up Magic Force from the Deck (you will clearly be activating it this turn). Notice you will be keeping the last 3 cards in hand, and you now have a searched card from Force. If you opened a copy of Strangle Lanius, don't search it specifically, you will be summoning one from the Deck later, and also it locks you into DARK monsters, which you want to avoid if your opponent disrupts your next play.  Next, bring out Rusty Bardiche leaving the XYZ monster with 1 material (and that makes a lot of difference, it truly matters), then Rusty effect sending Boots to the GY to set Shade Brigandine. You don't want to set the RUM Launch (specially going second) to avoid any S/T destruction your opponent may have. Boots effect in GY next banishing itself to search Launch. If everything goes as planned from here, you won the game 99.99% of the time.  Activate RUM Force targeting Force Lanius and summon Arsenal Falcon, it should keep 2 materials. Arsenal effect (leaving Force Strix as material) to summon Strangle from Deck, and activate its effect to bring back any LV4 Raidraptor from the GY. Here, overlay the 2 LV4 monsters you have to XYZ summon Gagagaga Magician in a zone Rusty points to, to prock Rusty's destruction targeting Arsenal Falcon. If Arsenal has a "Raidraptor" monster as material, when it's sent to the GY, he will bring out Ultimate Falcon and attach itself as material. Inmediately after, detach from Ultimate to lock your opponent out of monster effects but, most importantly, getting Arsenal to the GY.  Last but not least, activate Gagagaga Magician's effect to bring back the Arsenal Falcon from the GY with no XYZ materials, and if you're going first, you can perfectly pass from here before setting the Launch. As soon as you're allowed, activate said RUM Launch to summon Kali Yuga on top of Arsenal Falcon, and anything your opponent did and does in/after the chain you're summoning Kali Yuga will be negated. Your opponent can't play the game really (Kali Yuga's Azathot like effect procks instantly and last until the end of the turn), and you have 2k + 3.5k + 3.5k + 2.1k damage (well over lethal) and a Quick-Effect Harpie's Feather Duster.  This painful combo happens quite consistently and with the correct cards, your opponent will need 3 interruptions to make it unviable. Your backup plan is UDF to negate and steal, Zeus if you're going second and can't OTK, or most likely if you lost the coin toss, Arc Rebellion XYZ Dragon, summonable with Raider's Knight.  Even if you can't full combo, almost always the deck can end on a Arsenal Falcon that needs to be banished or bounced in order to avoid its floating effect to bring an inmune 3.5k beatstick that can shut the opponent down from monster effects, burns and decreases attack on top. But anyways, Force Strix + a DARK monster (considering you haven't used Raider's Wing effect to get there) is full combo uninterrupted, and you can play from there really.  Never banish 6 from Prospy. You always want to banish 3, and in my consideration the cards you for sure don't miss if you get out of your EX are Zeus, one Force Strix and one Gagagaga Magician. The rest is quite important. Maybe the UFD package is missable if you're going 2nd and can't OTK through Prosperity, but consider your options.  A board going 2nd with Rusty, Ultimate Falcon, Gagagaga Magician and Arc Rebellion has 10600 ATK. OTKing the turn you used Prosperity is viable, but you need your opponent having some monster(s) on the Field.  Kagetokage and Curtain Riser are in the deck as a XYZ enabler post and pre Normal Summon respectively. And you don't really need Shade, but any extender is welcome in this combo festival.  Important note, if you can full combo going 1st to get to Kali, Maxx "C" is not a problem really, considering you have ways to stop Ash and Nibiru specifically (e.g Called by and Crossout, both of them), so, if in your opener you have full combo + the 2 anti-handtrap measure cards, your targets should be those 2 and not Maxx "C".  Considering Prosperity is a HOPT (and thank God for that) and that this decklist plays 3of, you may want to replace one copy of Prospy for an Effect Veiler or a Ghost Belle, to make sure you have enough Crossout targets. I don't recommend it, but it's viable.  The deck is not really fun to play in the long term, nor cheap, nor interactive in most cases, but it wins, it wins a LOT, it isn't a pure coinflip (since you have your contingency plans or cards specifically made for going 2nd such as Droplet, Zeus, Arc, LS or Duster), it's somewhat versatile (even if the best it can do is the full lockout I explained before) and, in my experience, most of my opponents didn't know when to interrupt it correctly (the best disruption window is CLEARLY the Wise Strix summon, even more if you can destroy it with a Gamma for example). But most important, 7/10 times the combo goes off (or is for sure going off and the opponent knows that) the surrender is inmediate and you almost feel you made your opponent lose their time. So take that in mind if you decide to run this abomination.
Machina and infinitracks

deck_excerpt: Dragonmaid Pile to turbo out plenty of negates and push for game turn 2 or 3
deck_description: This Dragonmaid list basically abuses the same strategy most relevant meta deck abuse currently. Focusing on playing a pile of extender with just the right ratio of hand traps to open with 80% chance 1 and with 50% chance 2 with the other cards being extender.  The main goal of the deck is to set up sphere + 2 negates or Auroradon + 2 negates and a set up gy for the next turn if you went first. If you went second you usually can push straight for game against most boards.     The spice lies in having the new meteor dragon as a way to loop black metal dragon into Ravine + Sphere while only using your normal summon and combo from there into either Sheou + Savage or go all out into Auroradon.  The deck takes some time to get used to to play but rewards you with plenty of lines of play even through negates and you will rarely stand there without interaction durring your opponents turn, if you go second or first. I can go into more detail if needed how the combos work if asked for.

deck_excerpt: A more budget pile version of the recent meta pile decks. Also more fun to play and bann list safer
deck_description: Alright, there are two reasons why you are here and not looking at tournament decks. Either you bought a full Swordsoul core and not want to spend more money just to swap to the new hot stuff that gets banned soon and now search for a way to keep playing the expensive cards you got OR you have no patience for Punk dia note and want to play this Amazing ( dragon ) archtype already. Oh boy I got just the list for you. This deck does just what adventure tenyi rose dragon swordsoul ect. Does but cheaper and with a bit more explosive plays that catch people by suprise. The downside is a slightly higher brick chance ending with to many hand traps / traps. So if you dont mind that every tenth game, than this deck will still be something for you. So lets go into this card by card followed by some combos. First of all the classic cards : 3x Red Rose Dragon 1x Roxrose Dragon 1x Basal Rose Shoot 3x Tenyi Spirit - Adhara 3x Tenyi Spirit - Ashuna 3x Tenyi Spirit - Vishuda This is the most classical part of the deck. The main thing about it, is summon a big tenyi , summon red rose dragon , make baroness than use the rose dragons to go into Halq which is protected by Baroness omni negate. There are other ways to make this but this is the most simple version and usually the safest. The Swordsouls: 1x Swordsoul of Mo Ye 1x Swordsoul of Taia 1x Swordsoul Strategist Longyuan You rarely want to open them as they require a other card in hand and your normal summon, Long is probably still the best of the bunch to burn and make Baroness but usually you want to get to them later in your combo. The Punks : 3xNoh-P.U.N.K. Foxy Tune 2x Noh-P.U.N.K. Ze Amin 1x Joruri-P.U.N.K. Madame Spider 1xJoruri-P.U.N.K. Dangerous Gabu 3x Emergency Teleport Iam gonna include Etele as punk here even though you can also summon Ogre of it. But the punks are basically 1 card Halqs / replace the Rose dragons when it comes to make a Baroness without normal summoning. Madam spider also spins use a nice little negate to hand for time win / discard fodder/ or simple negating stuff. They allow us to either set up a safer enviroment for our combo / play through negates / bait hand traps and make sure carbogeddon gets to gy. Including Ghost ogre we also have 3 names for Amazing Dragon which is really Amazing to have when playing Amazing Dragon Spice like mayonaise : 2x Carboneddon 1xFlamvell Guard 1xAlexandrite Dragon This is a new combo piece that recently came up in a few lists. You have a few more normal monsters that allow you to use the tenyi effects in gy and sending / discarding Carboneddon allows you to also get free extender material. This also makes Carboneddon a 1 card halq through Almirah. See ? Salamangreat are still good and playable. Just dont play the bad cards lmao 1x Deskbot Its deskbot. you love him you hate him Konami will take him~ 1x Fairy Tail - Snow Send it somehow to gy and just loop it while your opponent asks themself why this card came of the list while you agree followed by asking for response knowing you just ruined their day <3 1x Foolish Burial Sends carboneddon/ Snow to be live or any tenyi you wanna use. Hand traps : 3x Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring 2x Effect Veiler 3x Ghost Ogre & Snow Rabbit 3x Nibiru, the Primal Being 2x Forbidden Droplet 2xInfinite Impermanence Basically you will see to 80% one of them and to 50% two. It helps your even weaker boards to usually hold the game in your favor and going second will make the board of your opponent soft enough to crack. 1x Swordsoul Blackout Blackout pop 2 or banish to extend. Nothing to interesting to see here. Its as blant as its rarity. Extra deck : 1x Baronne de Fleur the card protecting Halq basically and one of Konamis meanest jokes to push display sales 1x Baxia, Brightness of the Yang Zing Spins cards back to deck and extends afterwards, would love to play 2x 1x Draco Berserker of the Tenyi Just to push for games, can probably cut it for Baxia 1x Geomathmech Final Sigma You see Floowander birds, you make this. And you just win. Nothing more to say, they cant out it, and you dont need to think anymore after making it. Win Win 1x Herald of the Arc Light A lot of decks cant play under this and also its a free negate. You usually make it when you do your halq combo and have an ashuna in gy 1x Shooting Riser Dragon Makes sure you can also syncro summon in your opponents turn, makes a negated Halq useful and can send either Snow / Token Collector which wins a few match ups. Its also the card you usually use for Amamzing Dragon 1xSwordsoul Grandmaster - Chixiao Searches your extender and is a negate  after wards. Yeah this card is broken 1x Swordsoul Sinister Sovereign - Qixing Longyuan The best level 10 Syncro in the game as it stops a lot of the current meta decks and singel handly wins the Invoced match up. Also the burn comes up a lot against all the current decks who pay 2000 for verte / stall for time  / pay half for destrudo etc 1x Ukiyoe-P.U.N.K. Amazing Dragon This card allows you to break boards, bounce 3 in opponents turn and push for game in yours. Its just AMAZING! and a Dragon .... well a sea serpent 1x Yazi, Evil of the Yang Zing The heart of your Halq combo and way into the Swordsouls. Pop it with baroness or your auroradon and get a free 8 sync + level 10. This card sadly will take the fall for Halqs sins I feel 1x Crystron Halqifibrax Summon desk bot in your turn or shooting riser in the opponents. 1x Mecha Phantom Beast Auroradon Summon deskbot......wait Deja vu 2x Monk of the Tenyi Can probably go to 1, but makes your Tenyi live 1x Salamangreat Almiraj You only play this to make carboneddon live really, but I guess the effect can come up? Usually I either side the rose dragon engine out or the carboneddon depending on how much I need to side in.   For any questions , just write in the comments and I will get to it.

deck_excerpt: Very fun and fast-paced HERO Deck with a lot of fusion summoning!
deck_description: This deck is about flooding the field with hero monsters and finishing duels quickly. The entire deck is dependent on Elemental Hero Sunrise. It only takes two HERO monsters to fusion summon it onto the field. When it's summoned, you can grab a miracle fusion from the deck and immediately summon another powerful Elemental Hero fusion summon from the extra deck. Sunrise is very powerful because when you attack with another HERO monster, you can destroy a card on the opponent's side of the field. This includes the monster you are attacking. This makes it easy to remove pesky spells/traps when in the battle phase, as well as removing monsters that are difficult to destroy through battle.  This deck makes it very easy to get fusion spells out of the deck with Elemental Hero Blazeman and Sunrise. It's also very easy to search for any elemental hero card you want out of the deck using Elemental Hero Stratos, Elemental Hero Shadow Mist, Masked Hero Dian, and E-Emergency Call. There are plenty of special summoning cards and graveyard padding cards to make it very easy to get cards onto the field to activate their effects.  There are also several cards that allow you to draw outside the draw phase. Elemental Hero Liquid Soldier can be used as a draw 2 and it can send cards to the graveyard from your hand. There are also cards like Pot of Duality, Masked Hero Divine Wind, and Elemental Hero Nova Master that draw cards.  This deck also has plenty of spell/trap removal using Stratos, Sunrise, Masked Hero Acid, Masked Hero Blast, and R-Righteous Justice.  One of the best combos in the deck involves Masked Hero Acid and Elemental Hero Absolute Zero. When Absolute Zero leaves the field, all monsters the opponent controls are destroyed. When Acid is summoned, all spells/traps the opponent controls are destroyed. Using a Mask Change on Absolute Zero can bring Acid onto the field and completely board wipe the opponent. I usually go for this combo when going for lethal.  Using this deck, I have consistently summoned 2-4 fusion monsters on the field in one turn. This deck works really well as a "go second" deck since it has plenty of answers to any traps that could have been laid. There are also times where this deck can FTK.  Elemental Heroes have always been one of my favorite archetypes and this is one of the most fun decks I've ever played! I'm sure it's not the most efficient, there are probably better card options, so please leave suggestions if you have some!

I did not make this deck, I used the D/D deck from the link below.  https://ygoprodeck.com/tcg-bach-metagame-tournament-report-february-2022-na-remote-duel-ycs-pt-2/?utm_source=webpush&utm_medium=webpush&utm_campaign=webpush

deck_excerpt: 2 cards combo interruptions, tower, or even OTK
deck_description: https://youtu.be/J1p0I9Dc-9c

It's a simple Qliphort deck with the option to play high-rank XYZ-Monsters with Anchor drill. Anchor drill allows you to special one EARTH Machine monster from your hand (which all Qliphorts are) and with it's effect it allows to change both monsters level to the sum of their BASE-level. The effect of the qliphorts allow you to either go for Rank 4-XYZ or, if you activate Anchor drill, any rank 9 or higher (dependent on the qli you specialed):  Scout and Monolith 9 (You rarely want to special these, so no rank 9s are in here) Helix or Carrier 10 (Superdreadnoughts) Cephalopod and Disk 11 (Cephalopod is bad, Disk just once, also there are no good rank 11s except liebe) And Stealth as well as shell 12 (seven sins and zeus)  Since all Qlis (except scout which can search other qlis, and towers) are 2400/1000 or 2800/1000 you can use that for tenacity as a draw-engine with pantheism and march (only once, because locking you out of the extra deck is an extreme measure) Since all qlis lock you out of specials which are not qlis themselves, you need to either pull any Extra-Deck-plays (as well as urgent schedule) before activating your scout or you use wavering eyes to your advantage, which can give you scout (it's effect is a soft OPT, so you don't really lose anything except maybe Monolith). Besides that you can use wavering eyes to thin out your deck and/or cycle cards into the extra deck.

deck_excerpt: A competitive TCG ABC deck which utilizes Skill Drain as a floodgate & Epigonen for added consistency & versatility, allowing for the creation of firs
deck_description: Overall, this might be my favorite contemporary TCG ABC build at the moment.  Epigonen, the Impersonation Invader is a crucial card which is why it's featured in so many of my current ABC builds. The card revitalizes otherwise dead hands and gives the deck a better degree of consistency, an expanded level of versatility, and allows for the creation of stronger first turn boards. Typically, you'll want to end on Dragon Buster, Dragoon, Masquerena, and Verte with this build.  You can even prevent a card like Veiler or Impermanence from negating Verte's effect by banishing Verte from the field with Dragon Buster. This variation of the deck utilizes Dragoon over DPE as I appreciate Dragoon's ability to aid in OTKing and its negation effect.  I'm still running a decent line-up of handtraps so as to increase one's ability to stand firm should one's opponent be going first. I'll always have a soft spot for the PSY-Framegear Gamma engine and am still running a copy of PSY-Framelord Omega given how devastating it can be for your opponent if you summon that card after negating a handtrap used against you on your own turn before you've summoned a monster.  While I prefer running two copies of Union Driver, I've decided to run only one in order take full advantage of the fact that Skill Drain is unlimited considering its interaction with ABC Dragon Buster, itself. I'm tempted to cut a copy of Skill Drain, though, or some other card in order to bring the deck back down to forty cards with a forty card build being another variation of this deck that I'm testing.  It's worth noting that running only one Union Driver isn't as detrimental anymore when you have Epigonen considering you can tribute a copy of Crush Wyvern via Epigonen's effect, special summon Union Driver with Wyvern's effect, and proceed to equip Driver to the token summoned by Epigonen before proceeding with the regular shenanigans.  The side deck is still up to major debate as is whether to utilize Pseudo Space, Cynet Universe, or Mystic Mine in the main deck. I prefer Pseudo Space, at the moment, since it serves as an extender which better enables the creation of optimal boards and aids in the accumulation of card advantage, a necessity given how both Dragon Buster and Dragoon require cards to discard to activate some of their most useful effects. There's also no fear if you give it to your opponent as a result of Set Rotation.  I also could see an argument for adjusting the extra deck a bit considering that while Omega is devastating, it only appears in quite specific scenarios whereas something like Knightmare Cerberus, Lambda, and Lyna the Light Charmer can be more consistently brought out with each of those cards having their own benefits.  I'm torn between Borrelsword and Avramax, with Borrelsword being a great boss monster to fall back on while Avramax is a great boss to summon with Masquerena in the event of your Dragon Buster being hit with a card like Called by the Grave after attempting to tag out. Borrelsword, on the other hand, is rather easy to summon with the aid of Epigonen especially when you run Link Spider.  Link Spider is a necessity in the extra deck, regardless of whether you run Borrelsword or Avaramax, considering it can be used to easily summon Verte so long as you open with Epigonen and any other summonable monster, even Ash Blossom, no matter how dead the rest of your hand is. . That last point also ties into another reason why I prefer Dragoon to DPE is because if you start with that aforementioned nearly dead hand, ending on a lone Dragoon is usually more difficult to get over than a lone DPE.  Link Spider is also necessary if you want to summon an Apollousa with four negates on your first turn which is a valid option if  you either know or  believe your opponent has Nibiru.

deck_excerpt: Two ways to play this fun casual deck; Water Lock or Big Synchros.
deck_description:
Two ways to play this deck, Water Lock or Big Synchros.
  • Water Lock
    • Use Ice Knight and Silent Sea Nettle to easily get into Rank 4 xyz Stealth Kragen. Turns all monsters on field to water, use Kragen's effect to target and destroy opponent's monster and burn opponent for half the attack of the destroyed monster. Use Gozen Match to lock into water types only
  • Synchro
    • Normal Deep Sea Diva, special summon Neptabyss from deck, use Neptabyss effect to send Atlantean Dragoons to GY and add another Atlantean Dragoons to hand. Use Atlantean Dragoons effect when sent to grave to add either Mermail Abyssmegalo or Mermail Abyssteus depending on number of water monsters in hand. Special Summon the Mermail added to hand using the Atlantean Dragoon that was added and another water monster. Atlantean Dragoons effect in GY again (not once per turn), add another sea serpent, most likely Lappis Dragon. Special Summon Lappis Dragon since it was added to hand. Synchro using monsters on field.
      • Deep Sea Diva + Neptabyss = Tatsunoko
      • Tatsunoko + Mermail monster = White Aura Bihamut
      • Or any other synchro.

deck_description: do adventurer engine stuff first you don't get nib'd  then do standard metalfoes stuff, there's really not much science to this deck besides what everyone knows. You want to end in a board that has dpe, scythe, Wandering Gryphon rider and metalfoes combination set, plus whatever interruptions you can make with the metalfoes stuff. deck_excerpt: Calling all fusion fans: Yura's favorite deck, Fallen of Albaz!
deck_description: Everyone, the time has now come! In case you didn't already know, Fallen of Albaz is, hands down, my favorite card in all of YU-GI-OH!. So how could I come join this community (I only just joined yesterday) without showing you all the deck I love most? The answer is I couldn't! And so now all of you get to view my very own creation: Albaz Despia Dogmatika. Not only do I love Albaz, I also get a good groove playing it's partners-in-lore: Despia and Dogmatika. Yes, you heard me right: Albaz is a story that plays out in the cards, a card lore. Search on youtube.com 'Albaz lore' to learn more! Anyway, about the deck. My baby is based off of the very lore of Albaz, but that does not mean I didn't think that Despia and Dogmatika were actually good achetypes to partner Albaz, though some of you might think it a terrible idea to play Dogmatika with a deck whose main win condition is it's Extra Deck. Well, for those who think that look at this way: Not only does the deck prevail in Extra Deck plays, but it also has an engine which can counter the very familiar meta decks that use it. And, please, notice that you can, if need be (which, tbh, need probably will be), replace the Dogmatika cards with those from the ever helpful Side Deck. You don't have to use Dogmatika; it's just there if you wish to. And now about the deck. You'll notice that the deck is OCG, even though I myself only have ever played the TCG. That's because in this profile I wanted to include the new cards that are getting released in Structure Deck: Albaz Strike, which is coming out on April 8th. Other then those cards, all the other cards are available in the TCG, so once Albaz Strike is released and Tri-Brigade Mercourier, Springans Kitt, Unlikely Swordsoul Allies, Paradise Branded, Branded Fusion, Branded Condemnation, Branded Blade, Lubellion the Searing Dragon and Mirrorjade the Iceblade Dragon with it, this deck will be fully TCG. My beautiful (my deck) mainly focuses on turboing out the Albaz fusions, but it can also win with the Despian fusion monsters and even the Dogmatika monsters, when used with Dogmatika Nation. The new Tri-Brigade Mercourier is a nice negate, and Unlikely Swordsoul Allies can summon any Dogmatika except Dogmatika Nexus. If you use any fusion card to sent Despian Tradegy to the GY or banish it, you can add any Despia monster except itself from your deck to your hand, which allows instant combos, especially if you add Aluber the Jester of Despia, which lets you search any Branded Spell/Trap and also is a very powerful negate. Going second is always your go to with this deck, because then your opponent can set up their board for you to break it. If they don't have the right monsters for you to fuse with, no worries! Radian and Jizukiru are there to help. Remember this is just a example of what the deck can look like. Feel free to play three of the best cards and also add your own, like Interrupted Kaiju Slumber and Super Poly. Not to say the deck I made isn't playable or isn't any good, but for sure, you can definitely follow your own deck building flow. Tbh I didn't play three of some cards because I wanted to make room for others. I still think my deck is totally sweet, though. You can bring out Mysterion the Dragon Crown by using a Dogmatika as material, and Keeper of Dragon Magic gets you materials and searches Fusion Substitute. Some might say Masquerade is a waste of time, but trust me, it's better then you think. Same with Maximus. You can also side out Extra Deck monsters you think are not necessary for different ones. And Now Comes The Most Important Part! Have fun. I know it might sound cheesy, but having fun is what YU-GI-OH! is all about. I have no doubt that that is the full intention of the game: to make memories, to smile. Have fun with this insane and sweet Fallen of Albaz deck. Enjoy, and feel free to share any ideas in the comments.
Galaxy-Eyes. Yes.

deck_excerpt: My own version of Drytron for master duel.
deck_description: My own version of Drytron for Yu-Gi-Oh Master Duel. Currently it works quite well, it can still be improved and with the next season we hope to be able to optimize the deck more.  For more details here I leave the sample video:    The main strategy consists of quickly summoning Beta and then being able to ritual summon Idaten (it will return our ritual spell card to our hand many times) to be able to perform various combos. Then with another Beta and the Diviner of the Herald we can special summon Ultimaya and F0 Utopic.

-1st off: Start with branded fusion, fusion Tragedy and Albaz to summon Lubellion. CL1, activate tragedy's effect, add Aluber, CL2, activate Lubelion's effect, Fusion Albaz and Lubellion to summon Mirrorjade -2nd: Mirrorjade send Albion from the Extra deck to the GY, banish itself  -3rd: Normal summon Aluber, add Branded in Red from your deck to your hand  ( DO SOME ELDLICH STUFF HERE IF YOU CAN)  -4th: Move to EP, activate Lubellion's effect, set Branded Opening  -5th: During your opponent's turn, try to break their combo by CL1, Branded in Red, CL2, Branded Opening, discard 1 card, add Ad Libitum. Resolve, Cl2 ( y'all already know what to do), CL1, add Tragedy from the GY to your hand, fusion summon Guardian Chimera by Aluber on the field, Tragedy and Ad Libitum on your hand. then, CL1, activate Ad Libitum's effect, bring back Mirrorjade from the banish zone. Cl2, Tragedy, add Aluber. CL3, activate Guardian Chimera's effect, destroy 1 draw 2. Resolve and done.  (MAKES SURE TO DO SOME OTHER ELDLICH STUFFS BECAUSE THAT COMBO IS JUST FOR SUPPORTING)

deck_excerpt: A zombie deck combining Eldlich, Doomking Balerdroch, and the new Mayakashi cards.
deck_description: Mayakashi has become an actually viable strategy with the inclusion of the link-3. A single (uninterrupted) Hajun can turn into an Absolute Zero and a veritable Drident that floats on destruction. This paired with Balerdroch's continuous board prescnce and Eldlich's recursiveness (and generic zombie support) creates what I think can may be able to break into the meta. Granted, this deck is not going to be tier 1 or higher, but I believe it will be a semi-competitive deck that can actually see some success in the wake of Adventure, Phantom Knights, and combo Eldlich.   Some notes: 3x Yuki-Onna, the Icicle Mayakashi: This card is what is going to help push Mayakashi into meta contention. A link-3 that special summons the synchros from the GY on a quick effect best thing the archetype could have recieved, and is why I think it should be ran at 3 copies. The awesome part about this card is how it works with the link-2. If you link into the link-2, special summon Dakki, and the link up to the link-3, you can link back down into the link-2, special summon Dakki, and link back up again, letting you dump 2-3 of Icicle to the grave in a single turn. This does force you to play two of the link-2, which isn't great but is necessary. x2 Ghost Meets Girl - A Mayakashi and Shiranui's Tale: This card, in my opinion, is more of a gimmick than anything else. It's effect is absolutely busted, don't get me wrong, and will absolutely win you games if you can resolve it, but if you don't have access to your synchros or links it's more or less just a brick in hand. The number one issue with Mayakashi is how easy it is to stop it's main combo. An Ash, Imperm, or Veiler, will pretty much kill your Hajun's effect (which is why having Eldlich to fall back on is so important), and if your combo gets killed then you can't really make use of this card. Only playing two makes it so you can draw it sometimes but almost never in multiples. You can always search it if you know you can resolve it. No Crossout Designator: I don't really think Crossout Designator is worth it in this deck. Crossout is really amazing when it is imperative that your combo go through, but is eh when you have cards to fall back on (like the Eldlich cards). I would rather have more extenders or Eldlich cards than draw a Crossout because Crossout is really a brick if you draw it at the wrong time or if you draw multiples. Granted, the Mayakashi half will lost to Nibiru every so often because there are no Crossout's to protect them, but if that happens you'll usually have the Eldlich cards to fall back on. Also, you'll usually be going hand neutral with your opponent's Nibiru if you've only used Hajun from the hand for your Mayakashi combo, which really isn't too bad.   I really love Mayakashi and want to make this deck the best it can be. Any and all comments/critiques are appreciated, though I may take a while to respond.

deck_excerpt: Hippo Stall & OTK with Leeching the Light  Master Duel ***normal and rare cards only***
deck_description:
Write your deck strategy here... The OTK is simple
  1. Kaiju your opponent's monster
  2. Summon your tokens (Hippo Carnival spells)
  3. Leeching the Light (can be cast multiple times!)
  4. Attack with everything
  Other combos
  • Kaiju into Kaiju. Normal summon Neo Spacian Mole and bounce enemy's Kaiju back into your hand. Can be repeated every turn if your opponent doesn't can't deal with Mole.
  • Try to bait out MSTs throughout the game by setting Waboku, Draw Muscle and Jar of greed. Set Tenyi the turn before you drop the combo.
  • Angmarl the monarch can be summoned using your battle fader, performapal hip hippo or anchafroumite to search for whatever spell you need, usually Defence Muscle for draw. Leeching - Angmarl - 2nd Leeching if you want to commit hard.
  • Summon anchafroumite BEFORE hippo tokens to get a 6th monster (extra monster zone) to swing with during your Leeching the Light turn
  • Token Sundae is good to clear your board of tokens when it's clogged, while also removing enemy's backrow and battle immune or defence position monsters
The rest of the deck exists just to stall and draw for combo pieces. You probably want to go 2nd because cardcar d is your only turn 1 play. Most games you can stall long enough to see 2x Leeching the Light and Delg the 3rd. But if you use up all your leechings (max combo 3 times) you probably lose. This deck gets countered pretty hard by itself (cards like battle fader, waboku, etc.) Hippo tokens can wall off the opponent in a pinch but don't count on it. Piercing damage will hurt a lot. Use them for Defence Muscle draw and Token Sundae instead.  Use Waboku and Battle Fader to stall.

deck_excerpt: Fairly consistent Mystic Mine burn deck that can win going first and has decent chance going second.
deck_description:
Game plan:
  1. Get mine on field with various search cards and pots.
  2. Protect mine from self destruction with Field Barrier or Silent Wobby
  3. Get other protection for mine (Solemn Judgement and Dark Bribe)
  4. Use Goddess Skuld's Oracle to sculpt top of opponent deck so they can't draw into removal
  5. Burn with Cauldron of the Old Man
  Siding tips:
  • Side in Dimension Shifter and Lightning Storm if going second
  • Side out Silent Wobby if going second
  • Side in Prohibition if you know what removal opponent plays otherwise side in Cursed Seal of the Forbidden Spell, you can even side in both if you need more protection and you know you're going first
  Tips:
  • Don't place Field Barrier unless you have protection from Cosmic Cyclone since it's game over if mine gets hit
  • Use Amano-Iwato and Dark Ruler No More to safely place mine
  • Use Goddess Scold's Oracle to check what cards opponent plays, if you see twin twister or cosmic cyclone you can side it out for prohibition and just call it in advance
  • If Planet Pathfinder get's hit with Infinite Impermanence or Effect Veiler (which does happen because format is filled with handtraps), you can make Salamangreat Almiraj and then Secure Gardna to make it harder for opponent to OTK you, it's a last resort but it came up a few times and I drew into mine later

deck_excerpt: An improvement to my original 60 card chimera of a deck. Now, it's actually really good. Even at 60 cards >:)
deck_description: Okay, so I'm back with a revision to this chimera of a deck I made after I failed to read Adamancipator Analyzer's effect properly thinking it would work on Megalith. However, when I realized it didn't work I did however realize that they synergized well and after that went full-blown mad scientist and added in a Thunder Dragon engine and the deck worked well enough that I decided to stick to the idea and improve upon it.  If you want you can see the original deck here: https://ygoprodeck.com/adamancipator-megalith-thunder-dragon-no-this-isnt-a-joke/  So first I feel like I should explain the changes I made and why I made them.  C1: Ratio changes.  I have changed the ratios for the deck greatly to improve general consistency. Now the Adamancipator and Thunder Dragon decks are the core parts while the Megalith part is more included for some spicy plays like Numeron Dragon. I upped the previous thunder dragon package to a full engine to ensure I get Colossus more often and can set up Titan as well. I improved the Adamancipator Package by adding Guardian, I had to take out Leonite to account for the second Titan because I encountered a situation where I desperately needed it a few times. I also upped the Researcher to 3 but that was just to improve the deck slightly. I completely removed Friends because it really didn't matter. I removed the Impcantations because they did little to improve the deck and often ended up clogging the board which hurt the deck greatly. I changed around a few other cards and if you want to compare them you can check out the original list.  C2: Strategy changes.  Really the biggest change is that Thunder Dragon does the most legwork for the deck and the Adamancipator portion can get you some time to set up Thunder Dragon, or just win the game by itself in some cases. I added Verte to improve the Thunder Dragon portion and it has been a lifesaver on a few occasions. Other than that nothing has really changed since if the Megalith stuff happens the deck can really pop off, but even if it doesn't happen the deck can end up wild. In one case by turn 3 I tested how far I could go and ended on a Titan, Colossus, Access code, Borrel, Draglubion, and Numeron Dragon. Really the Numeron Dragon was just for fun but it was probably the single most explosive turn I had although if I played the deck better it could probably go higher.  C3: Changes in weaknesses.  These really haven't changed other than cards like macro or Dimensional fissure actually help the Thunder Dragon part greatly, you still get hosed pretty hard by skill drain if it gets set up for too long. Really, if I could add in some back row removal I would love to, if anyone has suggestions for a card to replace please tell me, I would love to know. My best guess would be to remove the Preparations and the Called by and put in 3 twin twister since it would help the Thunder Dragon portion with its discard effects. Ash blossom of course hurts but it can be managed.  C4: Changes against meta.  I'd say the only meta deck that counters the deck heavily is Eldlich but that's just because of the floodgates mostly. I haven't seen any Drytron yet and if an opponent had it they might have surrendered before I could find out. Chances are it's because I haven't hit Platinum yet but I'm close. I really just haven't had the time to play. Work and other obligations have gotten in the way. But I'll try and if I get there I will come back to update this portion.

deck_excerpt: A N/R rarity only Majespecter deck, splashed with generic WIND Spellcasters for coverage and added offensive pressure.
deck_description:
Hi, Grayewick the Fusionist here, back with another Pendulum list, but this time I'm presenting a deck that I personally haven't played a lot of, but I've encountered quite a few times in the past and still remembers how frustrating it was to deal with their boss monster (until it was banned RIP, it could come back now tho amidst all this Brave token shenanigans and DPE, surely but I digress), Majespecters. Why play this deck? Okay so, since Majespecter Unicorn - Kirin is still banned for whatever reason, I gotta admit, it's really tough looking for ways to pressure your opponent in this deck. My first concept even was splashing in a little Silent Magician engine, aiming to bring out Silent Magician LV8 because she's a 3500 body that is unaffected by your opponent's Spell effects, but ultimately scrapped it in favor of versatility in the form of Synchro and Xyz summoning (that's also why the link for this list says "Silent Majespecters" because my dumbass forgot to edit it before submitting so, that's annoying but anyway). Also, so long as a deck gives me an excuse to play Magician of Hope, I will do it, since it's my favorite Pendulum Monster. The Main Deck: Might as well call it "WIND Spellcaster, the deck" because you'll be reading that a lot. • The Majespecters (x3 Kyubi, Ogama, & Nekomata, & x2 Yata & Bunbuku) - Well... we can't really play a Majespecter list without Majespecter cards, so... self explanatory. They're all WIND Spellcaster Pendulum Monsters with Pendulum Scales of 2 and 5 that surprisingly does not have any Pendulum effect, and does something when Normal or Special Summoned, which are the following:
  1. Kyubi searches a Majespecter Trap.
  2. Ogama sets a Majespecter Spell/Trap directly from your Deck.
  3. Nekomata searches a Majespecter card.
  4. Yata searches a Majespecter Spell.
  5. Bunbuku searches a Majespecter monster.
• x3 Oafdragon Magician - He's a 2100 ATK beater, that is a WIND Spellcaster, which is relevant for the purposes of both our Majespecter cards and Xyz Summoning. We could also always retrieve him with Ninaruru, the Magistus Glass Goddess anyway, which is one of our primary defenders. His effect isn't as relevant since we're not really playing other Pendulum Magicians, which most of them are all at high rarity and there's not a lot of good pay off for them anyway. • x3 Windwitch - Snow Bell - Our only Tuner, because she's the only good low Level WIND Spellcaster Tuner at N/R rarity, and she's Level 1, so it shouldn't be hard to Synchro Summon with her. • x1 Planet Pathfinder - Our Terraforming, and we can only play it at 1 because Konami limited it for this format lol. • x3 Majesty's Pegasus - The archetypal Field Spell, non-searchable so play it at 3. Gives your Majespecters boost in ATK and DEF for added pressure because, they're honestly pretty frail. It also allows you to Tribute ANY WIND Spellcaster to Special Summon a Majespecter monster from the Deck. • The Majespecter Spells (x3 Storm, x2 Cyclone, & x1 Sonics) - We only play a few of these because this is still a Pendulum deck at the end of the day and we'd much rather search it through the effects of our Majespecter, except for Storm which is always nice to have. Don't worry, there are no Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring in this format, so hurrah. Their effects are:
  1. Storm tributes a WIND Spellcaster monster to target a monster your opponent controls and shuffles it to the Deck.
  2. Cyclone tributes a WIND Spellcaster monster to target a monster your opponent controls and destroys it.
  3. Sonics is an archetypal Honest but halves the damage it deals.
• The Majespecter Traps (x3 Tempest, & x2 Tornado & Supercell) - This we could afford to play fewer of, except for Tempest which is a counter trap, because we have more access to Trap searchers than Spells. Their effects are:
  1. Tempest is an archetypal Solemn Strike at a cost of only tributing a WIND Spellcaster monster, which is great in a low rarity format like this.
  2. Tornado tributes a WIND Spellcaster monster to target a monster your opponent controls and banish it.
  3. Supercell is a Continuous Trap that makes it so that while you have a Majespecter card in your Pendulum Zone, the activation and effects of your other Majespecter cards cannot be negated. It also allows you to recycle Majespecter cards (including itself) in your GY and draws you a card. Currently debating playing more of this for insurance.
• x3 Igknight Reload - Consistency piece. The Extra Deck: Synchro monsters • Old Entity Hastorr - A generic 2300 ATK Level 4 WIND Synchro monster that's is a Fiendish Chain when sent to the GY as a monster, and a permanent Snatch Steal when removed while equipped to a monster. • Battlewasp - Azusa the Ghost Bow - A generic 2200 ATK Level 5 WIND Synchro monster, who is only relevant because she's a WIND, and that means she gets the protection that Windwitch - Snow Bell bestows when used as a Synchro Material for a WIND Synchro monster. You could play Crystron Ametrix if you want a 2500 ATK beater instead, which is also neat because she switches all Special Summoned monsters your opponent controls to Defense Position upon her Synchro Summon. • Hi-Speedroid Kendama - Another generic 2200 ATK Level 6 WIND Synchro monster that deals piercing damage and can revive itself on corner cases. • Odd-Eyes Meteorburst Dragon or Psy-Framelord Zeta - A generic Level 7 Synchro monster that is a Battle Phase floodgate for monsters. It can also Special Summon 1 monster from your Pendulum Scale for the purposes of your Majespecter Spells/Traps. Zeta is just another generic Level 7 Synchro monster that can get rid of any of your opponent's Special Summoned monsters by banishing the two of them until your next Standby Phase, although requiring that monster to be in face-up Attack Position. Good against Xyz monsters. • Nirvana High Paladin - Your main focus is not summoning this card as fast as you can, but if you can make this card, at least you have it when you need it, because it makes OTKing easier in a deck as slow as Majespecters. Xyz monsters • Number 25: Force Focus - A generic Rank 6 monster with a Quick Effect targeting negation on any of your opponent's Level 5 or higher effect monsters. Also a good body at 2800 ATK and 2400 DEF. The only good Rank 6 option besides Sword Breaker, which is a budget El Shaddoll Construct for mono-type decks. • Firewall eXceed Dragon - A generic Rank 4 beatstick, which is only here because we're playing Link 3 monsters, so we can pump it up to 4000 ATK. • Magician of Hope - It special summons a Pendulum Monster from your hand, it can place itself to the Pendulum Zone for an attack protection, it can attach a Pendulum Monster from your GY to itself as Xyz Material for the purposes of its effect, and most importantly, it can be Pendulum Summoned if you can Pendulum Summon Level 4 despite it being an Xyz Monster. It's also a 2500/2000 body on board, which is neat because Majespecters do allow you to Pendulum Summon Level 4 monsters. • Number 82: Heartlandraco - A generic Rank 4 beater that gains a protection against battle, provided that you have a face-up Spell, and we're playing Pendulums and their Field Spell, so yeah. It can also attack directly by detaching an Xyz material. • Ninaruru, the Magistus Glass Goddess - A Rank 4 EARTH Rock Xyz monster that requires Spellcasters as Xyz material, in which we have plenty of, with an effect to detach an Xyz material to add a Level 5 or higher Spellcaster monster in your GY to your hand, which is why we can play Oafdragon Magician. We can't really make full use of both its equip effects, being a Spell/Trap destruction and allowing a monster equipped with her to attack twice because we're not playing any enablers for it, but she's fine as a 2400 DEF blocker. • Number 75: Bamboozling Gossip Shadow - A 2600 DEF body on board that has an interruption in the form of a replacement effect in response to an opponent's monster effect. • Number 49: Fortune Tune - It's a small towers monster, that can recycle itself and 2 of your Level 3 Majespecters in the GY upon getting sent there from the field. Link monsters • x2 Hraesvelgr, the Desperate Doom Eagle - A Link 3 monster that requires 2+ WIND monsters, which we play plenty of. It's our main beatstick for the deck, which also happens to have good Link arrows for the purposes of Pendulum Summoning. Also messes up your opponent's GY set up. • Shinobi Insect Hagakuremino - A generic Link 2 WIND Insect monster that's only here for the purposes of Link climbing. Additional notes and final thoughts: I'm not gonna lie, I've had a little bit of choice paralysis when it comes to building this deck but before everything else, free Kirin already Konami, I'm serious, this deck has a lot of versatile control tools, but lacks offensive pressure. This deck is so reliant on the Extra Deck and maintaining tempo to gain advantage, it's not even funny, but once you're able to pick up and keep it up, you'll most likely be fine because that's just the nature of control decks in general. I'm not really the type of person who are big on decks like this, so I'm sure anyone could pilot this more efficiently than me, but if I were to describe it, it's almost similar to playing Altergeists and even Salamangreats to an extent. You don't win by overwhelming your opponent, you win by burning their resources out, and in a slower format like this where only N/R rarity cards are legal, I think it's a pretty strong contender. Also, you could choose to play this deck at full control, by cutting out the Tuner and and other consistency pieces that you're comfortable not playing with and using Counter Traps or chainable Traps instead, but I think this deck already got more than enough back row to deal with your opponent's monsters mainly, so if I were to do it, I'd probably splash in some Magic Drain, Dust Tornado or Mystical Space Typhoon to deal with back row, Horn of Heaven, Pulling the Rug, or Forced Back. If you have any questions or thoughts, feel free to express them down in the comments and I'll respond to them as soon as I possibly can.

deck_excerpt: Chaos MAX Turbo with Dogmatikas and Gizmek Orochi
deck_description: Core Play: Make Blue-Eyes Chaos MAX Dragon as fast as possible -Comes out as 4k Immune to targeting+destruction by card effect, inflicts 2x piercing -Deck has several cards that send Herald of the Arc Light to GY so search Ritual Monster or Spell. Fallback plan If the ritual monsters aren't getting the job done or you can't get to them you can go into rank a 8 play instead Level 8 options -Ritual monsters that aren't getting you a win -Orochi summon by banishing 8 from deck (can summon on opponent's end phase so on your main phase 1 he can activate his other effect) -Dogmatikas have special summon conditions related to extra deck monsters(on sent to GY, if on field, banish 1 from GY) Draglubion Overlay 2 Level 8s, Detach 1 to activate, Special summon C107 and attach 107 as material so ithas full effects -Comes out at 4500, detach 1 to negate everything else on field for the rest of the turn. Can tribute 2 for 2 additional attacks. -This is the your last special summon for the turn, only C107 gets to attack that turn Link Play Make Bishbaalkin in extra zone with Diviner and another 8 so that tokens fill all of your unoccupied monster zones. Make Security Dragon, then Phoenix, then Cerberus (using Linkuriboh to make tokens into different names). Turn Security and Cerberus into Gryphon and place next to Phoenix.
Classic Cyber Dragon OTK. There were so many ways I could've made this deck, if you try this out feel free to play multiple copies of the cards or lower the card count.  Have fun and Enjoy!

deck_excerpt: With the demon slaying Shiranui you access your GY, banished pile, hand and field in a solid synchro spam strategy! A deck specifically made for Maste
deck_description: A deck specifically made for Master Duel's N/R Rarity Event.  The fan favourite deck of Duel Links is back to synchro spam in Master Duel's N/R event! This deck's strategy is to go second, clear the board with board-breakers and summon strong Synchro Monsters from your Extra Deck toolbox. The usual level 6 synchro to go for is Archfiend Zombie Skull, since it renders itself and other Zombie monsters cannot be destroyed by card effects. The main level 7 synchro is the hero of this deck, Shiranui Squiresaga, who offers various removal options based on what you banish from the GY.  If you have any questions about this deck, feel free to ask me in the comments below!

deck_excerpt: Rock spam... With an Egyptian twist! With generic rock support, a powerful midrange deck that turbos out Extra Deck monsters is made possible. A deck
deck_description: A deck specifically made for Master Duel's N/R Rarity Event.  Rock spam... With an Egyptian twist! Most of the rock support that had been racking up the last couple years have been largely untouched in the N/R event, and it comes together here in Triamid Adamancipator.  Triamid is a solid rock archetype that also has strong recursion and removal in the form of their field spells. In particular, Triamid Pulse does EVERYTHING for rock types: spot destruction, reviving a rock from the GY, and GY recycling of fieldspells with +1 draw! Triamid Loading makes every rock type monster float into a Triamid monster, and as an added bonus, searches out any Triamid S/T.  Just like in the usual Adamancipator strategies, the archetype is splashed into rock archetypes (in this case, Triamid) for easy access to bigger Extra Deck monsters and enhanced consistency.  Miracle Rupture has four targets in the deck to send to the GY and they each provide beneficial effects:  1. Nemeses Keystone (banish fodder for Gigantes, free summon and recycles banished monsters), 2. Tackle Crusader (Book of the Moon/Bounce S/T), 3. Revival Golem (Free body on board), and 4. Sentry Soldier of Stone (Free body on board).  With Adamancipator and Triamid working together coupled with generic rock support, a powerful midrange deck that turbos out Extra Deck monsters is made possible.  If you have any questions about this deck, feel free to ask me in the comments below!

deck_name: Dark Storm Turbo (Master Duel, N/R rarity only)
deck_excerpt: A Master Duel deck, featuring the Malicevorous, that is focused on turbo-ing out either Number 96: Dark Mist or Number C96: Dark Storm, all at N/R rar
deck_description: Hi, Grayewick the Fusionist here, back not with a Fusion deck but instead cosplaying as Number 96 from Yu-Gi-Oh! ZEXAL. Anyway, here I am presenting you one of the most cheesy beatdown deck in existence, Dark Mist turbo. Why play this deck? Well, the main goal of this deck is to bring out either Number 96: Dark Mist or Number C96: Dark Storm, and I'd say it's pretty fun, and you got access to one of the strongest Rank-Up-Magic spells in the game which surprisingly is just a R rarity, Rank-Up-Magic Numeron Force, which is a Dark Ruler No More or more precisely Kali Yuga except just for any face-up cards, especially in a format where Metalfoes will be everywhere. The Main Deck: • The kitchen utensils (Knife, Fork, & Spoon) - Number 96's archetypal monsters, the Malicevorous. Have three of them in grip and you have a guaranteed Dark Mist. Have three of them and a Rank-Up-Magic and you have a guaranteed Dark Storm. • The Live Twins (Ki-sikil & Lil-la) - Either of them is a guaranteed two Level 2 bodies on board. Have either of them and a Caligo Claw Crow in hand and you have a guaranteed Dark Mist. • Caligo Claw Crow - A free body, provided that you have at least 1 DARK monster, but can only Special Summon itself once per turn this way. • Crimson Resonator - Your crustiest Normal Summon. It's a Level 2 DARK Tuner, so I guess it works with Caligo Claw Crow. Gives you room to play Synchros, however much it matters. • Giant Germ - Your floater. The worst thing you could do in a turn is to set this card and pass. • The Rank-Up Spells (x3 Numeron Force & x2 Limited Barian's Force) - They're Rank-Up spells, the only one that we have access to that are generic, in fact. Limited Barian's Force is just your bare bones Rank-Up spell while Numeron Force, as for the reasons I have stated previously, is the best going second against an established board. • Psychic Blade - More Damage. You could also use Moon Mirror Shield instead, I guess. • Mystical Space Typhoon - Back row removal for coverage. • Forbidden Chalice - Good against monsters with problematic effects. • Dark Illusion - Greatest protection that we have access to, since most of our boss monsters are all DARK, and it's a Counter Trap, and we need to play as many protection as we can get since our boss monsters are pretty frail outside combat. The Extra Deck: Xyz monsters • Number 96 (Dark Mist & Dark Storm) - Our main boss monsters. Although very fragile against card effects, I haven't seen anything in the N/R format that can trump this card in combat. Dark Storm is a bit sturdier, since it has an added protection of battle protection. • Number 65 (Djinn Buster & King Overfiend) - Our second boss monsters. Djinn Buster has a quick play monster effect negation that also burns your opponent, while King Overfiend is a one-sided Skill Drain. That itself should speak volumes to this card's power in an extremely limited format like this. • Number 45: Crumble Logos the Prophet of Demolition - He is a walking Prohibition or Fiendish Chain against any of your opponent's face-up card, provided that he himself also stays face-up on the field. He's also pretty tough, having a 2200 ATK body. • Number 43: Manipulator of Souls - If all else fails, and we need to stall, we could always summon this card that is indestructible by battle or card effects, provided that we equip a "Number" card to it by its effect, in which we will most likely do since all Xyz monsters that we have are "Number" monsters. Synchro monsters • Old Entity Hastorr - A generic 2300 ATK Level 4 WIND Synchro monster that's is a Fiendish Chain when sent to the GY as a monster, and a permanent Snatch Steal when removed while equipped to a monster. • Underworld Fighter Balmung - A generic 2100 ATK Level 4 DARK Synchro monster that replaces itself upon getting destroyed by a card effect. • Crystron Quandax - A generic Level 4 Synchro Tuner monster, whose purpose is only to Synchro climb with Iron Chain Dragon into Stardust Chronicle Spark Dragon in which if it wasn't obvious enough, clearly cope, but since we don't have anything else better to do anyway, why not? • Iron Chain Dragon - A decent generic 2500 ATK Level 6 Synchro monster that mills the top 3 cards of your opponent's deck upon dealing battle damage. • Stardust Chronicle Spark Dragon - Summon this if you want/can, but don't focus on it. It's just here because of big number and because you could make it when the situation allows you. Honorable mentions • Cherry Inmato - A Level 2 DARK Plant Tuner that floats upon getting destroyed by battle. • Krebons - A Level 2 DARK Psychic Tuner that can just sit on the field and avoid battle destruction by paying 800 LP to negate an attack directed towards it. • T.G. Metal Skeleton - A Level 2 DARK Zombie monster just here because it can Special Summon itself after a monster (in your possession, most likely) is destroyed by battle or an opponent's card effect. • Blackwing - Gust the Backblast - A Level 2 DARK Winged Beast monster that can Special Summon itself if you control no other cards. • Dark Rose Fairy - A Level 2 DARK Fairy monster that can Special Summon itself from your hand if a Tuner monster(s) is Special Summoned, and can recycle itself by sending a card from your hand to the GY. • Doppelwarrior - A Level 2 DARK Warrior monster that can Special Summon itself from your hand if a monster(s) is Special Summoned from your GY. • Spear Cretin - A Level 2 DARK Fiend monster that can set up an annoying battle phase loop where having access to at least 2 of these and 1 of them being in the GY is full "combo". After getting flipped, use its effect to Special Summon another Spear Cretin from your GY in face-down Defense Position. Its effect is not once per turn. Final thoughts I don't expect this to be a "top tier" deck, since it's not really the most versatile deck available for the N/R format, but I can see a potential with this deck alongside possibly having access to more control tools instead, and considering the other tools at its disposal. I'm definitely going to be testing more of this throughout the event, since there's a lot of other good extenders and/or starters that are rarity locked, like Ret-time Reviver Emit-ter. Overall, it is a one trick pony deck that aims to abuse a very powerful Rank-Up spell and punish your opponent for unnecessarily overextending. If you have any questions or thoughts, feel free to express them down in the comments and I'll respond to them as soon as I possibly can.

deck_name: Counter Fairies (Master Duel, N/R rarity only)
deck_description: Hi,  Grayewick the Fusionist here, back with a deck that I love using to piss my opponents the fuck off but this time in just N and R rarities only, Counter Fairies. Why play this deck? Well, it's always a good time playing Counter Fairies. It's not necessarily a good time playing against them but, you know... that's the point of the deck, and that's never your problem lmao. Not much lot else to say about the deck, especially if you've been playing this game for a long time, by now you should know how annoying Fairy monsters are. Yes, this deck plays slow but who cares if your opponent is unable to play at all. The main deck: The Fairies • Herald of Orange Light - Yes, this card is only a R rarity. If you've played or against Drytrons, yeah... you already know. It's your main monster negate, and you can recycle it with The Sanctum of Parshath. • Bountiful Artemis - Your main source of draw power. It's not once per turn, it's not once per copy of the card, it's one draw per Bountiful Artemis, each time you activate a Counter Trap. • Meltiel, Sage of the Sky - Your way of gaining LP, and interruption in the form of non-targeting destruction, provided that "The Sanctuary in the Sky" or The Sanctum of Parshath is on the field, since the latter counts as the former. • Guiding Ariadne - The main reason why you're still alive, even after activating all that Counter Traps, although we're not really using Counter Traps that pay LP for cost, so the only thing this card will mitigate is the discard cost to maintain card advantage. • Minerva, Scholar of the Sky - Your main beat stick, and recycler, provided that "The Sanctuary in the Sky" or The Sanctum of Parshath is on the field. • Condemned Witch - Normal Summon Condemned Witch, add Forbidden Chalice. The Spells • The Sanctum of Parshath - One of your most important cards. It protects your Set Spells/Traps from targeting and destruction, it recycles your Fairies and Counter Trap cards from your GY and stacks them to your Deck, and it counts as "The Sanctuary in the Sky" for the purposes of our monsters' effects. • Mystical Space Typhoon - Back row removal for coverage. • Forbidden Chalice - Walmart Imperm, except it can be activated during the Damage Step. The Counter Traps • Seven Tools of the Bandit - Trap negate at a cost of paying 1000 LP. • Magic Drain - Spell negate that forces your opponent to -1 just to negate this. • Cursed Seal of the Forbidden Spell - Spell negate for the rest of the Duel at a cost of discarding a Spell specifically, that's why we can afford to play Chalices and MSTs for fodder. • Forced Back - A way to negate your opponent's Normal Summon and waste it by returning it to the hand. Not good in terms of card advantage but good in terms of ramping up tempo. • Black Horn of Heaven - A way to negate your opponent's Special Summons (that does not start a Chain) and destroy that monster for no cost. The side deck: Yes, no Extra Deck, because the available Fairy tuners suck so... yeah. Anyway. • Aurora Paragon - YEP floodgate. You can afford to just set monsters anyway so it's not much of a big deal for you, plus you can recycle it with Sanctum, so that's that. • Chaos Trap Hole - A way to negate your opponent's Special Summon of LIGHT or DARK monster(s) and banish them at a cost of 2000 LP. Works well with Guiding Ariadne. • The Selection - A way to negate your opponent's Summon of a monster, provided that it shares a type with a monster that is already on the field. Strong consideration since mono-type decks will be the go-to strategy in this format. • Pulling the Rug - A way to negate both of your opponent's monster's activation and effect that is activated upon a monster's Normal Summon and destroy that monster for no cost. • Divine Wrath - Monster negate at a cost of discarding a card. Final thoughts I mean... it's Counter Fairies. Everyone who plays this game pretty much already knows what the strategy wants to do, or what it wants you not to do. It's a heavily reactive resource management based deck that always wants to go first to be able to set up plays, pretty much loses to massive consecutive board wipes, has weak recovery against faster decks, but in a slow format like N/R rarity only, I think it's got a good shot at finding success. If you have any questions or thoughts, feel free to express them down in the comments and I'll respond to them as soon as I possibly can.

deck_excerpt: Just a Cyberdark deck with Dragunity flare.
deck_description: The main plan of this deck is the same as a normal Cyberdark Deck just with a DSragunity engine splashed in for some flare.

Fluffal

      This archetype focuses on Fusion Summon tactics, primarily to search out and recycle "Polymerization" while also utilizing cards such as "Edge Imp Sabres" and "Toy Vendor" along with "Fluffal Dog", giving the player easy access to the necessary cards to Fusion Summon "Frightfur" Fusion Monsters. As Fusion Summoning requires a large amount of cards, several "Fluffal" monsters help to quickly gain card advantage (such as "Fluffal Dog" and "Fluffal Wings") and recycle the necessary cards required upon being used as Fusion Material Monsters (such as "Fluffal Cat" and "Fluffal Rabbit"). The "Frightfur" monsters can be Fusion Summoned using "Edge Imp" monsters as the Fusion Material. They rely primarily on "Fluffal" archetype with boosting effects. "Frightfur" monsters also have offensive effects that either boost their ATK or grant additional attacks ("Frightfur Bear", "Frightfur Sabre-Tooth", "Frightfur Wolf", "Frightfur Tiger", "Frightfur Kraken"), removing cards on the opponent's field ("Frightfur Tiger", "Frightfur Leo", "Frightfur Kraken", "Frightfur Cruel Whale"), prevents the opponent from activating cards or effects when they attack ("Frightfur Chimera", "Frightfur Sheep"), and even steal away an opponent's monster by equipping them to themselves or Special Summon them to their controller's field ("Frightfur Bear", "Frightfur Chimera"). Some "Frightfur" monsters have a small weakness in having specific "Edge Imp" monsters for Fusion Materials (outside of "Chimera"), but cards like "Frightfur Patchwork", "Fusion Reserve" and "Fusion Conscription" can help you in getting your needed "Edge Imps" to the hand and "Fluffal Sheep" helps in recycling both your "Edge Imp" and "Fluffal" monsters. All of the "Edge Imps" possess helpful abilities on their own, such as "Edge Imp Chain" searching your "Frightfur" Spell and Trap support whenever it hits the Graveyard, "Edge Imp Saw" providing extra draw power, and "Edge Imp Tomahawk" being able to substitute for any of the other "Edge Imp" monsters should they not be available in the hand or field. The Deck responds badly to too many out-of-archetype cards, as they cannot be fused with, and the other Summoning methods are not nearly as important as your Fusion Summoning. However, Fluffals can potentially be merged with archetypes such as Gem-Knights, Shaddolls, or Invoked. (Traditional Format only) In particular, the splash-ability of Brilliant Fusion and its effect to send Fluffal Wings straight to the GY while Summoning Gem-Knight Seraphinite for an extra Normal Summon makes it a popular choice.

deck_excerpt: Best ABC deck to play in 2022!
deck_description: ABC is one of my favourite rogue decks since 2019 and Union Carrier abuse. Right now in this deck with both Adventurer engine and DPE engine there are more than 2 openings in this deck. It can go from Infinity and 1 handtrap to ABC+DPE+Masquerena with it's openings. Currently for this deck I made there are around 5 openings which is alredy a big plus for this deck that lost so much from getting his best combo card, Union Carrier, banned. You can start from classical Union Hangar opening or Galaxy Soldier opening to a brand new Adventurer opening. You can also open with DPE or with Gadget+Destrudo opening. Those alone can solidly for a rogue deck alone, but if openings are combined together, they can go against meta decks like Virtual World or D/D or Invoked Shaddoll Dogmatika (ok the last one is bad to be honest but it is still played a lot online so I consider it a kind of meta deck). If you think that there are any better options for this deck, every idea is welcome.

deck_excerpt: Like your opponent having a deck? Me neither.
deck_description: This deck is very simple. Tribute on opponents monster for a kaiju, and summon one of your own if you have it in your hand. then use a Mysterune spell to summon a Mysterune fusion monster. Attack the kaiju with the fusion monster to take 3000 damage to activate inferno tempest. Unless your opponent is playing Sky Striker or Eldlich, Inferno tempest should banish most of their deck, and since 3 Necroface have been banished, both players banish an additional 15 cards. Then finally finish mulling your opponent with your other Mysterune quick play spells and Hand Destruction. Called by the grave was added in incase your opponent tries to use hand traps on your draw cards. This decks big weakness is its hard to draw inferno tempest, and this deck is second going, so if you go first you just have to pray you can stay alive for a turn. Also Secret village of the spellcasters completely shuts this deck down. At the end of the day, this has been the best Inferno Tempest mull deck I've played, hope you enjoy! EDIT: Oh! Don't forget, Mysterune spells skip your next battle phase, meaning you have to summon your Mysterune fusion monster during your battle phase and NOT your main phase, otherwise you can't attack and the combo is ruined.

deck_excerpt: Malefic deck packed with beat sticks that shut down your opponent
deck_description: A very strong deck with Malefic monsters. Basically summoning beat sticks and shattering your enemy. Only thing is that you need to rely on "Malefic World" for most matches. Nonetheless "Pot of Acquisitiveness" is a life-saver for this deck as well as "Malefic Divide" since you'll be discarding and banishing monsters quite a lot. I believe it's quite a risky deck but def worth the fun and truly powerful when you learn how to play with it. Also, I believe that two "Pot of Acquisitiveness" might not be enough, as well as the one "Malefic Divide", so maybe adding an additional copy would make it better or perhaps add a "Monster Reborn" or smth.  The cards on the side deck are alternatives for some of the cards in the deck. "Effect Veiler" can replace "Skill Drain", and the extra "Malefic Paradox Dragon" can replace "Baronne De Fleur". Unfortunately, I can't think of any other replacements for the rest of the deck, in case some might be too expensive.
