deck_excerpt: Negate, negate, negate, negate, neg... Fun deck to keep up with the Meta in Master Duel
deck_description: If you're looking for a deck to help battle the meta slaves, this might be the one. Aside from the huge upfront cost to build this deck, it is super fun and sets up unbeatable boards like those at the top of the tier list. There are no single line plays for this deck so it can take a while to get familiar with it but the general gist of how to play it goes something like this. Step 1: Get two pendulum monsters on the board. Step 1.5: If you can complete step one while having an additional Mythical Beast Jackal King, you're gonna have a good time. This will stop many hand traps from ruining the rest of your combo. Step 2: Link Electrumite and put Astrograph Sorcerer into your extra deck Step 3: Pop a pendulum spell with Electrumite and return Astrograph to your hand, special summon him, add one card to your hand and draw a card. Step 4: Link Selene using the Astrograph  Step 5: Pendulum summon to stack your board. Step 6: From this point there are a few way to go, a lot of time time your board will be stacked enough to just end, but sometimes you need to flex more so go into Odd-Eyes Vortex Dragon and pop him with a Mighty Master or if you have enough material on the board, use Vortex Dragon and another card to go into Masquerena to go into Apollousa next turn for more negate. There are quite a few intricacies in these steps that aren't spelt out here, but you learn those with practice, or by watching here.

deck_excerpt: Invader of Darkness - Anti-Quick-Play Spell Deck - Squire, Dark Spirit and GY Revival Engine
deck_description: Feel free to scroll down to the Deck Profile if you don't want to read the nitty-gritty, here. This is my attempt at casting the Invader of Darkness as a viable boss monster within a worthy deck, focusing on graveyard revival strategies, Squires and Dark Spirit cards for his consistent summoning and shutdown of quick-play spells (Chalice, MST, E. Teleport, B. of Moon, Super Poly, Cyclone, Controller, Twisters, etc). Depending on the match-up, Vanity's Fiend and Lair of Darkness can further shut down your opponent's ability to summon monsters and defend against the Invader! I enjoy Allure and Upstart as draw cards that help prevent bricking, along with the first effect of Dark Spirit's Mastery as the primary search card for the Invader of Darkness (IOD). Usually, hard-drawing IOD isn't absolutely terrible: seeing him or Mastery in your opening hand, with Edea or Reinforcement, will bring out Invader of Darkness on your first turn. Play Mastery (If you don't have IOD in hand) to Discard 1 > Search & Add IOD > Normal summon Edea (or use Reinforcement to search Edea first) > Special summon Eidos > Use Eidos' effect to tribute both Squires to Tribute summon IOD. If you hard draw IOD and Mastery: Play Mastery > Discard IOD > add another IOD from your deck. (IOD is decent in the GY if you control a Dark Spirit monster). If you don't have / aren't able to get IOD to hand while controlling the Squires, Extra Deck plays can save you (thinking Phoenix / Unicorn). You can rebuild a board the turn after Tribute or Link summoning away the Squires: Banish Eidos from GY > Special summon Edea from GY > Special summon Eidos (from deck). The Squires' special summoning effects thrive when they're in the GY together. I've tried Double Coston and Doomdog in the deck for reliable tribute summoning and searching for IOD, but think the Squires' ability to re-build a board (after being sent from Tribute / Link summoning or your own board wipe with Torrential Tribute), in addition to making tribute summoning easier in general is just too good for me to pass them up. The downsides are that their stats are terrible, Edea is a LIGHT type, and you need 3x of each to fuel the Squire engine but you do NOT want to hard-draw into Eidos; he is only useful in your deck, graveyard or on the field. (That's where Allure can help, along with cards like Mastery and Reincarnation that allow you to discard 1). If anyone has better ideas for low-level monsters, please share - I'm not currently incorporating Tuners / Synchros though I understand there's great DARK support in the Synchro world (Thinking Beelze). GY revival strategies (however cheap they are), also work in summoning IOD quickly; Foolish Burial can send IOD while Reborn or Call of the Haunted can special summon him. By quick-effect, either Dark Spirit monster card can trade places with IOD in the GY. Foolish and a Malice in your opening hand, for example, means IOD will make an appearance on your field within a turn: Play Foolish > Send IOD to GY > Normal summon Malice > (set traps) > pass turn > Swap Malice for IOD (quick-effect) when your opponent does basically anything. (IOD loses his effect when summoned by a Dark Spirit, simply becoming a 2900 beatstick / eventual XYZ material, so this is not the primary strategy). Vanity's Fiend is my current back-up boss monster for this deck, with his timing being crucial and summoning being conditional (a level 6, not searchable, can't be special summoned, etc). Ha Des and Neosphere are alternative back-up bosses in the side deck. Dark Necrofear could also work well (being a level 8 and searchable by Mastery, summonable with the Dark Spirits). In the extra deck, Zombiestien, Lancelot, Zombie Vamp and Queen of the Night can step in when the IOD isn't cutting it. Zombiestein is a beatstick with a single negate at the cost of detaching one and switching him to defense (DEF/1000). Lancelot can attack directly, pop one monster and negate one spell/trap. Queen of the Night requires 3x Level 8's so she hardly ever comes out, but two of her effects are useful: detach 1 to negate 1, or detach one to give a little attack boost to another monster. Thanatos (Rank-4) is great if Armageddon and Grepher are on the field and I want to make a heavy-hitter that becomes immune to card effect (quick-effect) by detaching 1. Break Sword is a great Rank-3 if you end up drawing several Dark Spirits, with his ability to destroy 2 cards (one of your own, one of your opponent's). Lair of Darkness can really shut down some decks' engines if they are attribute-specific, so my side deck runs 3x copies. It doesn't do much against certain decks, sort of like Zombie World, which has a similar effect and is usually only sided-in for specific match-ups. Torrential Tribute can devastate your opponent and leave you relatively unharmed if you control the Squires. Once banished from you GY, Eidos will special summon Edea from the GY, who can special summon another Eidos from the Deck, allowing for a very easy Tribute summon of IOD (if he's in your hand), all while your opponent's board has been wiped. If you had Call in your back row when you activated Torrential, and you destroyed an IOD on your field, you can bring him back out through Call's revival. If there are any suggestions, please let me know - thanks!

deck_excerpt: PK Fire Combo deck, trying to end on Masked Hero Dark Law, El Shaddoll Winda, and Dark Requiem Xyz Dragon
deck_description: Kind of a casual combo deck, not necessarily actually a serious deck here, but I had a combo idea, and I wanted to go for it. The idea was a super-pure combo deck that uses Cherubini to send a Shaddoll, Rusty to help set-up Requiems into Isolde to access Dark Law into Verte for Magicalized Fusion to make Winda. The combo actually works pretty well when you see Tour Guide or enough Extenders, but doesn't really leave room to play interaction, which makes siding hell and going second pretty rough. Still, I love this type of extended combo, I love putting up weird boards, and I wanted to manifest that in this deck.  This is take 2. Accesscode is decent for breaking boards and OTKing, but in the backrow matchup I really want Unchained Abomination. Cicada King is only an on-field monster negate, and truly wasn't worth making nearly as often as I thought, so I popped in Tornado Dragon. This gives me some sort of plan against Trap decks. To help the situation going second, I added some interactive cards - TTT isn't really great going second right now, but it certainly isn't bad, and it helps the deck play through hand traps and gather information going first, so it's lower risk than some other options. Imperm always seems sweet, but here a bluff is extra value. I don't think Droplets is that good in this deck going first, it is a very very card hungry deck, so these are mostly just discard fodder, but going second these can help break those unbreakable boards, and for amazing value. This makes siding less miserable, going second at least possible, and rounds things out in Trap matchups, but also makes the inconsistency problems the deck has worse, since you won't be seeing that broken starter (Tour Guide) as often. Still, being able to actually play Yu-Gi-Oh is nice, and reducing the brickiness of the deck is also nice.  It became a problem not to run 2 Dark Rank 4 Xyz for the Break Sword combos, so I cut Abyss Dweller, which was redundant with Dark Law anyways, and added Time Thief Redoer. Because you can often make a Rank 4 with a Trap and a Monster, Redoer seems like the best bet - there are a couple on-field negates, a versatile Book of Moon or two, and a couple very specific ways to negate summons, and not a lot else interesting in terms of Dark Ranks 4s, and Redoer does a half-decent Tornado Dragon impression while maybe sneaking extra value vs Spell heavy decks. I cut down interruption cards - while it is important to have some, the deck also already had some consistency issues, and the interruption suite made them a lot worse, so I'm trying to do damage control without giving up on going second.

deck_excerpt: Very powerful high aggressive combo deck
deck_description:
Hello, I am Masterpeace and I tested this deck for long time. This is what I came up ultimately. This is a hyper aggressive combo deck, that's why we play 31 monsters. Trust me, if you get into your combo, this deck is almost unstoppable. Unfortunately the original Red Dragon Archfiend, Red Nova Dragon and Hot Red Dragon Archfiend are no longer good anymore. The next best level 8 synchro monster is Chaos Ruler, that's why I play two copies. Supernova outpowers Red Nova in every sight, I replaced that one. I don't play Burning Soul, because you need to have combo to make this card live and if you want to make King Calamity in your opponents turn, it misses timing if you want to add a card from your graveyard. Don't get me wrong you still can play this card, but I would recommend not to. I choose Effect Veiler over Imperm, because it's a light tuner monster which comes in clutch for Supernova and Chaos Ruler. Combo 1: Crimson Resonator + Wandering King Wildwind
  1. Specialsummon Crimson, since you control no monsters
  2. Specialsummon Wildwind, since you control a fiend-type monster with 1500 atk or less
  3. Go into Red Rising and use its effect to bring back Crimson
  4. Effect Crimson, since you control only crimson and one dark-dragon-synchro monster
  5. Specialsummon one Creation Resonator and one Synkron Resonator
  6. Go into Supernova using Crimson, Creation, Synkron and Red rising
  7.  Effect Synkron, add back Crimson to your hand
  8. Congratulations, you haven't even normalsummoned
Combo 2: Crimson Resonator + Ascator, the Dawnwalker
  1. Specialsummon Crimson
  2. Effect Ascator, discard one, specialsummon Ascator from your hand and the fire ant from your deck
  3. Use fire ant and Ascator to go into Chaos Ruler
  4. Chaos Ruler effect: (You wanna see Synkron, Handtraps, Wildwind, Red Reign, Red Familiar etc.)
  5. Crimson effect: specialsummon one Chain Resonator and one Synkron from your deck (or two Synkron, depends)
  6. Go into Supernova using everything
  7. Effect Synkron, bounce back one Resonator you need
This is only the tip of the iceberg, there are way more combos. I wish you great victories with this absolute power deck!

Preferably go for White Wing Magician and Purple Poison Magician so that you can summon Timestar Magician, or an alternative is Harmonizing Magician. What we are going for here is trying to maximize our way to get Z-ARC out right now, Timestar being summon after using Pendulum Call will basically mean it and your other "Magician" monsters cannot be destroyed by card effects until your opponents end phase. With Timestar out you can also send the materials you need to grave using it's effect if the opponent attempts to destroy your pendulum scales, so if you have Double Iris and Black Fang already send White Wing and Purple Poison and vice versa. Then next turn search out Astrograph/Chronograph and bring out Z-ARC, united we stand is in there so that you can equip it onto Z-ARC so he can't be destroyed in battle unless they destroy the equip spell or they gain Z-ARC's attack points, United We Stand gives Z-ARC an extra 800 points per face up monster on the field so start bringing out a bunch of preferably strong monsters so you can back him up without worry! I've been playing Supreme Kings since they came out and built the deck the way I like it.

deck_excerpt: Bait and Stall Strategy - Synchros you Don't want to Mess With
deck_description: A Rose / Forest themed deck embracing a Bait and Stall strategy using the field spell "Ancient Forest" to destroy any monster that declares an attack at the end of that turn. Other cards like Spiritual Forest and Wall of Thorns can further stall attacks, especially if you control all of them at once. The offensive strategy comes into play when the deck's powerful Synchro and XYZ boss monsters reach the field, with efficient help from low-level Tuners like Hope Ear Squadron and Rose Girl. Board-clearing traps (like Torrential and Wall of Thorns) are built in to reinforce the risk of backfire, so your board is protected and allowed to build each turn. Lonefire is an amazing going-first Normal summon, with an effect allows you to special summon any Plant monster from your Deck by tributing itself (or another Plant you control). If you have set Wall of Thorns and control Lonefire in Attack position, you can Bait an attack on Lonefire and destroy their attack-position monsters, but if they don't attack, you benefit from Lonefire's effect each turn until it's off the field. Rose Paladin helps get main deck bosses to your hand and onto the field as quickly as possible via discarding herself to allow you a Deck search. For the Tuners, Hop Ear lets you Synchro summon during your opponent's turn, while Rose Girl recycles herself back to your hand and, being a Level 3 Earth type, can XYZ summon Meliae who can either give you a foolish burial effect (to send Hermitree), or the special summon (in defense) of any Plant from your Deck (almost always going to be Chirubime). Foolish Burial is almost always used to send Sylvan Hermitree to the GY, which by effect, allows you to re-arrange the top three cards of your Deck in any order, giving you more control over your next turn. Chirubime sets up a wall, special summons other Plants from the Deck, is an Earth-type and serves as excellent Rank-8 material. Any card effect that lets me special summon a Plant directly from my Deck is almost always going to be used on Chirubime in DEF for her amazing effects. Talaya is like a more offensive Level 8 Water-type version of Chirubime, who protects your other Plants from card effects while giving herself an ATK boost off of them. I'm still looking into alternative boss monsters for the Main Deck (Level 8 or 9 for the XYZ summons) and am absolutely open to hearing suggestions! The Synchro and XYZ monsters are what will give your opponent the most trouble. Ideally, Black Rose Dragon is summoned at the correct time to clear the field and go in for game. Queen of Thorns is super useful in this deck, especially if Ancient Forest is at play. She does 1,000 Burn damage to your opponent for every non-Plant monster they summon until she's dealt with. If she's destroyed by battle, your opponent's attacking monster is too (if you control Ancient Forest), and if Spiritual Forest is also on the field, she's protected from one attack per turn (you still take battle damage). Fairy King (XYZ) is extremely easy to bring out as well, using Rose Paladin and/or Eco. In addition to being great XYZ material in this deck, Eco can dual-serve as a hand-trap when/if burn damage is dealt to you, being special summoned rather than discarded. The World Tree, if preserved, grows counters when Plants go to the GY, two of which can be removed to destroy one card on the field. Plenty of Plant monsters end up in and out of the GY with this Deck, so this effect can usually go off once per turn as long as the tree stands. You can use Frozen Rose to send one Plant to the GY to draw two and feed the World Tree one counter. Wall of Thorns is like running three copies of Mirror Force, enforcing the deck's overall defensive-yet-aggressive strategy when you bait an attack. I think Spiritual Forest is stupid good in this deck as well, putting up yet another reason why your opponent would not want to declare an attack, forcing them to use card effects to get rid of your board.

deck_excerpt: Spam the field with your army of spellcasters to access your Extra Deck toolbox with the magical Magistus! A deck specifically made for Master Duel's
deck_description: A deck specifically made for Master Duel's N/R Rarity Event.  Spam the field with your army of spellcasters to access your Extra Deck toolbox with the magical Magistus! Out of the 16 Magistus cards, only 3 are inaccessible in the N/R event since they're Super/Ultra rarity, so many Magistus plays are still available.  The two Magistus Extra Deck monsters allow various toolbox options: Aiwass is an ATK boost (equip effect) and a quick "Change of Heart" while Ninaruru is a backrow pop/multi-attack (equip effect) and spellcaster GY recycling.  A sizeable Dogmatika package is included, serving as free special summons and big bodies on board.  Generic spellcaster support are Gagagashield (Turns a spellcaster into a "towers") and Unpossessed (Every monster floats into 1500 def spellcaster which are the Dogmatika and Magistus Zoroa).  If you have any questions about this deck, feel free to ask me in the comments below!

deck_excerpt: Sephylon Beatdown - Kristya Lockdown - Herald Negates
deck_description: A LIGHT Fairy deck with three operating strategies: Sephylon the Ultimate Timelord's 4000 ATK Beatdown, Archlord Kristya's Lockdown effect and The Herald of Perfection's discard-to-negate-anything engine. The goal was to work with Sephylon's difficult summoning condition and make him a viable boss monster in a deck, where the Level 8 Fairies he can summon also perform well on their own as powerful bosses in their own right (Primarily Kristya with 1x Hyperion as a backup boss (interchangeable with Vanity's Ruler, Guardian Eatos (although not searchable), Phosphorage, Majestic Mech - Goryu, Splendid Venus, or whatever high level Fairy you choose)). The Herald of Perfection can grant you at least one, usually up to three, negates per turn, by discarding other Fairy monsters from your hand (Heralds are hand-traps in and of themselves). I run 3x Purple Herald in the side deck in case I face a trap-heavy deck (thinking Eldlich). The Heralds' discard effects quickly fill your GY and make summoning Sephylon possible, who can be searched by Card of the Soul (while you have 8000K Life Points) or Power Angel Valkyrie. Power Angel can search Sephylon from the deck if she's on the field while you negate something your opponent does, most easily accomplished by discarding a Fairy while you control Perfection. An alternative is to activate something like a Solemn trap while you control Power. The Agent of Creation / Shine Ball engine is not only great for getting 3-4 Fairies in the GY quickly, but also for the obvious Link-summoning capabilities. Manju makes getting Perfection on the field doable within 2 turns. While Sanctum of the Parshath is on the Field, you can Link summon Celestial Airknight Parshath and use its effect to add Sephylon to your hand from your Deck. This card with Hyperion allows you to pop two cards per turn by banishing Fairies from your GY, which shifts focus from the Sephylon strategy to a different one, where Fairies are being removed from the GY and thus casting aside fuel for Sephylon's summoning. Foolish Burial is just plain helpful for filling the GY with monsters more quickly. Valhalla is there to special summon Kristya or Hyperion to avoid bricking with them. Terraforming is still in the Side Deck only because I once ran a single copy of The Sanctuary in the Sky to protect against battle damage.

deck_excerpt: We're playing just x2 vanilla BEWD and x1 Alternative. This is a Blue-Eyes Trap-Control build with an extended discussion on deck-building theory and
deck_description: No audacious claims here that this is 'the best, most consistent, least bricky Blue-Eyes deck ever'. Players would do right to view any claims like that with a lot of skepticism, especially if they lack documented success in competitive play. For my part, I have not competed with this deck in a tournament yet, though I plan to take it to locals while Skill Drain is still at x3--if for no other reason than to have fun playing Blue-Eyes again. But the reason I've embraced this build at all is because of the success of other players who have taken similar builds--the Blue-Eyes Trap Control build--to locals and won. HaltessiaGaming (YouTube channel name) has won several OTS local tournaments playing this variant of Blue-Eyes, gradually over time moving towards a heavier fusion build. Credit to HaltessiaGaming, his YouTube deck profiles and combo videos go over the theory behind his deck-building strategy in great detail. Whether players take up the trap-control build or not, they're worth studying for competitive players because of how fearlessly they cast away long-held deck-building dogma around 'how you have to run Blue-Eyes'. Practice is the sole criterion of truth, and the fact that no other Blue-Eyes builds are seeing success--let alone topping--tournaments speaks for itself. Dogma is Dead I was skeptical of the Blue-Eyes control build for some time--mainly turned off by how fragile a strategy revolving around True Light seemed. But what really got my attention with HaltessiaGaming's build was that, originally, he played the vanilla Blue-Eyes White Dragon at x2 and the Blue-Eyes Alternative White Dragon, which is treated as the vanilla on-field or in-grave, at x1. That's basically heresy among Blue-Eyes players, who have feverishly insisted that the vanilla is played at x3 and the Alternative White Dragon at x2 (some die-hards insist on playing it at x3 but this is no longer widely accepted). Of course this is Blue-Eyes we're talking about so the x5-6 level-8 dragons--all of whom are considered 'Blue-Eyes White Dragon' on the field or in-grave, mind you--are joined with a host of other level-8 dragons. The high probability of opening with an unplayable hand necessitates running other cards like Trade-In at x3, which Blue-Eyes players have rationalized as a 'draw engine' (in fact, Trade-In mills the deck but only replaces itself and the level-8 monster discarded, making it a +0). "It's called Brick-Eyes for a reason," says the old saying. Of course the deck bricks. It's loaded up with unnecessary monsters that certain players feel an attachment to including but rarely go live by themselves! In my other deck profiles, I've talked in some detail about deck-building theory as it relates to Blue-Eyes and bricking. Blue-Eyes decks haven't had an issue searching their signature monsters or getting them out onto the field. The main issue is how overloaded these decks have been with extenders and boss monsters, who not only show up in opening hands in place of critical starters but, more importantly, take up valuable deck space that would normally go towards hand traps, board-breakers and other cards you would traditionally associate with 'going second'. Its consistency is problematic, sure, but even the boards it creates have tended to lack staying power into turn-2. Worse still, traditional Blue-Eyes staples like Trade-In are absolutely devastating targets for an opponent to hit with Ash Blossom, blowing out 33-40% of a player's opening hand depending on whether they went first or second. A lot of the Blue-Eyes staples have had similar vulnerabilities, notably Melody of Awakening Dragon (played below), but the generic discard-1 cost of Melody is easier to fulfill and can often mitigate the damage of disruption (for example, by discarding either of the White Stones). What did the Battle of Chaos support do for BEWD? Thanks to the new support released in Battle of Chaos, a lot of the fundamental weaknesses associated with Blue-Eyes decks can be fixed. Blue-Eyes Jet Dragon has practically replaced Alternative as the main level-8 extender to get on the board with its powerful, non-targeting bounce effect, its field protection of other cards, and its outrageously simple summoning requirements. Jet Dragon is a boss monster that can easily function as a hand trap--its one drawback being its requirement that a Blue-Eyes White Dragon be in grave. Similarly, Dictator of D. is a badly needed special summon that foolishes Blue-Eyes White Dragon from the deck for cost and can easily bring out any of the deck's big dragons from the grave. Its effect designating the target for opponent attacks comes up less frequently but can make an impact in shoring up an established board. It acts a lot like Magicians' Souls does for Dark Magician decks, albeit without the now-coveted draw power of the latter, and gave the deck another essential starter alongside Sage With Eyes of Blue, the White Stone of Ancients and--sometimes--the White Stone of Legend. I won't go into the specific combo lines here since others have outlined this and more in detail already, but Dictator + Sage practically gets the deck to full-combo. Ultimate Fusion, too, is an outstanding extender that really ties a tighter fusion build together with the trap-control variant. When using Blue-Eyes White Dragons from the field, it pops face-up cards on your opponent's field. More importantly, though, it recycles its fusion materials by shuffling them back into the deck. This singular function enables Blue-Eyes decks to play fewer level-8 bricks since it keeps replenishing search and summon targets for cards like Dictator of D., the White Stone of Ancients and Melody of Awakening Dragon to grab. It's also a quick-play, allowing it to synergize exceedingly well with traps like True Light (which can also search and set Ultimate Fusion). Blue-Eyes Abyss Dragon, a two-year old card, has finally found its moment too. It's able to search and add Jet Dragon to hand during the End Phrase when summoned off the White Stone of Ancients and serves as a level-8 body for Formula Synchron to make Baronne de Fleur off Halqifibrax's second effect. Polymerization at x1 helps potentially get a Blue-Eyes from hand to grave without recycling it back into the deck, but Abyss Dragon also searches it to net a +1 on summon--provided a BEWD is in the graveyard already. But equally significant, in-grave, players can banish Abyss Dragon to give their dragons a +1000 ATK boost, allowing two Blue-Eyes White Dragons and/or Jet Dragon to OTK an opponent. Obviously the card has skyrocketed in price, and while it's certainly optimal, it's also not necessary. Neither of HaltessiaGaming's two builds, for instance, used Abyss Dragon. Blue-Eyes Trap House & Skill Drain Konami's decision to return Skill Drain to x3 had major implications for the format. Eldlich decks saw an immediate boost from the infamous continuous trap's return to unlimited play. But as HaltessiaGaming's deck profile and theory discussions have pointed out, Blue-Eyes decks can benefit immensely from Skill Drain too. Even when it was limited to x1, most Blue-Eyes decks played Skill Drain. The reasons are clear: Most of the monster effects that summon Blue-Eyes White Dragon and its counterparts resolve off the field, allowing the deck's core beatdown strategy to play around the otherwise devastating floodgate. Most Blue-Eyes monsters are at 3000 ATK or more, effects aside, making them formidable in matchups with decks that require an elaborate choreography of monster effects to climb into big extra deck monsters. Blue-Eyes Tyrant Dragon, the new fusion monster released in Battle of Chaos, is also unaffected by trap cards, meaning that if the Tyrant Dragon is already on the field when Skill Drain resolves, its effects are not negated. But Skill Drain isn't the only advantage Blue-Eyes has in this format. With so many decks using Artifact Scythe to restrict use of the extra deck, Blue-Eyes trap-control builds can play around another devastating floodgate. With the amount of on-field protection offered by main deck cards like True Light and Blue-Eyes Jet Dragon, players can maintain and even win with a board without relying on the extra-deck. These are just features of the format. Some obnoxious Blue-Eyes dogmatists have flippantly dismissed the trap-control build for relying on Skill Drain x3 to win, arguing that without the trap, the deck couldn't win. Sure. That's true. But that's exactly the nature of any format. The restriction or un-restriction of certain cards changes the lineup of decks that can perform well or poor. What works in one format won't necessarily work in another format, owing in part to a particular deck's strengths and weaknesses. Blue-Eyes decks have a lot of weaknesses, even now, but this is a format that also showcases its potential strengths. Not only is there nothing wrong with playing to those strengths in the format; it's a necessity for competitive-minded players looking to bring out this iconic creature of destruction. Final Thoughts Blue-Eyes probably isn't a viable strategy beyond the local level, even with the new support. The deck still has consistency issues, albeit much fewer than previous eras, and there's a lower power ceiling for the deck in general. Some of this is mitigated by playing more hand traps and real traps, but other than making Baronne de Fleur via Halqifibrax, you're not able to throw many negates on-board. With that in mind, the trap-control variant plays a longer game than many Blue-Eyes players are familiar with--a long game that makes liberal use of True Light to keep pace. That brings obvious vulnerabilities too. And while I'm convinced that playing 2x BEWD, 1x Alternative White Dragon is a better ratio for consistency in general--you want to be able to play your opening hand, after all--occasionally you run into the issue of not being able to activate certain effects without a BEWD on-field or in-grave. Cards like Foolish Burial, Dragon Shrine and obviously Dictator of D. tremendously help with this. In closing though, I appreciate those players who take a look at new support and aren't afraid to roll back existing deck-building dogma. They're seeing some success--the most Blue-Eyes decks have seen in at least a year--and that's worth taking note. Let me know your thoughts in the comments. Good luck and have fun, comrades.

deck_name: Edison Format | 1 | Flamvell Synchro Assault Mode
deck_excerpt: Edison Format - Flamvell Synchro Assault Mode
deck_description: For the past six months I've slowly started getting into Edison and I'm having such a blast! The decks still have that old school yugioh feel to them. Card advantage is key and you always try to play around staples like Heavy Storm and Mirror Force, giving it that chess feel to it. Yet it feels somewhat modern in that decks are capable of being very aggressive and generating advantage on the spot. If you're not careful your opponent can easily push for game or create a game state that's hard to out with just one or two cards. While every format has its own meta, with some deck being better than others, I've tried a variety of decks and have yet to see one that feels straight up bad. And I've played Brainwash Turbo so that really says a lot! (I'll get to that one at a later date) There are a lot of decks to play and have fun with. Sadly, most people don't commit their time to writing decklists for a 12 year old format (shockers, I know). Also there's edisonformat[dot]com, a website for Edison decks, tournaments, rules and cardpool. However when it comes to creating and sharing decks no website beats ygoprodeck so I decided to start uploading my Edison decks here in hope to inspire people to create and share decklists of their own. As of now the deck's I have created are all heavily inspired (or in some cases almost completely copy and pasted. What, am I not supposed to play Mirror Force and co.?) by decks found on edisonformat[dot]com so I'll try linking the original deck/deck that served as a basis for my decks here, too. With that being said, let's get into the deck that first got me into Edison: Flamvell Synchro Assault Mode   Strategy This idea is to destroy monsters by battle using Flamvell Firedog to then summon Flamvell Magician, turning Firedog into a 1-card Synchro 8. In most cases you'll go into Stardust Dragon but this deck is on a large Synchro Toolbox, allowing for a variety of Synchro plays. Once you have your Flamvells in rotation, Rekindling allows for immediate advantage, resulting in at least a Synchro 8. The Assault Mode engine gives you access to both a 1900 ATK beater as well as consistent access to Assault Mode Activate thanks to Assault Beast. Once you've summoned Stardust Dragon you can tribute it for Stardust Dragon/Assault Mode. This card is decent by modern standard, meaning it's absolutely broken by 2010's. It's your classic negate everything kind of omni-negate. But that wouldn't be modern enough now, would it. So obviously, in good old 2022 fashion this card also floats. If your opponent manages to out it you get to summon a Stardust Dragon from your GY. The Flamvell engines is pretty good by itself but getting to Firedog is key. The Gravekeeper engine allows to keep on pressuring your opponent without committing to too many staples to even out the board state. Either wall up with two Gravekeeper's Spies or use Gravekeeper's Descendant for removal.   Cards and Engines I've already talked about the Flamvell engine, consisting of 3 of each Flamvell Firedog, Flamvell Magician and Rekindling The Assault Mode engine consists of the 3 Assault Beasts and one copy of each Assault Mode Activate and Stardust Dragon/Assault Mode. Assault Beast is still a good beater at worst. Since this deck is a Synchro Toolbox deck it runs Blackwing - Gale the Whirlwind and Plaguespreader Zombie for Synchro 6 and 7 plays. Plague can also be used to put Stardust Dragon/Assault mode on top of your deck the turn you want to summon it, since Assault Mode Activate cannot Special Summon from hand. Rekindling is an unsearchable power card so Gold Sarcophagus helps accessing it consistently. Sangan can't search your Flamvell engine nor can it search Assault Beast but it can search cards for almost every game state. I can add Spy to stall, Sniper Hunter for removal and either a level 2, 3 or 4 Tuner.   Credits to www[dot]edisonformat[dot]com/decks/rogue-decks-gravekeeper-flamvell

deck_excerpt: Yosenju's on your turn Melffy's on there's. archetypes complements each other well.
deck_description: Yosenju's on your turn Melffy's on there's. archetypes complements each other well.  Instead of using Battle fader and the like to protect life on opponents turn you use Melffys and Yosenju Oyam to keep your life safe. So, you can then do it all over again next turn.  Turns looks like this  Summon Yosenjus to do their things  End turn Yosenjus back to hand first, then Melffy’s to field.  Melffy Dog, into Cat, cat in to Oyam. Oyam to field in def walling for a turn.  Now you have Oyam to ram into a monster to search and do your Yosenjus again.  Repeat as needed    Odd deck Choices explained   Link Apple: Yosenjus needs draw power and Link apple is an upstart in the deck. And with doubles and triples in the extra deck losing one or two is not a big deal.  Draw Muscle: can be used with any melffy to stall their battle phase or just draw 1 card.
Use The Atlantean Dragon and your White Aura synchro monsters to defeat your opponent! And have fun!

deck_excerpt: Utopia Deck with Onomat Engine I Used to Reach Platinum 1 in Master Duel
deck_description:
This deck is based on the tried and true utopia deck with the onomat cards added for summoning purposes with some additional modifications as well. I will go over some of the combos that can be done with this deck. The extra deck was cut down to 13 to combat DD Dynamite bots in Master Duel but if you arent as worried about that, you can add standard staples such as zeus, bagooska, tornado dragon, etc. The main downside of this deck is its cost (in master duel) the majority of the cards are URs/SRs so there are a lot of expensive cards. The packs you'll wanna target are champions of hope and onomatopair-up (and the recontract universe structure deck for astraltopia)

Full Combo:

Starting Board: Three (unique) onomat monsters Utopic Onomat + Dodododwarf -> Utopic Sage + Ascended Sage + Utopic Onomat + Dodododwarf (returned via effects, first utopic, then dodododwarf) Utopic Onomat + Dodododwarf + Zubababancho -> Primathmech + Astraltopia (summoned via 3 card effect)   Alternate Start: Utopic Onomat + Zubababancho + both ZS monsters Utopic Onomat + Ascended/Armed Sage -> Utopic Sage + Ascended/Armed Sage + Utopic Onomat (returned via effects) Utopic Onomat + Zubababancho + Ascended Sage -> Primathmech + Astraltopia (summoned via 3 card effect)   Rest of Combo: Primath + Utopic Sage -> Utopic Future -> Utopic Draco Future Astraltopia + Discard -> Zexal Construction Astraltopia + Ascended Sage -> Utopia Double -> Utopia + Double or Nothing Zexal Construction + Double or Nothing -> Phantom Knights Rank-Up-Magic Utopia -> Utopia Prime -> 4 material Utopia Dragonar 4 material Utopia Dragonar -> 2 material Utopia Dragonar + 1 material Ultimate Leo Utopia Ray 1 material Ultimate Leo Utopia Ray -> Ultimate Leo Utopia Ray w/ Equipped Pegasus Set Phantom Knights Rank-Up-Magic and pass turn (set activity queue from auto to on if in master duel so you get earliest chance to activate dragonar) Opponent's Turn: 2 material Utopia Dragonar -> 0 material Utopia Dragonar + 0 material (important for rank-up-magic) Diablosis Diablosis + Rank-Up-Magic -> Kali Yuga w/ Full Board Negation for turn (persists through removal, and negates your board too)   Final Board: Utopic Drago Future w/ monster negate and steal (if on board), Ultimate Leo Utopia Ray w/ two monster negates (on board), Dragonar w/attack negation quick effect, and Kali Yuga with (both sides) spell & trap removal   Potential Modifications: If you draw the phantom knights rank-up magic/zexal construction, or astraltopia, you can skip primath and instead use two material to summon gagaga magician (which can be used to summon utopia->C39 Utopia Ray->Utopia Lightning if you choose to add them to your deck) as the second material for utopic future If you draw double or nothing, skip utopia double If you draw pegasus, use zexal construction to replace it in the deck instead of double or nothing  

Partial Combos:

PC1: If the best you can start with is something like Utopic Onomat, Zubaba, and one ZS monster (or any other setup where cant get 4 material on the board after utopic sage), you can skip the utopic draco future summon and just go for dragonar alone. In this case, you will summon hope harbinger instead of diablosis on your opponent's turn for a single spell negation. PC2: Worst Case senario that you can still get a combo off is when you can only summon two monsters to the board. This usually happens when youre going second and need to use most of your hand to negate the opponent's monsters through effects such as droplet. In this case, just go utopia double->utopia + double or nothing. Certainly not as powerful as the previous combos, but if your opponent has an attack position monster with 2k or less attack (or 4k if one of the two monsters you got out was armed sage, allowing you to get asura strike) you can still end the game in that turn if you negate your own attack and then activate double or nothing There are likely other partial combos i missed but most of them are likely just going to be bits of the full combo, so go out there and experiment and find the combos you prefer.

deck_name: Phantom Knights But its a Synchro Deck Now
deck_excerpt: PKs are cool, you know what else is cool? Synchros. Let's combine the two!
deck_description:
If you know me, you know i love the Phantom Knights archetype. But what most people don't know about me is that i love synchro spam decks. So I got to thinking, how can i mash these two concepts together into one deck? well here it is, the fruits of my tomfoolery have led me into a slippery slope of jank madness. If you want a quick description of the deck I have presented to you here, it would be that this deck is literally just Infernoble Knight, but without the Infernoble Knights Unlike the "PK but it's a Fusion Deck" counterpart to this list (which you can find here https://ygoprodeck.com/phantom-knights-but-its-a-fusion-deck-now/), this deck is leagues more complicated when it comes to combos. So let me show you what this deck is supposed to do. The key cards for most of your combos are as follows: Isolde, Halqifibrax, Auroradon. (kinda like Infernobles)   Most combos go as follows:
  1. get 2 warriors on board to get Isolde, anything will do
  2. use Isolde's second effect to get your tuner of choice (I chose Comrade Swordsman of Landstar cuz it's funny)
  3. use Isolde and tuner of choice to make Halqifibrax and use the effect to get Deskbot 001
  4. use Halq and 001 to make Mecha Phantom Beast Auroradon and use his effect to get 3 tokens, triggering 001 to special from grave.
  5. use 001 and 1 token to make Herald of the Arc Light
  6. use Auroradon's effect to special Mecha Phantom Beast Coltwing from deck by removing the other 2 tokens
  7. use Coltwing's effect to get 2 tokens, triggering 001 again
  8. use Coltwing, 001, and 1 token to make Baronne De Fleur (coltwing is level 6 because of his effect)
End Board Results: Auroradon, Herald (omni negate), Baronne (2nd omni negate) and a spare token. It's also important to know that the combo listed above is entirely possible after making Bardiche, which means you can stack a fog blade or two if you want to make the combo longer

deck_excerpt: Just your average troll deck. Enjoy!
deck_description: I don't have a true strategy.... It's a TROLL deck! You Troll people with it.

If you go back and check out the decks that were played at SJC Edison in April 2010 you'll find some discrepancies. The two "best" decks of the Edison format are arguably Diva HERO and Vayu Turbo, yet neither of them was played back in April 2010. The decks played back then weren't bad. Many of them, like Jeff Jones' 1st place Dandywarrior Quickdraw, are still viable today. However, after spending so much time with a specific format people found new decks and strategies. One of them is Diva HERO.   Strategy Diva HERO decks constantly try to put pressure on your opponent, thanks to almost every card generating advantage. You have Elemental HERO Stratos that can search you another monster to keep the card advantage going. Destiny HERO - Malicious not only provides a body for free but makes summoning Stardust Dragon laughably easy. Pressuring your opponent with Synchros and impactful main deck monsters like Caius the Shadow Monarch or Dark Armed Dragon is pretty good on its own but what makes this deck shine is it's capability to completely abuse one of the only few generic HERO Fusion monsters that were released back in 2010: Elemental HERO Absolute Zero. This card is very difficult to out and you can potentially summon more than one a turn. With every card generating you advantage and keeping on the pressure you'll often find yourself in an advantageous game state during which you can then push for lethal with Absolute Zero, Stardust Dragon, DAD, etc.   Cards and Engines For the HERO half of the deck you're obviously on the aforementioned Stratos and two Malicious. Destiny HERO - Diamond Dude, who despite its low ATK stat and inconsistent effect still proves to be quite threatening since its effect can be very strong if it resolves and worst case he'll get you closer and closer even to your powerful spells even if its effect misses. If you have Caius or a Malicious in hand and don't mind commiting your normal summon to him you can also search Evil HERO Infernal Prodigy. It's a free Special Summon which makes for great tribute fodder. If you tribute it for Malicious you'll even get a draw during the End Phase. Miracle Fusion, although technically part of the HERO package, deserves it's seperate mention. It summons Absolute Zero by banishing materials in the GY. Nothing's easier than putting a few monsters in the GY in a format in which games take longer than a single turn. You play a large amount of WATER and HERO monsters and will barely ever find yourself out of luck. Thanks to cards like Malicious and Miracle Fusion it's very easy to control the number of DARKs in your GY. That means that you can easily set up a Dark Armed Dragon even if you draw into him late into the game. Now onto the Diva engine. The engine consists of a playset of Deep Sea Diva and a Spined Gillman as the target. Don't forget that Diva can summon itself to link climb into a Synchro 8 with just another level 4 monster. I'll include Treeborn Frog and two Snowman Eater here since they are still WATER monsters that provide advantage and are used as material for Absolute Zero afterwards, even though they're not searchable by Diva. Last but not least I quickly want to mention Future Fusion. Pre-errata this card sends the materials to the GY when it resolves. This allows to mill both Treeborn Frog and Malicious and sets up your GY for Miracle Fusion, too. Fantastic.   General credits to www[dot]edisonformat[dot]com/decks/category/diva-heroes

deck_excerpt: Marincess NR deck profile. NR is a Master Duel Festival format with only N and R rarity cards. I've been testing this list for two weeks, and I think
deck_description:
Welcome to this Marincess NR deck profile. NR is a Master Duel Festival format with only N and R rarity cards. I've been testing this list for two weeks, and I think I've came up with a solid and fun to play list. Marincess Sea Horse is the most important card in this deck, as it allows us to combo easily. Tin Goldfish is very useful in this recipe because it allows us to summon from hand any of the other LV4 we carry. Mermail Abysspike is an awesome card, as it allows us to search for Marincess Sea Horse when needed. Silent Angler is a good extender, but can be difficult to use in the first games due to the restriction it sets after being special summoned. Tenyi Spirit - Shthana should always be special summoned first if it is in hand on our first turn. Marincess Basilalima isn't as good as I'd like, but we run it because we can Link 1 summon with it and it is a LV4 that can be summoned from hand by Tin Goldfish. Silent Sea Nettle is a very good water extender that allows us to recycle cards from both Main Deck and Extra Deck. Both Magical Mallet and Moray of Greed give us a lot of draw power, allowing us to risk sometimes unimportant cards to get the extender we need. Forbidden Chalice is a staple in this format. We also use Paleozoic Dinomischus and Marincess Wave to disrupt. When it's not possible to summon both Marincess Blue Slug and Marincess Sea Angel in the same turn, opt for Marincess Sea Angel and prioritise getting Marincess Battle Ocean. One of the basic non-standard combos in other Marincess variants that you're going to see a lot here is as follows:
  • Normal summon Mermail Abysspike, discard 1 water monster, search for Marincess Sea Horse.
You need an extender here, Tin Goldfish before Mermail Abysspike, Tenyi Spirit - Shthana before anything else, or an extender like Silent Sea Nettle now.
  • Special summon Silent Sea Nettle.
  • Link 2 with Mermail Abysspike and Silent Sea Nettle. Link summon Marincess Crystal Heart.
  • Special summon Marincess Sea Horse to a zone Marincess Crystal Heart points to.
  • Link 1 with Marincess Sea Horse. Link summon Marincess Sea Angel and use Marincess Sea Angel's effect to search for Marincess Battle Ocean.
  • Activate Marincess Battle Ocean.
  • Link 3 with Marincess Crystal Heart and Marincess Sea Angel. Link summon Marincess Marbled Rock and use Marincess Battle Ocean's effect.
Now we have Marincess Battle Rock in the Extra Monster Zone with protection, with two different Marincess Links equipped and an attack above 3000. That's a basic combo without the best cards, you can do it from many starters and sometimes get Marincess Blue Slug and equip it as well, Marincess Battle Rock achieving an attack of 4500. Put Forbidden Chalice, Paleozoic Dinomischus and Marincess Wave to good use, don't be too greedy and use them when they would do the most damage to your opponent. Don't worry too much if they only destroy Marincess Battle Ocean, you can recover it with Marincess Marbled Rock's effect and activate it again. Your Marincess Marbled Rock will gain its corresponding attack bonus and regain its protection against opponent's card effects. Feel free to customize this list to your liking.

deck_name: Pandemonium Archfiends (Master Duel, N/R rarity only)
deck_excerpt: A deck centered around Pandemonium and the Chess Archfiends, for the N/R rarity only event.
deck_description:
Hi, Grayewick the Fusionist here, back with a deck that could've easily been a Fusion deck if only either Archfiend Heiress or Archfiend's Manifestation was at least a R rarity, also a deck that would've been really good if we had access to a Skill Drain like card in N/R rarity event, Pandemonium Archfiends. Why play this deck? Archfiends aren't really a meta deck, but it's actually a pretty fun one to pilot in slower formats. It's one of those old archetypes that does not really receive much direct support over time, until lately that the Labrynth cards got announced in which they actually did get some. The main deck: Monsters • The Chess Archfiends (x3 Shadowknight, x2 Terrorking & Desrook, & x1 Infernalqueen, Darkbishop, Vilepawn, & Imprisoned Queen) - These are your main beaters, and also your main defenders. They all have a mandatory stipulation that requires its controller to pay a certain amount of LP during the Standby Phase in order for them to stay on the field. These are their respective effects:
  1. Shadowknight - A WIND Fiend monster with 2000 ATK, but all battle damage it inflicts to your opponent is halved. Its targeting protection requires a roll of 3 to negate it.
  2. Desrook - A LIGHT Fiend monster with 1800 DEF, that has an effect that can be used to send it to the GY when a "Terrorking Archfiend" you control is destroyed, and Special Summon the said monster. Its targeting protection requires a roll of 3 to negate it.
  3. Vilepawn - An EARTH Fiend monster that prevents your opponent from attacking other monsters, except "Vilepawn Archfiend", which can be used to dupe lock your opponent. Its targeting protection requires a roll of 3 to negate it.
  4. Terrorking - A DARK Fiend monster with 2000 ATK that negates the effects of monsters it destroys by battle. Its targeting protection requires a roll of either 2 or 5 to negate it.
  5. Infernalqueen - A FIRE Fiend monster that has an effect that boosts an "Archfiend"'s monster's ATK by 1000 during the Standby Phase, until the End Phase. Its targeting protection requires a roll of either 2 or 5 to negate it.
  6. Darkbishop - A WATER Fiend monster that does not have a unique effect, but its targeting protection requires a roll of either 1, 3, or 6 to negate it.
  7. Imprisoned Queen - A Level 8 DARK Fiend monster that has an effect that boosts an "Archfiend"'s monster's ATK during only your Standby Phase, until the End Phase, although it requires you to both have a face-up "Pandemonium" and it to be in the GY.
There is also Skull Archfiend of Lightning, a Summoned Skull retrain that is also an honorary Chess Archfiend, since it also has a targeting protection that requires a roll of either 1, 3, or 6 to negate an opponent's card effect that specifically targets itself, and destroy that card. • Archfiend General, Archfiend Commander, & Archfiend Cavalry - Your classic combo usually involves pitching General to search for Pandemonium and activate it, Normal Summon Cavalry, Special Summon Commander, then mandatory destroy Cavalry. This will trigger two things, both your Pandemonium to search and your Cavalry to Special Summon itself. Do keep in mind that for Cavalry to trigger its Special Summon effect, you'd need to have at least 1 more "Archfiend" monster in the GY. Playing more copies of either of the three is fine. • Archfiend Emperor, the First Lord of Horror - Your boss monster. A Level 8 DARK Fiend monster that has an effect that enables it to be Normal Summoned without Tributing at a cost of halving its ATK and DEF, and if it was summoned this way, it is destroyed during the End Phase. It also has a targeting removal effect that banishes an "Archfiend" card from your hand or GY to destroy a card on the field. • Trance Archfiend - The one of, in which you'd usually play more copies of in a regular build since it allows you to recover your banished "Archfiend" cards for the purposes of Archfiend Emperor's effect. Spells • Brain Control - Semi-limited in the N/R rarity only format. Adds more pressure and helps you get rid of problematic monsters, provided they can be targeted. • Mystical Space Typhoon - Back row removal. This could also be Nobleman of Extermination. • Book of Moon - Also another way of dealing with high ATK monsters, so long as they can be targeted. Could literally be any card of your choice. • Archfiend Staff of Despair - Another way of you dealing with high ATK monsters as well, and can recur itself back to the hand at a cost of 1000 LP. You could choose whether to play this card or not, usually the latter in favor of another copy of the next card. • Falling Down - A Snatch Steal, but costs you LP instead of healing your opponent, and also destroys itself if you do not control another "Archfiend" card but hey, a nerfed Snatch Steal is still a Snatch Steal. • Pandemonium - The reason why you're still not dead despite all that maintenance cost, because it makes it so that neither player has to pay LP during the Standby Phase for the effect of "Archfiend" monsters. It also allows you to search an "Archfiend" monster with a different Level upon the destruction of one. Traps • Archfiend's Roar - It's Call of the Haunted, but it requires you to pay LP and it destroys that monster during the End Phase. Your best target for this usually is Archfiend Cavalry, at least in this list. Some people only play 2 of these, which is understandable and completely fine. • Call of the Archfiend - It's also Call of the Haunted, but only for Level 5 or higher Fiend monsters and requires you to discard a Fiend monster specifically as a cost. Some people only play 1 of this since it requires set up, but I like the added security in case my opponent outs the first one. Extra Deck None, you absolutely could play this deck by itself and it'll probably work itself out just fine, but in a full power build, you'll usually either run Archfiend's Manifestation, Archfiend's Call, and Archfiend's Ascent and sometimes Archfiend's Awakening too, and a copy or two of Masterking Archfiend, with either Pot of Prosperity, Pot of Extravagance, or Celestial Observatory since you run a plenty of Level 6 monsters, for consistency. You could splash in some Dogmatika Punishments and high ATK targets as well, that'd be acceptable too. Final thoughts This deck performed better than the 2 other decks that I'm still currently testing lately for the N/R rarity only event, I'll give it that, but not having access to both Archfiend Heiress and Archfiend Empress really hurts, since it could've definitely been faster with the addition of the said cards and Fiendish Rhino Warrior as well. Not having access to high impact staples and floodgate really hurts too, since the main deck monsters usually aren't enough by just themselves. Overall, It's fine, but is being carried by the staples even more due to the lack of access to the high rarity support. If you have any questions or thoughts, feel free to express them down in the comments and I'll respond to them as soon as I possibly can.

deck_excerpt: Summon Infinity, control the game and finish with Rampage or something like that.
deck_description: Decklist that I used in Master Duel, Tech options can be tweaked according to prefference, in my case I only have one impermanence and one dropplet, and that's why I run the deck like this.  Main strategy is the good ol' Rank 5 into Nova and Infinity, for the omni negate and monster absorbtion, by either luckily drawing Core, Nashe or Hertz + Duplication, or Galaxy Soldier Shenanigans, using Nashe to revive a regular Cyber Dragons...  Having a Cyber Dragon on the field (or ready to be summoned) + Kaiju = Remove anything from the board by summoning Fortress Dragon.  Megafleet does the same but without the Kaiju, you need the opponent's monster to be on the extra zone tho.  Zeus is there a bit just because I have him, never really used it, but could be useful I guess.  Almiraj sends Hertz to the graveyard if you have nothing else.  If you manage to summon Rampage and Sieger you can potentially OTK very easily, Rampage can even win you the game by himself if there's no monsters on the opponent's field and he's at 6300LP or less.  To link climb from Hiita to Accesscode, you'd need to have summoned almiraj at some point and have him on the graveyard, then summon Hiita, so normal summon an Ash Blossom or, link her away with something and then you want your opponent to have another Ash on the GY, (or another fire monster) to revive it when you summon Hiita, then link them away to summon Transcode Talker, and use Transcode's effect to revive Almiraj, and then finally Accesscode, made from a link 3, so 5300ATK.  I haven't really used Eternity, but it is really hard to remove, as long as you have some other fusion machine monster on the GY, and that's easy to do with megafleet and fortress dragons, Eternity will be untargetable and inmune to all effects, so it can only be killed by battle or by dropping a Kaiju on it.

The only thing better than kaiju'ing your opponent is kaiju'ing your opponent and getting to keep the monster. Imma be real with you, this is a weird one. I present you: Brainwash   Strategy Essentially, this is an OTK deck. You're trying to give your opponent multiple strong monsters, return their control to you - the owner - and OTK on an empty board. Although this isn't always possible. Sometimes you have to settle for trading a Lava Golem for a potentially bigger threat or just to wall up. You'll be trying to stall your opponent with cards like Cyber Valley or Battle Fader (who's great tribute fodder for Nightmare Archfiends), Compulsory Evacuation Device and Fiendish Chain. Do keep in mind your opponent's life total. Your trying to maximize on consistency with a 38 card deck + 2 Upstart Goblin (which simply trade for the next card in your deck) so your opponent might have 10000 LP when you're trying to push for lethal only for you to realize that you can only deal 9000 damage.   Cards and Engines Remove Brainwashing and Owner's Seal are your win conditions. All your beatsticks are summoned to your opponent's side of the field and with these two cards you can return them to your control. While Remove Brainwashing seems better than Owner's Seal since it doesn't apply it's effect at a singular moment like the latter, it is easier for your opponent to remove it than it is to negate the activation of Owner's Seal so keep that in mind when searching either with Gold Sarcophagus. I've already talked about Lava Golem, the card you're probably the most familiar with anyways. Besides it there's our honorary Knightmare and nightmare for many who've been around when he was still legal: Grinder Golem. He summons himself while giving you two token, which can be used as tribute fodder for Nightmare Archfiends or Reptilianne Vaskii. Volcanic Queen has less attack than Lava Golem but you can't always tribute 2 monsters and you can send another monster after missing lethal to deal another 1000 damage with her effect.  Nightmare Archfiends is like Ojama Trio on steroids. Requires a monster/token on your side of the field but has a huge payoff if you manage to take back control. That's a total of 6000 ATK points. While Cyber Valley helps drawing into your combo pieces while stalling the game Battle Fader has surprising synergy with the deck as some cards require you to have a monster/0 ATK monster on the field. 2 of each Magic Planter, Upstart Gobling and Gold Sarcophagus help getting to your win con. Backrow is omni-present in older formats so this deck is on a lot of backrow removal to ensure you are OTK'ing whenever you're ready. Heavy Storm, Cold Wave, Giant Trunade and Mystical Space Typhoon should get the job done.   Necessary Rulings Volcanic Queen doesn't say it on her card text as she is lacking any reprints but her effect that burns a monster by sending a monster you control to the GY sends for cost. That means you cannot send Tokens for the effect. Cyber Valley's effect to banish and draw 2 does not banish for cost. You can banish it and a token and still draw 2. You are legally allowed to activate Remove Brainwashing and Owner's Seal even if you don't have enough free monster zones available. In that case you return as many monsters as you can and the rest are sent to the GY and considered to be destroyed by game mechanic. That means that if you cannot take control of all Nightmare Archfiends-Tokens they are destroyed while in they are in your opponent's posession and your opponent therefore takes the 800 effect damage per destroyed Token. Once a monster's control has been given to its owner the control will not change back when Remove Brainwashing is removed from the field. The monster is yours for the keeping. Cold Wave does not negate already applying continuous-like effects. If you already control a face-up Remove Brainwashing you can use Cold Wave and still apply its effect.   Credits to www[dot]edisonformat[dot]com/decks/rogue-brainwashing-beatdown

Hello there,  this is my take on the yet to be released Albaz Structure Deck.  My attempt is semi budget since it doesn't include the expensive Despia cards ,but utilizes a small Thunder Dragon engine.  With this deck, you can end on a board of Mirrorjade + Dragostapelia + Titan + Mercourier in hand, but you can also brick horroibly and just set 1 pass.  The card Fusion Gate is a very cool budget option in this deck. With two Dark monsters with different Types in hand (optimal TDroar + Mercourier) you can go into Dragostapelia while also searching for Kitt, which will get you to Branded Fusion.  The side deck presents some accountable options, but can be customized at will.  Suggestions to improve the deck are welcome. :)  Have a nice day, everyone!  <<Edit:  I upgradet the decklist.  Reduced TD's since the only real starter for that line is Dragonroar. Added the Gizmek and Albion instead. Albion dump Branded Blade to draw one and recycle is really nice. Some other minor changes to  enhance gameplay. Endboard stays fundamentally the same. >>

deck_excerpt: Adventurer Enforcer Salamangreat / Colombia WCQ Regional 1st Place
deck_description: Category: Tournament Meta Deck  Tournament Meta Decks are current-level Meta Decks that are capable of going up against the best of the best. These are curated lists that cannot be uploaded by regular users.  Creator: Joset Rojas Tournament: Colombia WCQ Regional - March 19th 2022 Placement: 1st Place https://youtu.be/995bTB8mYD0

I think it will be interesting to share my changes to the deck. Update: 2022/03/23: Removed foolish burial, added two Mathematician as a better replacement. Added deck strategy. A flexible deck, every other duel you could draw the cards needed for invoked summoning, or shaddoll summoning. Either work very well, or if you're lucky both. Invoked strategy: You draw an aleister the invoker? Normal summon, and add invocation to your hand, you link summon Artemis the magistus moon maiden, and then fusion summon Invoked Mechaba using Invocation. Dogmatika/Albaz strategy: I use dogmatika and albaz for a monster negate and monster removal, useful for monsters that cant be destroyed by battle or card effects. I use albaz to tribute opponents troublesome monsters. Dogmatika monsters have OTK potential, and could be used as fusion material for El Shaddoll Construct and Invoked Mechaba. Shaddoll strategy: You want to efficiently use your flip monster effects here, Reeshaddoll Wendi is a great card and the most aggressive. Ideally you would want to get Winda out there as a special summon limiter. Shaddoll Schism is your ace in the hole, you will want it in a long game. My thoughts: I like to run 3 Cosmic Cyclone here because Skill drain is such a terrible card to encounter. And 3 Crossout Designator because I was sick of my opponents always playing handtraps, both have been good additions. I am missing one more "Dark Ruler No More" it has been an excellent card and I like it a lot more than Effect veiler, Forbidden droplet, and Infinite impermanence.

deck_excerpt: Fun XYZ beatdown deck for the event
deck_description:
This is far from a top contender in this format because a lot of the important cards are SR or UR (I wish we at least had Gladiator Beast Equeste), but it can still do some interesting things. You want to go second because you can't really do anything going first if you don't open exactly Test Tiger, a level 4 or lower Gladiator Beast and either Gladiator Beast Attorix or Gladiator Beast Augustus in hand (you can go into Draglubion with those 3 cards). Going second gives you an extra card, allows you to attack to  start combos and makes Ancient Warriors - Loyal Guan Yun a lot better, who is especially good in this deck because he opens up attack possibilities for your Gladiator Beasts. The deck is mostly build to make XYZ of different levels consistently. The huge downside is that you either have to attack (especially difficult after your first turn because you opponent can make it harder by only having monsters with high ATK and nothing in defense) or use multiple cards for that. My body as a Shield is pretty bad, but this deck loses hard to Torrential Tribute, so I have it in for now (you can try Nobleman of Extermination instead, but that isn't perfect either). Standard plays:
  • Attack with a Gladiator/Use Tiger on it to summon Augustus from deck, which then summons another Augustus or Attoric from hand to go into Draglubion for Heart-Earth (Attoric sends Augustus from deck)
  • If you have either Comeback or Rejection you can attack/Tiger into Attoric, which either sends Octavarius from deck (to revive it with Combeack) or Gaiodiaz from extra deck (and then you summon Octavarius from deck with Rejection) to go into a level 7 XYZ
  • Darius opens up level 4's and Tiger and Rejection open up the level 3's, Monk of the Tenyi is only there for Vishuda lines (I would definitely play 3 Vishuda if it was possible) and Geonator into Berserker are really strong if your opponent doesn't play around it or overextends too much

deck_description: Write your deck strategy here...     Mostly a draw turbo and deck thinning list to get to a copy of Leeching the Light. You'll almost always have enough monsters on the field to OTK with it. Thunder King's effect is amazing for the OTK because it can negate card activations before you go for the Leeching the Light combo, so you don't get surprised by a battle phase hand trap or book of moon or something like that. Make sure you don't give your opponent Jizukuru before your combo with Kyoutou up because they can use its effect to negate Leeching the Light.  Kuraz can pop your own marshmacaron, baobaboon, tokens or chainable backrow for draw or clear some of the opponent's field before OTK. Refer to my other list for combos and tech choices. It's an easy deck to pilot  with a simple game plan :)  https://ygoprodeck.com/hippo-carnival-n-r-event/

deck_name: Yosenju - Kaiju N/R event- MASTER DUEL
deck_excerpt: Control Banish  Return monsters to hand
deck_description:
COMBOS Kaiju return loop Cards you need : Yosenju kama 1 / Compulsory Evacuation Device / Yosenjus' Sword Sting / Neo-Spacian Grand Mole+ Gadarla, the Mystery Dust Kaiju / Jizukiru, the Star Destroying Kaiju
  1. Special summon one kaiju to the opponents field
  2. You can return kaiju to hand:
    • Use Yosenju Kama 1 effect and target a Kaiju (Just works if you have another Yosenju monster with different name)
    • Set Compulsory Evacuation Device and use it in Kaiju
    • If you have 2 Yosenju monsters in hand return Kaiju and other face up card from the opponent field (This effect works with one yosenju in hand but you can return just one card)
    • If you have  Neo-Spacian Grand Mole attack the kaiju and chain Neo effect to return kaiju
You can combine a lot of those steps, for example:
  • Opponente have 2 monsters in field, Gadarla, the Mystery Dust Kaiju is special summon by an opponent monster tribute
  • You Summon Yosenju Kama 1 + another Yosenju and then you use Kama 1 effect, the kaiju is in your hand again
  • You special summon kaiju again and set one Compulsory Evacuation Device / Yosenjus' Sword Sting
  • On the next turn you will can return the kaiju again with one of those set cards
  Yosenju defense wall Cards you need : Yosenju Ojam + Any other Yosenju monster IMPORTANT: This combo doesn't works if Dimensional Fissure its on the field  Very simple combo that protects from direct attack
  1. If the opponent declare an direct attack just use Yosenju Oyam effect and send one Yosenju monster in hand to the graveyard (If you have Yosenju Kodam better send him)
  2. Special summon Oyam in defense position when the opponent have more than 1 monster in his field (In defense position will resist every attack except when the attacking monster has a different attack than the original), special summon Oyam in attack position when you dont have more monsters in hand and the opponent just have one monster in field (When both monsters are destroyed you can add one Yosenju card)
  Yosenju basic search Cards you need : Yosenju Kama 2 + Yosenju Kama 3 Summon both monsters, when you declare an atatck with Kama 2 and the damage is calculated use Yosenju Kama 3 to add a Yosenju card, depend on the situation search a monster or Yosenjus's Sword Sting   Finally, look at the cards in the side deck they can be a good option too !

Can I just say that Yu-Gi-Oh GX will always have a place in my heart as one of the best comedy shows out there. It gave us some really cool monsters that are still fan favorites to this day like Yubel, Elemental HERO Neos, Cyber Dragon. People tend to be really fond of Hydrogeddon and Crystal Beasts and Volcanics have dedicated fanbases, yearning and screeching until the day they receive playable support. Although HEROs are Jaden's signature monsters I always found the Neo-Spacians and Neos monster pretty cool. Sadly, there were anything but playable if we don't count Grand Mole as a removal tool. So you can imagine that I was incredibly stoked to see that someone created a deck in Edison that actually made use of the Neo-Spacians! And I gotta say, this deck is the reason I started writing these Edison decks in the first place. Now here's a quick disclaimer: I've only recently build this deck and played it much less than the others (as in test hands and nothing else as I've been really busy ever since I got this deck). But I gotta say this deck is incredibly fun on paper, the 50-ish test hands I had were so cool and the idea behind the deck is awesome. Here's to probably one of my favorite Edison decks: Neo-Spacian.   Strategy In short, this deck revolves around card advantage. Almost every card in your deck interacts with Cross Porter, who will then add you a Neo-Spacian to hand. All you need is a Cross Porter in the GY and you can summon Synchro monsters almost every turn while gaining Neo-Spacians in the process. The Neo-Spacians themselves are somewhat of a toolbox. While the monsters are pretty weak by themselves their effects can be pretty good in niche situations, some more niche than others. You could consider this deck baby Diva HERO. It's a little less explosive and summons Iron Chain Dragon more often than it does Stardust Dragon but what it lacks in explosiveness and pressure it makes up for with the Neo-Spacian toolbox and the crazy amount of draws and adds at your disposal. Snipe Hunter will almost always have plenty of discards available and Tragoedia will pretty much sit at 3000 ATK constantly. You can manipulate the GY to incredible detail ensuring Dark Armed Dragon is live the second you want it to.   Cards and Engines The heart and soul of the deck is Cross Porter. When it is sent to the GY you can add a Neo-Spacian from deck to hand. Note, that it's an optional when effect, meaning it being sent has to be the very last thing to have happened in the previous chain/action before the trigger is met. If you discard it for cost, say for Snipe Hunter, it will not trigger as the last thing was the resolution of Sniper Hunter's effect. You can trigger it with Armageddon Knight and it meets the criteria for both Debris Dragon and Junk Synchron, who'll both negate Porters effect on the field but you only care about the effect in the GY anyways. Once you perform a Synchro summon the trigger will be met and you can add a Neo-Spacian to hand, while putting up pressure on board. Since you'll be adding a Neo-Spacian to hand almost every turn Convert Contact is not only a draw 2 with little to no setup required but also sets up your GY for Pot of Avarice. This means that Neo-Spacian Grand Mole, who's limited for a reason, can be recycled multiple times. Almost all your monsters are DARK so you'll always have a card to banish with Allure of Darkness. If you don't know what to banish you can just add Neo-Spacian Dark Panther and banish a copy of that one. Let's talk about the Neo-Spacians. The previously mentioned Neo-Spacian Dark Panther can copy the effect of an opponent's monster. That means you can steal the pwerful effects of Dark Armed Dragon, Brionac, Dragon of the Ice Barrier or Ally of Justice Catastor to name a few. Besides Dark Panther this deck is on a copy of Neo-Spacian Aqua Dolphin and Neo-Spacian Grand Mole. The former is most commonly knows by Isolde handloops, back when Linkross was still around. You can still handloop when you have a Synchro on board but most importantly you gain knowledge into your opponent's hand. Knowing your opponent has for example Heavy Storm or Mirror Force in hand can be game changing. Grand Mole bounces itself and the monster it is battling back to hand, which is a great out to many strong monsters without having to commit much. You'll be giving up your board presence but that's well worth being able to summon Grand Mole again on a later turn.   Credits go to www[dot]edisonformat[dot]com/decks/rogue-neo-spacian-toolbox

deck_excerpt: I build this because I was curious about how this deck would work.
deck_description: The deck targets its monster/spell/trap to special summon their monsters and send a card of a different type to the grave and get some additional effects off as well and use those monsters to go into level/rank 3 or higher synchro or Xyz monsters and use their spell/trap cards to special, negate, destroy, or change levels.  The adventure engine uses the brave token to allow the effects of the ridable dragon, and wandering gryphon rider to go off, and uses the effect of water enchantress to add rite of aramesir that special summon the token and activates fateful adventure from the deck (which allows you to add gryphon rider from deck to hand and equip rideable dragon to the token).  The DPE engine allows you to summon Destiny Hero - Destroy Pheonix Enforcer and use his effect to destroy your opponent's cards ( at a cost of destroying one of yours) and weaken your opponent monsters for every hero in the grave and if he were to be destroyed special summons a destiny hero from the grave including himself. As a bonus Destiny hero - Dasher during the draw phase if you draw a monster you can special summon that drawn monster without cost (but you can only do this once) and if you have no cards in your hand you can banish Destiny Hero - Celestial and one other Destiny hero to draw 2 cards.

deck_excerpt: New Gladiator Beast Tri-Brigade blend, with improved ratios and synergy between the two archetypes.
deck_description: This deck can be easily hurt by Ash Blossom, so prioritize searchers based on what you can afford to lose to bait out Ash Blossom if you do not have Called by the Grave available. Being able to send Fraktall, Kitt, and Nervall to the GY, but not add Kerass can still be useful since you are adding materials for Tri-Brigade Link Summons. Tri-Brigade monsters can also summon Gladiator Beast Dragases, allowing you to summon additional Gladiator Beasts, either through Dragases's own effect or by using Test Tiger.  You can use your first Augustus to summon a second Augustus, who can then summon a third Gladiator Beast. Tamer Editor's effect to summon Fusion Monsters is only once per turn per copy, so you can summon a second Tamer Editor and summon a new Fusion Monster. If you cannot summon both Heraklinos and Domitianus, the early turns of the duel will likely depend on which one you choose, depending on whether you are more concerned with monster effects or Spells and Traps. Discard costs for Heraklinos and Twin Twisters will trigger Nervall and Kitt's effects, making them viable to keep in hand for the next turn.
