deck_excerpt: Deck is focused around Megaliths to disrupt or beat over your opponent's monster using the Drytron Engine but loaded with staples so you have other op
deck_description: It's obvious that with the Adventure Package that released in Grand Creators that you can literally splash it in most decks along with the DPE package to create a scythe lock combo which is pretty easy to do so long as you have enough mats to nail at least 3 monsters on the board. Sycthe Lock(For Those Who don't know): Only do this if you brick and are going first TBH, it's a very breakable board but just start by getting at least 2 monsters out to make Dagda and then start a chain with another card in your hand to trigger and set Artifact Sycthe then get a third monster out and go into verte so you can copy Fusion Destiny to Summon Destiny HERO - Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer. On Standby of your oppnent's next turn trigger Phoenix Enforcer's effect and pop your own sycthe and one other card on your field(or itself if you must) to trigger Sycthe and lock your oppnent's plays from extra deck that turn. Very effective against decks like D/D/D or Dragon Links but not very effective against Flowandereeze. If you're unsure then you can wait till Mainphase 1 do this simple chain if it wasn't Flowandereeze or use enforcer to disrupt w/e deck it is that doesn't use extra deck like popping their key cards.. Let's say you start on a good hand, it doesn't matter which drytron you start with as they can eventually extend to each other but ideally you want to end with Beta fafnir and send Metonis if it's not in your hand to the grave and then add it back with it's effect. If you don't have Benten try to get to it as this deck thrives on more rituals being in the grave for Megalith's Bethor's disruptive destruction effect or Aratron's negates. If you go for the megalith plays you go from Megalith Ophiel (To get Hagith)->Megalith Hagith to add Megalith Portal in your hand from Hagith's effect or if you already have it get Megalith Emergence -> Then with Meteonis Drytron summon back Ophiel field to add Megalith Phul -> Use Hagith's effect to ritual into Phul and end your turn there-ish. These are just the barebones combo's but your Keycards are Hagith, Ophiel, and Phul. Och is in the deck in case you have a somewhat deadhand and want to use it's Dark World Dealings effect, it also has the benefit of being use as a medium to ritual summon like the other megalith's but like Phul it can do it on the oppnent's turn.  After that you just  go for what you need using Phul's effect, if your oppnent is combo-ing wait till they have 2-3 cards on board to triggle Megalith Phuland pull Megalith Bethor from your deck using the ritual monsters on field and hand to summon it as it gets to pop one card you oppnent controls for each ritual based monster in your grave. If you're finnishing off your oppnent then use Phul's effect to get Phaleg whic boost your atk/def stats by 500 for all monsters on your field for every ritual monster in your grave. Aratron is just in here in case your board is strong but lacks protection and you don't need Bethor's effect to popping and just want extra protection. Like for instance you end on Masq +Utopic Draco Future/Divine Arsenal Zeus. Yes if you get desperate you can summon the handtraps as materials for your combos, they're not just for tech options. Crossout is there at three bc oh boi you're like the beta dragon links where you're Special summoning for days to get to your key cards so nibiru is your biggest threat, Ash blossom is kinda of a hit if you open with dupe Drytrons but this deck can live through at least most hand traps. Droll and Lockbird will slow you down the most so if you get hit with that but no cross-out to respond then just do the weak ass Sycthe lock and pray your oppnent has no out to it next turn. Dark ruler no more is preferred over Droplet as you want to keep a card advantage and it's just a Going 2nd filler card for this deck. Side deck has backrow hate that can be tossed in if your you're dueling a trapbased deck. There's a lot of whack and weird boards but this is mostly a for fun deck as it's end board is not insane as Prank kid's adventure or Swordsouls. But as another pile deck with Adventure_Token.exe package it makes it feel like this deck can do something with each oppening hand.   Important Note:  If at any point you use Gamma Eltanin's effect you cannot go for Adventure Token plays that turn so choose which approach you play wisely as it will lock you out of the Adventure token package if you go for the megalith plays.

deck_excerpt: Full decklist & play guide to crushing your foes with the powers within the Wetlands... except Frog the Jam.
deck_description:
...Except Frog The Jam: A Paleozoic/Aquaactress/Frog Triple Feature

Ever wanted to see a 3000 ATK Frog?

(Edit sidenote at the start for those seeing it: For some reason, YGOPRODECK is convinced that Mother Grizzly is SR. It is not. It is an N. I checked. I don't know why it believes this is the case. But if you clicked here because of the comedy of 'haha this loser's using an SR in the N/R' format, hi! Enjoy the decklist!) The N/R Festival is here in Master Duel; a chance to try decks far more interesting than anything in the Platinum ladder with essentially no cost. As someone who climbed into platinum using none other than a Paleozoic deck already, I decided 'hey wouldn't it be funny if I did that here too'? And so here we are! This deck combines the powers of the Paleozoic trap-"monster" lineup, the few decent Frogs at N/R, and the severely-underrepresented Aquaactress archetype into a single deck that boasts both disruption and sheer unga bunga power on tiny little aquatic entities. It's heavily based off this list made by DevilDeckYGO and direYGO (read: I netdecked for the groundworks and modified it from there), so credit where credit is due on that one. With that said, let's get into how the deck works!

Step 1: Setting the Stage

The heart and soul of this deck is your Field Spell and your trio of Continuous Spells. Wetlands gives all Level 2 or lower Water Aqua monsters 1200 attack; this is functionally your entire monster lineup (save two), because for some reason the Aquaactresses are Aqua despite clearly being fishes. Well, I won't complain. Meanwhile, the Aquarium trio all provide benefits to your WATER monsters and/or your Aquaactresses, and revive an Aqua from the grave if your foe ever removes them. Three Aquaactress Tetra provides a scary amount of consistency; the longer it's allowed to stay on the board, the more cards it can fetch you, and you can even activate multiples of it in one turn! For this reason, Aquarium Stage is one of the most ideal searches if you're not going on the offensive - it gives your WATER monsters battle protection and your Aquaactresses specifically protection from -all- monster effects. I can't count the times foes have attempted to fire a Malevolent Sin or Relinquished only to accomplish nothing. Aquarium Set provides a moderate 300 ATK boost to all WATER monsters and an additional 300 to Aquaactresses specifically. It's a decent choice if you already have Stage or are up against a deck that primarily uses backrow-based removal, and it's also very funny to put a new meaning to the phrase "Set, pass". Aquarium Lighting is the weirdest of the three, doubling attack when battling enemy monsters, but only for Aquaactresses specifically. Don't take this one unless you specifically both already have an Aquaactress and either Set or Wetlands online. Of the other two Aquaactresses, Guppy summons an Actress from hand, and Arowana searches one from deck. I'm only running one of each of these because Guppy's useless unless you already have one of the others in hand, and Arowana needs you to tribute. Which isn't super difficult in this deck - it's easy enough to get a Paleozoic or Ronintoadin on the field - but it's still an investment (and one that can end up falling down a Bottomless Trap Hole all too easily). Needless to say, Tetra is the best of the three.

Step 2: A Chorus of Croaks

No Toadally Awesome in this format, but wetlands girls make do. Your frogs are an excellent way to squeeze out value over the opponent, and can become surprisingly bulky with Wetlands up. Whether you've seen its lock or simply its advantage-gathering, you probably already know what Dupe Frog does, but Flip Flop Frog is another story. It's similar to the PACMAN cast of reusable flip-esque monsters, but unlike them, its effect fires even when flipped face up by an opponent's attack. This means Flip Flop Frog at least trades with anything attacking into it, but it gets better for three simple reasons;
  1. Flip Flop Frog's effect is non-targeting, non-destroying removal. This means it gets around annoying thorns in the meta's side such as Invoked Cocytus or Blue-Eyes Chaos Dragon (not MAX, the other one).
  2. The more Frogs you have on the board, the better Flip Flop gets. Ronintoadin is a frog while it's on the field, so it's easy to bounce two or more cards on your turn and then go for a lot of damage.
  3. Aquarium Stage is Flip Flop Frog's best friend. Your opponent attacks into your Flip Flop Frog, gets bounced, and Flip Flop stays alive, ready to return more cards to the hand the next turn.
And then we have one copy of Unifrog, who... exists. It's a bit of a silly high-roll tech choice, and you can cut it if you want, but it's searchable off Dupe Frog and gives you a way to pick away at backrow-heavy decks beyond just your Paleozoic traps. We also have two monsters that -aren't- frogs but will be included here for brevity's sake. Dewdark of the Ice Barrier is a beatstick and Gagaga Cowboy-esque gamecloser tool. He has 1200 ATK normally, 2400 under Wetlands and more with an Aquarium Set or two involved, and can attack directly. This list runs him at 2, but feel free to modify up or down based on preference. Finally, my extreme jank tech, Mother Grizzly. Yes, a recruiter from 2004. Why? Because this format is slow enough that set monsters aren't necessarily being destroyed by effects a majority of the time, and she is one of the only ways you can search either Flip Flop Frog or Aquaactress Tetra, the two most crucial monsters for your plans.

Interlude: The Back Row

The Paleozoic lineup to this deck is really quite simple. 3 apiece of Olenoides, Canadia, and Dinomischus. (Oh and a single Torrential Tribute.) Olenoides is the primary form of backrow removal you have access to. In a format this slow, it's going to be very handy. If you can, fire it during the opponent's End Phase after they've set cards in order to render them inactive. Canadia is a fantastic form of disruption by setting your foes' monsters face down, and Dinomischus is the most powerful by banishing ANY face up card... but has the cost of a discard. Perhaps more notably in this deck than any other, Paleozoics can revive upon either player activating a trap card! They start off at 1200 ATK, but easily reach 2400 or higher after a Wetlands, just like Dewdark. Extra notable (and often forgotten) is that they're also immune to all monster effects when summoned this way, making them powerful beatsticks that are difficult to out via monsters! Just remember that they -will- be banished upon leaving the field unless you tuck them snugly under an Xyz Monster.

Step 3: Special Guests from the Extra Deck

Hoo boy. The Extra Deck options in the N/R Festival are... messy, let's say. But there's a lot of fun in that mess, so here's the rundown on the Extra Deck options this deck plays! You don't go into these super frequently, in all honesty. Number 54: Lion Heart and Number 39: Utopia Roots are both made via three or two Tetra respectively, and either bounce battle damage and have battle immunity or negate attacks and power up vs. Xyz decks, but... well, you'll make these once in a blue moon at best. Feel free to cut them for more copies of the relevant extra deck. The rest of your Xyz are all Rank 2, and thus more accessible. Of them, the best two are The Phantom Knights of Cursed Javelin, which negates a monster's effect and sucks its attack to 0, and Number 45: Crumble Logos the (et cetera), who has higher attack (2200 vs. 1600) and can negate backrow or monsters (as well as all other cards sharing that card's name while it remains on the field), but can't lower attack. We play 2 Javelin and 1 Logos here; if you cut anything from this extra deck, you probably can't go wrong with adding a second Logos. Out of the other Rank 2 Xyz, Herald of Pure Lights cycles cards from grave to hand to deck, but doesn't provide much advantage unless you URGENTLY need a monster from grave to hand, and Cat Shark, who is a wall you could also use to make your Logos a 4400 ATK beatstick sometimes. The other half of the Extra Deck is links. Starting off with the two you'll be going into the most - Codebreaker Virus Swordsman is an excellently sized body for a link-2 that even revives itself once on destruction (though this won't help you against Bottomless Trap Hole), and Geonator Transverser, a serious contender for underrated MVP of the deck. Being able to swap spare weak monsters with your foes' main powerhouse comes up more often than you'd think. Watch the zones and wait for your chance. If your opponent isn't using backrow-based monster removal, Doublebyte Dragon can just straight up win you the game, and Gravity Controller is an out for if your foe tries to do the same against you. Pentestag lets those Wetlands-boosted beatsticks break through wally foes, and Powercode Talker is at once both beatstick and effect negation. Triple Burst Dragon is just okay, feel free to cut it. Finally, Marincess Marbled Rock is a water link. Yup, that's it. You literally can't use any of her effects, but tragically enough, you have no better options.

Step 4: Okay, So How Do I Actually Play The Deck

The number of traps you have, as well as monsters that activate best on destruction, means that first and foremost you want to go first. Don't activate your Aquariums (except for Stage) if you don't have to (i.e. not summoning an Aquaactress turn one) - the lack of information means leaving your opponents uncertain of your deck and thus less likely to play around Paleozoics/Flip Flop Frog/etc. If you have Stage and Dupe Frog in hand, it's sometimes best not to activate Stage at all, letting Dupe Frog die and thus loading your grave for an eventual Ronin as well as finding you Flip Flop. This is up to your own preference, though. Your main goal early game is to disrupt your foe's plays with your Paleozoics and Frogs before pivoting into violence through Wetlands. Some games you won't draw Wetlands at all, and that's fine; you can either chip down your opponent or attempt to use the Extra Deck instead. Don't fall for the temptation of going into your Extra Deck at the first moment, though! A lot of the times it's better to leave your aqua monsters on the field to be protected by Stage or to get the effects of cards such as Tetra or Dupe Frog. Keep a card in hand for Dinomischus where possible. Your ideal discard is Ronintoadin as an excellent way to get it into the grave, but anything works. Also, remember; both Stage-protected Aquaactress monsters and Paleozoics are immune to monster effects. This means your main threats are backrow removal (backrow that destroys monsters) and backrow removal (cards that get rid of your spells and traps). Watch your opponent's traps and make careful guesses as to what they might be; a well-timed Torrential Tribute can put you out of the game altogether. Other than all of that, this deck isn't too complex to pilot once you know what you're doing. Good luck, and enjoy your time frogging!

Afterword: Other Options

The ratio and types of backrow this deck uses is entirely up to you. Lost Wind, Bottomless Trap Hole, and more copies of Torrential Tribute are all great for disrupting plays. Moray of Greed could prove useful with a higher quotient of monsters, but the fact that we're at almost exactly a 20:10:10 ratio means it's less likely to activate. Dragon Queen of Tragic Endings is very very funny - summoning itself when you control 3+ Continuous Spells, drawing a card and making the foe discard when it deals battle damage, and reviving itself by sending a continuous spell to the grave, which also triggers your Aquariums' revive effects. It's a bit too highroll-y for my liking, but hey, give it a shot if you feel like it. Magical Broker is another way to trigger your own revival effects and also stalls for time if need be. Hooray for slow formats. Given that Dewdark is a tuner, you could probably choose to run them at 3 and a Level 4 Synchro of your choice, of which this format has a grand total of six. Out of them, Old Entity Hastorr is probably your best bet. Every single Paleozoic backrow is N/R. Customize as to your want. More backrow-removing tools is highly welcomed; as both your Paleozoics (by default) and Aquaactresses (under Stage) are immune to monster effects, backrow-based disruption is their Achilles' heel. Mystical Space Typhoon, Nobleman of Extermination, and Mythical Beast Garuda are all fair options. You can attempt to run a heavier Marincess package; both of their Link-1s are available at Rare, plus the sheer power of Marincess Wave is not to be overlooked. If you want to simply splash one in to recover off Marbled Rock, Marincess Basilalima is the most generic, I guess. And of course, for sheer style points, accept Frog the Jam into your heart and deck-- eh? whaddya mean it's called Slime Toad now? Thanks for reading, and feel free to comment with any severe deckbuilding issues I may have made down below!

deck_excerpt: A deck built with morphtronic support and the powerful halq/deskbot/mecha phantom beast engine to help get out power tool dragon or other powerful syn
deck_description: Your main goal in this deck is to get out Halq so that you can get out deskbot 001 and then get out mecha phantom beast aurorodon using them both, at which point deskbot 001's graveyard effect will leave you with a level 1 tuner and 3 level 3 tokens. From there, you can get out the boss of the morphtronics, power tool dragon, or baronne de fleur for the powerful negate effect.  You can get out halq with any tuner and another monster, so you're relying on celfon to get out a tuner, or scopen to pull a non-tuner level 4 out of your hand. scopen plus a level 4 can also just lead into a level 7 synchro, and remoten helps fish scopen or more copies of celfon and smartfon. smartfon is a good fisher and a tuner you can special summon out of your hand, which also helps fulfil halq's summoning requirements.  Overall, it's not a meta deck, it's not even rogue, but it can win pretty well against other non-meta decks and can even lock horns pretty well with rogue decks like melffy or ghostricks. Baronne de Fleur is really good destruction power and a negate, you get out Accesscode talker pretty easily, and the fact that smartfon and celfon aren't limited to once per turn helps you swarm the field, especially if you manage to land machine dulplication on celfon.  An important note is that smartfon is a special summon monster, so it's not a valid target for machine duplucation. You'll be using that on celfon and remoten.  Some substitutes: radion is a thunder monster rather than a machine, so feel free to swap it out for another boomboxen or slingen, but tbh radion's attack boost is genuinely good when you have a swarm of morphtronics out. In addition, trident warrior can always be swapped for another goblindburgh for the ability to get out celfon with it, too, but sometimes trident warrior's 1800 attack does end up mattering when against a bricking deck that has a decently sized monster on the board.

deck_excerpt: Madolches + Staples from Cyber Strike / Charmers SDs, and a Kaiju package in the side.
deck_description: I love Madolches. They're by far one of my favorite decks, but holy heck, they are expensive. Thankfully, with the power of reprints from the Albaz Strike structure deck, and some staples from the Charmer and Cyber Strike Structures to really enhance the playability of the strategy in these times of DPE Scythe spam for the budget, but realistically this deck, even full build with Prosperities and Small Worlds, albeit extremely consistent, does not put up a strong board on it's own. The deck puts up one negate, and a GY shuffle. Another issue is it's absolutely required, yet disgusting brick in Madolche Messengelato. The cards in this deck that you would use to summon Messengelato, which would be Puddingcess Chocolat-A-la-Mode and Hootcake, CANNOT summon from hand. If they would please give us something to shuffle Messengelato back and more in-archetype interruption, I think it'd make it go from rogue to absolutely able to handle the meta.

Yet another Marincess deck. As you can see I've cut down the Marincess core and added yet more goodstuff plus crossout-designator and fodders for it. I also decided to go a little over the 40 cards which seems, at least to me, suprisingly good. There is no actual combo for the deck since you utilize your extenders to at least bring out Aqua Argonaut on your first turn, if you play first. I'm open to any suggestions you guys may have.

deck_excerpt: Surprisingly, this fan favourite girl has most of her cards available in Normal/Rare. This blind-second Sky Striker deck will smash through your oppon
deck_description: A deck specifically made for Master Duel's N/R Rarity Event.  Surprisingly, this fan favourite girl has most of her cards available in Normal/Rare! This means that a somewhat functional albeit weaker Sky Striker strategy is viable in the N/R format. There is no Engage, Kagari, Shizuku, Widow Anchor, Zeke, and Hornet Drones, but these ladies can still pack quite a punch!  The usual Sky Striker strategy is used - wear down your opponent with net gain trades using spell cards to win in a drawn out grind game. 6 potent equip spells are in the deck to allow the Strikers to beat down your opponent's monsters.  The Extra Deck Strikers only feature 3 Hayate and Kaina. The rest are rank 4 toolbox and generic link monsters.  And remember... RAYE IS BAYE!!!  If you have any questions about this deck, feel free to ask me in the comments below!

deck_excerpt: The most fun deck I made for the N/R event.
deck_description: This is a deck I built based on my experiences in the TCG playing one of my favorite decks: Beetrooper. Of course, Beetrooper doesn't exist in Master Duel but many of the cards used in the deck are available for use in Event N/R. Among them, the Battlewasp archetype and the Gokipole and Giant Ballpark engine stand out, which has synergy with Normal Insect monsters, allowing you to play fun games throughout the duel. The main idea of ​​the deck is focused on taking advantage of the floating effects of the main Insect monsters of the deck that even if they are destroyed or leave the field they give you an advantage in the form of Special Summoning from the Deck or adding Insects to the hand. These cards are: Battlewasp - Sting the Poison, basically it is a "Stratos" from the Battlewasp archetype and normally you will add Arbalest the Rapidfire to the hand which is a great Follow Up for your next turn by Special Summoning Sting the Poison back to the field and allow you Synchro plays such as SYNCHRO-6 Halberd the Charge. If you already have the Arbalest in your hand you can add 1 of the Battlewasp Extenders in place like Pin the Bullseye or Twinbow the Attacker so they enter the field allowing you to make Synchro plays like the SYNCHRO-5 Azusa the Ghost Bow or some LINK-2 like Codebreaker Virus Swordsman. The Pin the Bullseye and Twinbow the Attacker Extenders also have field effects, with the Pin the Bullseye dealing 200 damage to the opponent and the Twinbow the Attacker being able to do 2 Attacks during the Battle Phase which means inflicting 2000 damage per battle. (Remember that Twinbow the Attacker locks you into Insects for the rest of the turn if you Special Summon it by its own effect). - Gokipole, this is one of my favorite Insect monsters because if it is sent to the GY you will be able to add a Level 4 Insect to your hand, and if you add a Normal Monster with this effect, you can Special Summon it. and destroy a Monster on the field with ATK equal to or greater than that of the Normal monster. That is, in this deck, he will either add Arbalest the Rapidfire to the hand that as I said is a great Follow Up to be your Normal Summon or it will be an interaction with the opponent by adding you to Vanilla Shiny Black "C" Squadder that will enter the field and destroy an opponent's monster with 2k ATK or more without targeting. It happens a lot that you set Gokipole face-down and the opponent destroys him in battle and you use your interaction effect by bringing Vanilla from the deck and destroying his monster by taking him by surprise because no one expects that to happen. (Detail that you have to pay attention is that he can destroy your monsters too, so in Master Duel if the opponent doesn't have a monster that can be destroyed but the message to destroy a monster on the field appears, you click No because what will happen would be to destroy your own monster). - Arbalest the Rapidfire besides being a Monster Reborn of the Small Insects in Normal Summon (Special Summon doesn't work), it has excellent Floating effect when destroyed by an opponent's card you Special Summon a Battlewasp Monster straight from the Deck which is very beneficial. So even if your opponent negates his Normal Summon effect with Forbidden Chalice you can go into the battle phase and crash the Arbalest into an opponent's monster just to Special Summon Sting the Poison straight from the deck which will add another Battlewasp Monster on top of that to the hand. Just by knowing what the 3 main monsters in the Main Deck do, you can see why the deck works: You can have plays every turn when Looping your own monsters, for example: Sting the Poison Add Arbalest the Rapidfire and Arbalest the Rapidfire Reborn Sting the Poison that can add you another Arbalest the Rapidfire so the Loop never ends. Same goes for Gokipole and Arbalest the Rapidfire where Gokipole Add Arbalest and Arbalest Reborn Gokipole and did all the Resource Loop again. - Finally, speaking of Floating effects, we have the excellent Field Spell Giant Ballpark that whenever any monster you control is destroyed by an opponent's card effect, you can Special Summon a Normal Insect from your GY, which in this case will always be Shiny Black "C" Squadder. But Giant Ballpark main function is its Damage Calculation effect which allows you to avoid taking battle damage (either you or your opponent) to send a Level 4 or lower Insect from your Deck to the GY. Then we can send the Gokipole that will activate its effect of adding an Insect to the hand that you will choose if it will be Follow Up through Arbalest or it will be interaction through Vanilla or even more interesting is to send the Shiny Black "C" Squadder because like you sent a Normal Monster by the effect of Giant Ballpark you will simply be able to Special Summon any number of copies of it to the field of your hand, Deck and/or GY which means having 3 Shiny Black "C" Squadder on the field to attack with them and do a lot of damage and in Main Phase 2 make Synchro, Xyz or Link plays. Talking about the tech cards used in the deck: Lightning Vortex and Raigeki Break don't have such a high cost in this deck because both Gokipole and Shiny Black "C" Squadder are good discards since with Giant Ballpark you reborn Vanilla from GY and Gokipole becomes a Search from Arbalest the Rapidfire or Vanilla to enter the field and destroy an opponent's monster. So basically you can still get value out of your Monsters even after discarding them to the GY even if you discard a Battlewasp as you can use Revival Swarm to bring Sting the Poison back to the field and still get a Search for free. Speaking of Revival Swarm, it allows you to make very strong plays, especially in the Grind Game, such as giving Reborn from Sting the Poison that adds Arbalest the Rapidfire and as you didn't spend your Normal Summon you still bring the Arbalest to the field that goes give you Reborn from another GY Insect and in the end with just one card you managed to bring three Monsters to the field to make plays mainly from Synchro and Xyz RANK-3. On top of that Revival Swarm has an excellent effect on the GY of targeting an Insect you control like Halberd the Charge and it cannot be destroyed by battle or card effects until the end of the opponent's turn, including your cards. So even if you use Torrential Tribute you will still have the monster protected. Torrential Tribute is very valuable in this deck because you will continue to generate an advantage by destroying monsters like Gokipole for example, so losing cards on the field is not that big of a problem for you. Dogmatika Punishment has the versatility of being able to destroy both Monsters or Spells/Traps too because if the opponent has a monster with 1700ATK or less you send the Fossil Machine Skull Wagon to the GY instead of the Blue-Eyes Ultimate Dragon and it has GY effect banish yourself to target and destroy a Spell/Trap on the field. So even not using Mystical Space Typhoon you still have 6 Spell Trap outs in the deck which are 3 Raigeki Break and 3 Dogmatika Punishment. Ring of Destruction I'm just using it to receive rewards of causing Burn on the opponent, you could be using Needle Ceiling instead for example it's a card that does the same role as Torrential Tribute but only for Face-Up monsters so if you have a monster Face-Down and your opponent has 3 Monsters Face-Up you use Needle Ceiling and destroy all their monsters but keep your monster on the field. The main Extra Deck Monsters are the Synchro Battlewasp Azusa the Ghost Bow and Halberd the Charge, being Azusa a card that has a good effect of causing Burn to the opponent but the main factor is that it is Tuner so if you use Sting the Poison + any Lv3 Monster to make it and have Pin the Bullseye on the field you use both to make Halberd the Charge which is the deck's win condition because it basically takes away any monster with 5k or less ATK in battle as it cuts ATK of the opponent's monster in half which means trigger the effect of Azusa the Ghost Bow to return to the field from GY and that way you have both Synchro of the archetype on the field to control the game. Halberd the Charge is such a good Boss Monster in this format that for example there was an Infinitrack Gadget Train player who did turn 1 the Ravenous Tarantula and on top did Pain Gainer, followed by The Seven Sins which means ending up with a 4k ATK monster with 4 materials and protection against destruction when detach 2 Materials. But with only 1 Sting the Poison and 1 Extender I dealt with this boss monster because I added Arbalest the Rapidfire to the hand (Follow Up) and brought Pin the Bullseye to the field and set Torrential Tribute and on his turn if he gave summon any monster I would activate Torrential Tribute and chain Sting the Poison to Tribute Pin the Bullseye and negate the effects of Seven Sins and that way he would lose protection from destruction and the entire field would be cleared. My opponent was smart and decided to go into the battle phase to force negate the Sting the Poison I used and then decided to spend the turn playing around Torrential Tribute. But since I had Arbalest the Rapidfire from Follow Up I simply Normal Summoned it and reborn Sting the Poison which added Twinbow the Attacker to enter the field to be Sting the Poison's tribute to negate Seven Sins again and this time I didn't even need to use Torrential Tribute once because it was just Halberd the Charge that I took it out in the Battle Phase by cutting its ATK in half. That is, the deck has outs within the engine itself for practically all boss monsters of this format, either negating their effects and destroying them with the traps used or taking them out in battle. About the Extra Deck's Link Monsters, Codebreaker Virus Swordsman is very good in this deck because you easily put two monsters on the field and often they are of levels that don't allow you to Synchro or Xyz Summon so what's left is for you to use them to do it this Codebreaker that has absurd 2300ATK which is very high for a Link-2 monster and its main factor besides ATK is that it has excellent Floating effect if the opponent destroys it either by card effect or by battle it will return to the field in the End Phase. And this is relevant because not only does it keep card advantage but as it leaves the Extra Monster Zone you can return it to one of the columns of the Extra Monster Zone that are not occupied and on your turn do the Shinobi Insect Hagakuremino pointing at it which means that the opponent can't target the Shinobi for attacks so it's a card that stays on the field for a long time until you come back into play. Shinobi as well as Geonator Transverser has the function of punishing players who place their monsters in the wrong zones so you can take advantage of that. The Number 20: Giga-Brilliant and Number 70: Malevolent Sin as they are Insect-type Xyz monsters can be used as material to make the Digital Bug Corebage on top which in addition to good ATK status has an excellent effect of shuffle a monster in opponent's defense position into deck and can even attach Insects from your GY to it to keep using this effect again. Just be careful that as you need to detach 2 Xyz materials to summon the Digital Bug Corebage on top if you use the effect of one of these Xyz you won't be able to do the Corebage on top later. Number 49: Fortune Tune is a utility card that survives on the field for several turns as it cannot be targeted by cards and still protects itself from destruction including your cards like Torrential Tribute while giving you 500LP every Standby Phase. And when the opponent finally takes him out of the field you use his effect to return him and two level3 monsters to the deck recycling their cards to do it again if necessary. Super Quantal Mech Beast Grampulse and Number 75: Bamboozling Gossip Shadow are the best possible interactions to do in this N/R format. Gossip Shadow is a monster negate as the effect makes both players draw 1 card and Mech Beast Grampulse is a Spell/Trap pop every turn. Disregard the Side Deck, they are just examples of cards that you can test in the main deck.

deck_name: Dragon Link Deck - PLAT 1 in Master Duel
deck_excerpt: A Dragon Chaos deck archetype, using a bunch of  Dark/Light monsters  to summon powerful  Link/Synchro/XYZ monsters from the Extra Deck.
deck_description:
A powerful deck, I managed to reach Platinum 1 in Master Duel without complications, I leave you the deck list with their possible changes. MAIN DECK HAND -TRAPS - Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring x2 ( can be x3 instead of Nibiru or replace into Maxx "C ") - PSY-Framegear Gamma x2  - PSY-Frame Driver x1 (don't replace this one) -Effect Veiler x2 ( can be x3 instead of Nibiru ) - Nibiru, the Primal Being x1 ( can be replace by any Kaiju, Effect Veiler, Ash Blossom, etc.)  *** You can use any Hand Trap at will, but prioritize DARK and LIGHT ones, these can be add to your hand by Chaos Ruler effect. Another HAND-TRAPS options are:
  • Ghost Ogre & Snow Rabbit
  • D.D. Crow
  • Artifact  Lancea
  • Fantastical Dragon Phantazmay
MONSTERS - Rokket Tracer x2 (can be x3 instead of Chamber Dragonmaid or Starliege Seyfert) - Rokket Recharger x1 - Rokket Synchron x2 - Absorouter Dragon x1 (can be x2 instead of Destrudo the Lost Dragon or Chaos Emperor) - Starliege Seyfert x3 (can be x2) - Black Dragon Collapserpent x2 (can be x1, but I won't do it) - White Dragon Wyverburster x2 (can be x1, but I won't do it) - Chaos Dragon Levianeer x1 - Black Metal Dragon x2 (can be x3 instead of Chamber Dragonmaid or Starliege Seyfert) - Red-Eyes Darkness Metal Dragon x1 (can be x2 instead of  Chaos Emperor) - Noctovision Dragon x2 (can be x3 instead of Destrudo the Lost Dragon or Chaos Emperor) - Destrudo the Lost Dragon's Frisson x1 (use it for link summon Cryston Halqifibrax, can be replace for Noctovision Dragon or Absorouter Dragon) - Chaos Emperor, the Dragon of Armageddon x1 (use it for XYZ summon  Number 22: Zombiestein, also a good extender; can be replace for Noctovision Dragon, Absorouter Dragon, Red-Eyes Darkness Metal Dragon or Galactic Spiral Dragon) - Chamber Dragonmaid x1 (can be replace for Rokket Tracer ,Omni Dragon Brotaur or Black Metal Dragon; also replace Dragonmaid Tidying  if you don't want it ) SPELLS - Boot Sector Launch x1 - Dragon Ravine x1 - Chaos Space x3 (BEST CARD IN THE DECK, use it to search any CHAOS Dragon) - Foolish Burial x1 (Good exteder, use it to send Absorouter, Destrudo,Starliege, etc to the GV; can be replace for any other CARD) - Called by the Grave x2 (Protecction vs HAND TRAPS, can be replace for any other CARD) - Quick Launch x3 (can be x2) *** Another useful SPELLs are Monster Reborn, Raigeki, Harpie's Feather Duster, Lightning Storm, Crossout Designator or World Legacy Guardragon. TRAPS - Dragonmaid Tidying x2 (If you don't play Chamber Dragonmaid, replace it for any TRAP like  Infinite Impermanence,  Solemn Strike, Solemn Judgment, etc.) Extra Deck - Chaos Ruler, the Chaotic Magical Dragon x1 (YOUR DECK MASTER, use it to send cards to the GV and add any LIGHT or DARK monster) - Hot Red Dragon Archfiend Abyss x1 ( A DENIER and BEATER, summon it using Effect Veiler or Rokket Synchron + Chaos Ruler) - Borreload Savage Dragon x1 (A DENIER and BEATER, summon it using Rokket Synchron + Lvl 7 Dragon  OR Rokket Tracer + Lvl 4 Dragon ) - Number 22: Zombiestein x1 (A DENIER and BEATER, summon it using 2 LVL 8 MONSTERS like, Chaos Ruler,  Chaos Dragon Levianeer or Chaos Emperor) - Striker Dragon x2 (A SEARCHER, use it to add  'Boot Sector Launch', also casn be use to add any Rokket in teh GV) - Guardragon Pisty x1 (A EXTENDER, special summon any Dragon that is banished or in GV) - Dragunity Knight - Romulus x1 (A SEARCHER and EXTENDER, use it to add 'Dragon Ravine') - Quadborrel Dragon x1 (AN EXTENDER and  DISRUPTOR, discard 1 card and destroy  1 face-up monster on the field, if it destroyed itself you can special summon two Rokket Monster from the GV, that can be use to summon Borreload Savage Dragon) - Hieratic Seal of the Heavenly Spheres x1 ( A DISRUPTOR and SEARCHER, use it to return any face-up card to the hand; prioritize Normal Summon Monsters, Extra Deck Monsters or Continuos Traps; also special summon any dragon from your deck ; prioritize Chamber Dragonmaid) - Crystron Halqifibrax x1 (AN EXTENDER, special summon any Lvl 3 o lower tuner from your deck, prioritize Rokket Synchron ) - I:P Masquerena x1 (A DISRUPTOR, use it to Link summon Knightmare Unicorn or Apollousa in your opponent turn) - Knightmare Unicorn x1 (A DISRUPTOR, use it to shuffle a card into the Deck, also a LINK 3 to summon Accescode easier) - Apollousa, Bow of the Goddess x1 (A DISRUPTOR, usually you will summon it using Cryston Halqifibrax and other two materials; negate monster effects of your opponent) - Accesscode Talker x1 ( A BEATER, use it to finish the game, if is LINK SUMMON using Unicorn has 5300 ATK, also useful to clear any card on the opponent field removing links in your GV) *** Another options from Extra Deck:
  • Another copy of Hieratic Seal 
  • Another copy of Striker Dragon
  • Borrelsword Dragon
  • Borreload Dragon
  • Black Luster Soldier - Soldier of Chaos
  • Triple Burst Dragon
  • Knightmare Phoenix
  • Knightmare Cerberus
  • Union Carrier ( also add 'Dragon Buster Destruction Sword'  at the MAIN DECK)
  • Number 38: Hope Harbinger Dragon
  • Dingirsu, the Orcust of the Evening Star
  • Hieratic Sun Dragon Overlord
  • Number 68: Sanaphond the Sky Prison
  • Crystal Wing Synchro Dragon
  • Hot Red Dragon Archfiend
  • Beelze of the Diabolic Dragons

deck_name: Rikka Aromages (Master Duel, N/R rarity only)
deck_excerpt: A deck that utilizes both the strengths of the Rikka's combo potential for Xyz plays and the Aromages' control tools, all at N/R rarity only.
deck_description:
Hi, Grayewick the Fusionist here, back with plant waifus. Yes. They're actually fun to play, test them before you judge me. Anyway, presenting Rikka Aromages. "Why play this deck?" This deck is surprisingly good enough in a slower format like the N/R rarity festival, because not only is it a control deck that utilizes your Aroma Spells/Traps for disruption, it can also combo out of nowhere and OTK with Xyz plays through your Rikka monsters. It also does not give a fuck about Kaijus, which is absolutely great, for the reasons that will be explained later. I'll go further in details in the list. The main deck: Monsters • The Rikka monsters (Hellebore, Snowdrop, Erica, Primula, & Petal) - Your main combo engine. They all do something about Tributing and in response to a Plant monster getting Tributed in any way, shape, or form. These are their effects:
  1. Hellebore - A hand trap that negates the effects of your opponent's monsters' activated effects. It can also Special Summon herself from the GY by Tributing any Plant monster but banishes herself when she leaves the field.
  2. Snowdrop - Your main combo starter. You're usually starting with either her and either Hellebore or Erica. Special Summons herself and 1 other Plant monster in your hand at a cost of Tributing a Plant monster. She also helps you with the Xyz plays by modulating the levels of all Plant monsters you currently control depending on the target's Level.
  3. Erica - The Level 6 monster that you'll mostly be using for combos, and also the one you're gonna be searching the most with Petal. She's also a hand trap that boosts a battling Plant monster's ATK/DEF by Tributing herself, and like Hellebore, can also summon herself from the GY with the same said stipulations.
  4. Primula - Your extender of the deck. Special Summons herself when a Plant monster you control is Tributed by any means (which will be relevant soon), and can also modulate the Levels of your two targeted Plant monsters by increasing their Levels by 2.
  5. Petal - Your main searcher of the deck. She searches any of your Rikka monsters during the Main Phase, except a copy of herself, and either adds it to your hand or sends it to the GY. She can also Special Summon herself from your GY during your opponent's End Phase, if you control no monsters, or all monsters you control are Plants.
• The Aroma monsters (Bergamot, Marjoram, Rosemary, & Angelica) - Your main control engine. If you play Duel Links, you most likely already know what they do but regardless, these are their effects:
  1. Bergamot - Your game ender. If your LP is higher than your opponent, he grants all Plant monsters you control piercing, also if you gain LP while he's on the field, he gains 1000 ATK and DEF until the end of your opponent's next turn.
  2. Marjoram - Your GY disruption. If your LP is higher than your opponent, she grants you battle damage protection from attacks involving your Plant monsters, also if you gain LP while she's on the field, she can banish cards in your opponent's GY, up to the number of Aroma monsters you currently control.
  3. Rosemary - Your field disruption. If your LP is higher than your opponent, she grants your Plant monsters an Armades effect but only for monsters, also if you gain LP while she's on the field, she can change the battle position of 1 monster on the field. This is not a hard once per turn.
  4. Angelica - Your main Tuner, if you ever feel like Synchro Summoning, but more importantly, she's a hand trap that can discard herself as a Quick Effect to gain LP equal to a targeted Aroma monster's ATK in the GY. She can also Special Summon herself from the GY if your LP is higher than your opponent's and control an Aroma monster, but banishes herself when she leaves the field.
Spells • Mystical Space Typhoon - Backrow removal. Could also be Nobleman of Extermination if you wanna game harder. • Aroma Garden - The archetypal Field Spell, at least for the Aromas. Its effect can be used to gain 500 LP and boost the ATK and DEF of all monsters you control by 500, if you control an Aroma monster, even if it leaves the field. Also, it heals you for 1000 LP when an Aroma monster is destroyed by battle or card effect, and this effect is not once per turn, which we will be abusing most of the time through our interactions. Traps • Ballista Squad - Targets and destroys a card your opponent controls for a cost of Tributing, which is the most important part about this card, since it triggers our Rikka monsters' effects. • Blessed Winds - Your 3-in-1 interruption. Just hover over the highlighted name to read, since they're too long lmao. Also, the main reason why most if not all of our Extra Deck monsters are Plant monsters. • Dried Winds - Destroys an opponent's monster upon gaining LP, also allows you to pay LP if your LP is at least 3000 LP higher than your opponent's to destroy all of their monsters whose total ATK is less than or equal the amount paid. • Humid Winds - Your main searcher, at a cost of paying 1000 LP, also allows you to gain 500 LP if your LP is lower than your opponent's. • Horn of Heaven - An aggressive Counter Trap, which can be used in response to a potential Summon of an opponent's problematic monster at a cost of Tributing 1 monster, which makes it even better. The Extra Deck You'll notice that most if not all of these cards are Plant monsters since they're recyclable by Blessed Winds, although, one could obviously adjust the ratios of each card however much they see fit. I'm just saying. The only Link monsters • The Sunavalons (Dryas & Dryades) - There's no reason not to play these cards, especially since we're playing all Plant monsters. The Xyz monsters • Kanzashi the Rikka Queen - Your Rikka boss monster, kinda, since she's the easiest to bring out turn one. She's a Rank 6 Plant Xyz monster that has an effect to detach an Xyz material when a monster(s) is Tributed and Special Summons a monster in either GY, but negating its effects, also makes it so that it is treated as a Plant. She also has a card effect destruction protection by Tributing 1 Plant monster from your hand or field as a replacement, but only once per turn. • Number 50: Blackship of Corn - A Rank 4 Plant Xyz monster that allows you to send a monster your opponent controls to the GY and inflict 1000 damage to your opponent, so long as it can be targeted. • Number 87: Queen of the Night - Your ACTUAL boss monster, I think, since she's got the arguably best effects of all your Extra Deck monsters, while also having the best stats. She's a Rank 8 Plant Xyz monster that has a once per turn Quick Effect that can be one of the three effects in selection. Hover over her name to see the full details. The Synchro monsters • Periallis, Empress of Blossoms - She's a Level 7 Plant Synchro monster that can once per turn Special Summon any Level 5 or higher Plant monster from your hand or GY. She also gets her ATK boosted by 400 for each Plant monster you control, except herself. This effect actually applies for both of its copies if you have two or three of her. • Splendid Rose - She's a Level 6 Plant Synchro monster that can be used to get over some problematic high ATK monsters that can be targeted, at a cost of banishing a Plant monster from your GY. She also has an effect that enables her to attack twice, at the same cost as stated but also halving her ATK until the end of the turn which may or may not come up. • Queen of Thorns - Your main floodgate. She's a Level 6 Plant Synchro monster that makes it so that each player must pay 1000 LP for each monster Normal or Special Summoned from their hand, except for Plant-type monsters. Obviously, this will never be a downside for us. The side deck More optional cards, as per usual. • Fairy Archer Ingunar - A Level 6 Plant monster that could be a great extender if you wanna go more heavy on the Rikka engine for more Rank 6 plays. • World Carrotweight Champion - Always a good one of extender from the GY that can also set up your GY for Plant decks. • Evilswarm Mandragora - A Level 4 Cyber Dragon for Plants, commonly seen in Rank 4 toolbox decks back in the day. • Aromage Cananga - A Level 3 Plant monster that can be used as coverage for more Spell/Trap disruption by bouncing that card to the hand, also has an effect that makes it so all your opponent's monsters lose 500 ATK and DEF if your LP is higher than theirs. • Aromage Laurel - A Level 1 Plant monster that's a good extender if you wanna go more heavy on the Aromage engine for more Synchro plays, since it has an effect that it can make a non-Tuner Plant monster a Tuner if you gain LP. It also makes you gain LP upon getting sent to the GY by any means. • Aroma Jar - A Marshmallon that makes you gain LP during the End Phase. Great for a more stall dedicated strategy. • Evil Thorn - Free Link 2 on board while burning your opponent, and more importantly, it Tributes for cost. • Advance Draw - Tribute either your Hellebore or Snowdrop; Draw 2 cards. It's not once per turn. • Share the Pain - A non-targeting, non-destruction removal, that also Tributes for cost. Bro... • Enemy Controller - A decent combat trick that allows you to either switch a monster's battle position, OR better yet, Tribute a monster for cost to take control of an opponent's monster until the End Phase, so long as it can be targeted. • Wall of Thorns - Mirror Force for Plants. • Spiritual Water Art - Aoi - This is unironically good with this deck, since most of our main deck monsters are WATER monsters, and the best part is as per usual, it's a Confiscation that Tributes for cost. • The utility Paleos (Olenoides, Dinomischus, & Canadia) - A MST, a Dark Core, and a Book of Moon, respectively. Also works with Spiritual Water Art - Aoi, funny enough. Honorable mentions are the usual staples such as Torrential Tribute, Bottomless Trap Hole, Forbidden Chalice, Lightning Vortex, and many more. Final thoughts This deck is actually fun to play. It does not require a lot of negates to interact with and disrupt your opponent. Even though it can easily be as aggressive as much as you want it to be at any point, it's also not hard to just go back into the defensive whenever something goes wrong, but since you're still utilizing some control cards, you still need to keep constant track of your resources. In fact, I've had so much fun playing this deck that I might actually build this in MD in the future and test more versions of Rikka as a more consistent and coherent strategy, because I just love building under explored and underestimated archetypes. But I gotta say, there will be awkward hands that won't be straightforward to play, so you just gotta be mindful of making plays with them. As per usual, if you have any questions or thoughts, feel free to express them down in the comments and I'll respond to them as soon as I possibly can.

Draft Deck 2

deck_excerpt: I'm still playtesting this. Read description for Master Duel version
deck_description:
There isn't much to say about this. I like Cyber Angels and Dogmatikas are strong. If you're new to Yu-Gi-Oh or you're a returning player, Cyber Angels are ritual monsters that don't rely on the extra deck, and we're combining them with an archetype that loves to send monsters to the graveyard directly from said extra deck. Here are some cards i want to highlight:
  • Manju of the Ten Thousand Hands: you can replace this dude with Diviner of the Herald if you got the money for it, but it does the job still fine
  • Ash Blossom & Joyous Spring: can be replaced with any handtrap you want
  • Borrelsword Dragon: budget Accesscode Talker
  • Dogmatika Maximus: this card is amazing, not only it sends your extra deck monsters to the grave to activate their effects, it also does the same with your opponent allowing you to take away resources from them
  • Five-Headed Dragon: it's just a Dogmatika Punishment target
  • PSY-Framelord Omega: once in the graveyard can shuffle back itself and another card, very helpful
Now for the Master Duel players, you obviously must take out White Relic of Dogmatika, Dogmatikamacabre and one Nadir Servant. You can replace them with another Called by the Grave and two more Cyber Angel Benten (curse you Drytron for bringing her to 1).

Consistent hand advantage and a more controlled gameplay! The deck name "Heresy" is from a youtuber named Hardleg Gaming and the build is inspired by several handful of other Witchcrafter+Dogmatika builds I was able to find online.  The deck utilizes the Witchcrafter Engine, mainly, and is heavily reliant on tributing themselves in order to search out their spell cards as well as summon each other with very little effort. Because they resolve off-field when tributing themselves you get to play with cards like Psy-Frame Gamma when your opponent attempts to stop any of your effects with Ash Blossom.  Because all of the Witchcrafter spells add themselves back into your hand this allows for you to also play cards like Different Dimension Reincarnation, Phoenix Wind Blast, and Paleozoic Dinomischus if you wish.     Highly recommended for players that aren't looking for anything hyper aggressive or spending ten minutes comboing off.     **EDIT: Removed one of my Charmers from ED that aren't as common of an element for an additional Titaniklad. That will let me send a copy to the grave while still having an extra for Albaz.

deck_excerpt: Gren Maju but with a gimmicky twist of an engine.
deck_description:
Well, it has certainly been a while (whole year if anything) since I uploaded stuff here. But best later than never I guess. So, back to the memes we go. Recently discovering the existence of Numbers Evaille from the recent article here, which completely flew over my radar, I had a thought on how to use it as an engine. Basically, Seven Sins turbo. And what deck loves banishing? Well you clicked on this so you know. This might just be my memiest (that a word?) deck this far, apart from the Gustkraken loops I keep to myself, so grab a seat and get comfy, cuz this is about to get real. Shout outs to Therarely and Alice_YGO for making me entertain the idea of creating this abomination. To explain the use of each card in the Deck:
  • Lord of the Heavenly Prison: Okay, this deck is more on the trap heavy side, so a beefy body while protecting your stuff doesn't hurt. Helps with otk and adds protection.
  • Gizmek Orochi: A staple in Gren Maju decks, this fella banishes to summon itself and it even has a neat effect on field. Only a fool would run less than 3. Great discard fodder for astraltopia but that is another story.
  • Dimension Shifter: Banish, banish and banish some more. Yeah it should be blindly obvious at this point.
  • Necroface: If gets to banish then gren become stronk. Simple as that. Can even recycle your extra deck from cards like prosperity if need be.
  • Astraltopia: The searcher for the engine. Unfortunately will use your NS but it is worth it. Discard Orochi if possible.
  • Gren Maju Da Eiza: The boi himself, the heart and soul of this deck. NS after banishing tons of cards and punch for game.
  • Eater of Millions: Banish for boi that removes by banishing. Need I explain why this is good?
  • Numbers Evaille: Use this to summon the Seven Sins. Useless going first and against decks like monarchs, but you can change your side deck accordingly. Make sure to summon Orochi first before activating.
  • Reinforcement of the Army: The searcher for the searcher, allowing essentially seven copies of Evaille.
  • Pot of Desires: You would play three if possible but I guess those days are past us. Draw power and banish, what more do you want?
  • Gold Sarcophagus: Banish Necroface, give chonk to Maju.
  • Pot of Prosperity: Banish your ED for add power, all in all great.
  • Storming Mirror Force: "Lol no" your opponent's monsters. With Heavenly Prison, this becomes quite threatening.
  • Torrential Tribute: Last ditch move. If you have only Orochi, not that much. And with macro cosmos this becomes even better.
  • Macro Cosmos: Steroids for the deck what else can I say?
  • Solemn Strike and Judgement: Negates for rubbing insult to injury or for when you don't manage to otk.
The Extra Deck doesn't need that much analysing cuz it boils down to Seven Sins turbo. Select everything else and voila. A 4-material nuke with protection and a big chonk. 3 nukes at best, none at worst. The side deck is moreso some S/T removal since the deck struggles with that and an alternative, more controllish engine with Harmonizer Gradielle for extra stalling until you stack up enough banished cards to finish your opponent in one blow. Aaaaand that is it! As always, hope you like the deck, this is moi signing out. And remember, memes are the DNA of the soul.

deck_excerpt: Budget blind going second Mekk-knights with an Orcust side deck
deck_description: This is a deck that I have been working on for a little bit now and am getting for myself. It is a blind going second Mekk-knight deck that has a side deck for boarding into going first with mainly an Orcust focus, the cost of this deck currently is about 220$, but it can be made for around 160$ if you replace 3 evenly matched with 3 Raigeki. I made this deck because I wanted a somewhat budget deck to play in the TCG after I found that I have a locals nearby. I have been playing Mekk-knights on master duel for about 2 months now, so I think this is the deck I would want to take to a locals. The other decks I play are a bit too complicated for me to play outside of a simulator or are much too expensive.  The side deck is to board out of all the going second cards for backrow and Scraps which act as Orcust starters. (manly board; Pankratops, 3 Evenly matched, 3 Dark ruler, 3 Gameciel, Mekk-knight red, Mekk-knight yellow, 1 Mekk-knight blue, 1 Mekk-knight indigo, and 1 World legacy memories, for everything in the side deck).  The main starters are Mekk-knight purple nightfall, Girsu and Mekk-knight blue sky. World legacy memories is a good starter if you are going second, but be careful as this card locks you into Mekk-knights, which will stop you from making Linkuriboh, Almiraj or summon World legacy tokens with Girsu's effect, which are used to create a column.

deck_excerpt: o famoso deck do mago negro como você nunca viu. the famous black mage deck as you've never seen it.
deck_description:
Sobre o Deck

Acredito que o deck de Mago Negro, é um dos Decks mais amados pela comunidade, porém também é um dos decks mais esquecidos e nerfados pela Konami. Onde a sua principal carta: “Dragoon Negro de Olhos Vermelhos”. Já foi banida no OCG e está para ser banida no TCG.  Nesse link  você encontra uma versão focada no Dragoon Negro de Olhos Vermelhos, que ainda não está banida no TCG.

Todavia os problemas (Isso PRECISA parar! O que Yu-Gi-Oh! se tornou?) do Yu-Gi-Oh, e principalmente do Master Duel, que são estes:  

  • Os Campos de negação infinita; 
  • Os combos de mais de 10 minutos; 
  • OTKs de um turno, como por exemplo: “DDD-Dinamite”;
  •  O fato de muitos decks te forçam a jogar no primeiro ou segundo turno. Esse deck te permite joga em qualquer turno.

Combo (DEMONSTRAÇÃO)

O principal combo desse deck, consiste em baixar para o campo 4 cartas e são estas: “Drenar Habilidades, Círculo Mágico Negro, Vila Secreta dos Magos, Mago Negro”, somente com essas cartas você bane cartas do oponente, nega os efeitos dos monstros e sela as magias do oponente: 
  • Vila Secreta dos Magos: Se somente você controlar um monstro Mago, seu oponente não pode ativar Cards de Magia. Se você não controlar nenhum monstro Mago, você não pode ativar Cards de Magia. 
  • Drenar Habilidades: Ative este card ao pagar 1000 PV. Negue os efeitos de todos os monstros com a face para cima enquanto eles estiverem com a face para cima no campo (mas seus efeitos ainda podem ser ativados).  UMA DAS PRINCIPAIS CARTAS DO DECK
  • Círculo Mágico Negro: Quando este card for ativado: olhe os 3 cards do topo do seu Deck e, depois, você pode revelar 1 deles que seja "Mago Negro" ou uma Magia/Armadilha que mencione "Mago Negro" e adicioná-lo à sua mão e, além disso, coloque os cards restantes no topo do seu Deck em qualquer ordem. Se "Mago Negro" for Invocado por Invocação-Normal ou Especial no seu campo (exceto durante a Etapa de Dano): você pode escolher 1 card que seu oponente controla; bana-o. Você só pode usar cada efeito de "Círculo Mágico Negro" uma vez por turno. 

Como invocar ou obter um Mago Negro

A principal forma de invocaram Mago Negro para o campo é utilizando a carta: “Alma Eterna”, você também pode utilizar a carta “Alma dos Magos” ou ainda uma “Maga da ilusão aprendiz” ou “bastão do mago” para trazer um Mago Negro para sua mão.  

Algumas Considerações

Fazendo o deck rodar (COMPRAR CARTAS)

Como já dito antes esse deck reside em baixar cartas específicas para o campo e para isso eu vejo uma necessidade, mesmo que contra minha vontade (Porque a carta esta BANIDA NO TCG), ter pelo menos 2 "C" Maxx no deck para tentar fazer o deck rodar mais rápido e ou parar o oponente. E o que já disse antes o deck de Mago Negro é bem abandonado pela Konami. Vale lembrar que você pode acabar utilizando a cartas como: “Alma Eterna”, “Alma dos Magos”, “Maga da ilusão aprendiz”, “bastão do mago,  Salvação do Mago  ou Servo da Alma.” Para trazer as cartas necessárias para sua mão. Porém elas estão suscetíveis a "hand traps ou counters traps".

Sobre o extra Deck

Como já dito antes esse deck um dos objetivos desse deck é combater OTKs de um turno como por exemplo: “DDD-Dinamite, e para isso é necessário que o deck tenha no máximo 13 cartas mas o ideal mesmo são 11. e esse deck se encaixa perfeitamente nisso. visto que muita das vezes você só vai utilizar eles para ter monstros fortes em campo, já que seus efeitos geralmente vão estar negados pela carta Drenar Habilidade. Mas aqui estão as que não podem faltar (LEIA OS EFEITOS):
  • Predaplant Verte Anaconda: para combar com a Fusão Marginalizada e assim invocar o Mago Quinteto.
  • Os Magos Negros, Mago das Trevas, o Cavaleiro do Dragão, Mago de Ilusão de Ébano,

Fraqueza do Deck

A maior fraqueza desse deck além de um possível "break" e não conseguir finalizar o combo, que vai te permitir selar os efeitos de monstros e magias do adversário. São duas
  • Cartas como "Confronto Justo": No final da Fase de Batalha, se seu oponente controlar mais cards que você: você pode fazer com que seu oponente bana cards do campo dele, com a face para baixo, até que ele controle o mesmo número de cards que você. Se você não controlar nenhum card, você pode ativar este card da sua mão.
  • E a própria Alma Eterna, primeiro pelo fato de ser uma armadilha (NA MINHA VISÃO ELA DEVIA SER UMA MAGIA), pois primeiro vai ter que ser baixada, pra dai depois ser ativada no próximo turno, e depois pelo seu efeito:  "Se este card com a face para cima deixar o campo: destrua todos os monstros que você controla". (EU ACHO ESSE EFEITO JUSTO, MAS SER UMA ARMADILHA ATRASA)
OBS: Você pode usar o Mago das Trevas, o Cavaleiro do Dragão, pra proteger, a Alma Eterna e o Círculo Mágico Negro mas geralmente ele vai ter esse efeito negado pela Drenar Habilidade.

deck_excerpt: Unchained helped out by a Scrap Engine. Raptor helps get easy links
deck_description:
This deck has been so much fun for me in Gold and Platinum ladder recently. After testing out a Rokket Engine and a Metalfoes engine I landed on Scraps which have been the most profitable with working with the xenolocking of Unchained.
  • You only get locked into Fiend types if you use the effects of the Unchained Twins Aruha and Rakea. So Sarama is a great card if you have a way to dump one of the other twins from your deck/hand right away.
  • Scrap Raptor can give you super easy access to Wyvern or 1 of the synchros. (Personal favorite of mine is using Scrap Twin Dragon to destroy one of my small Unchained or one of the set Spell/Traps, just for a double bounce of 2 cards.
  • The Spell lineup can be mildly cloggly, so the ratios can be altered pretty easily.
  • If you are able to end your combos on the xenolocking small Twins you only have to worry if you dont need to go into Accesscode Talker in that moment.

deck_excerpt: New competitive format for TCG/OCG tournaments. You seen the HERO OTK, now get ready for the MAGICIANS!
deck_description: DM OTK strategy:  1. Activate the card Salvation, then set Eternal from your deck.  2. Activate Circle to add 1 DM or any spell/trap (Navigation or Servant) that mentions it in its text.  3. Summon Rod to add either Navigation or Servant to your hand (different from the other you added with Circle).  4. Activate Branded Fusion to summon Lubellion, then use Lubellion to discard either Navigation or Servant to summon DMtDK.  5. Use Souls to dump DMG the GY to summon itself, then use Souls effect to draw 2 cards (by sending 1 spell/trap from your hand and Salvation to the GY).  6. If you brick, use Illusions effect to add Timaeus to your hand, then return 1 card. Now tribute Souls to summon Timaeus.  7. Activate Servant to search DM, then draw 2 cards (since you got DMtDK on the field and DMG in the GY). Now use Timaeus effect to summon Dragoon for your endboard.  8. Now your endboard is unbreakable board with Eternal & DMtDK, banish ready with Circle, and negate ready with at least two Navs in the GY and one Dragoon on the field.

deck_name: Master Duel Insect Deck Legacy Pack Cards Only!
deck_excerpt: This is a fun insect deck that has OTK potential as well as some iconic cards like Man-Eater Bug whilst remaining consitent enough with the limited ca
deck_description: Use Giant Ball Park to stop potential damage you might take and to also special summon 3 of your Normal Monsters from your deck. With these monsters you can then link off into traffic ghost and then if you have two more effect monsters you can summon Codebreaker Virus Swordsman (make sure you summon Virus Swordsman directly beneath traffic ghost) who will summon Codebreaker Zero-Day, with these you can then link off into Virus Berserker who will re-summon your two codebreakers whilst being able to destroy up to two spells and traps. Then with the two codebreakers you have just summoned, you want to use Traffic Ghost and Zero-Day to make a Rasterliger which can gain attack equal to a link monsters attack that's in either player's graveyard. So for example if your opponent has a Tri-Brigade Shuraig in their grave, you can then make Rasterliger gain 3000ATK making it have 5000ATK, meaning by the end of your turn you could have up to over 10000 damage on your field giving you more than enough to OTK your opponent.  Use cards like Dust Knight to put Gokipole in the grave to add a normal insect which you can then special summon and destroy a monster  Use Giant Rat to special summon any monster you might need with 1500ATK or less  Use Baobaboon to fix your hand so you have the cards you need (it's also a great way to put Codebreaker Zero Day on the bottom of your deck to stop you from bricking as you want it in your deck) and to also have multiple effect monsters on the field to help with your link summons  If you wanted to replace any cards then you could replace or even remove cards Like:Doom Dozer which can be replaced with something like Super Armored Robot Armed Black Iron "C", you can replace Man-Eater Bug with one of the Swarm Flip Monsters, you can replace Gigantes with Aztekipede, the Worm Warrior and then the back row can be anything you want as well as the XYZ monsters used in the Deck.

deck_name: Red Dragon Archfiends - Master Duel (Off-Meta) - March 2022
deck_excerpt: RDA Deck for Master Duel - Off-Meta Synchro Spam Shenanigans
deck_description: My final iteration of my Red Dragon Archfiend deck.  My personal favorite deck of all time. I've used Junk Stardust, Pend Magician / Z-ARC, Galaxy-Eyes, Elemental Heroes, Utopia, and Slime / God Card decks, and nothing so far tops this one in terms of fun for me. The combos are pretty simple and mostly revolve around getting Crimson Resonator out so you can get Supernova out on turn 1. Summon Crimson as the first monster so you can special summon it, and summon whatever Level 4 you have (preferably Wildwind so you still have a normal summon, but any of em work), go into Red Rising Dragon, use its effect, summon 2 more Resonators and go into Supernova. I'd recommend summoning Mirror Resonator and Creation Resonator so you can use Mirror Resonators effect in the future, or use it for plays with Chaos Ruler or Red Risings second effect. If Crimson gets negated, that's fine too, just go into Chaos Ruler and excavate the top 5 cards, and hopefully, that'll give you a counter play if you don't have a potential one in your hand already.  The main Extra Deck priorities are Red Rising, Chaos Ruler, Abyss, and Supernova. Red Rising is what allows most of the plays in the deck. Abyss is a once-per-turn Quick Effect negate and can summon more Resonators. Supernova can banish the opponents' entire field should they use a monster effect, and if they negate that, it still has a ton of ATK, getting 500 for each Resonator in the GY (which is a lot if you use combos correctly). Other cards, such as Samsara or Ancient Pixie, are there to fill space in case you don't get levels matching up to 6 or 8 with monsters you have in your hand (for example, if you only have Creation and Wildwind). Samsara is a good general defensive option, and Ancient Pixie has some very rare potential should you have Tilted Try up on the field. If you don't want to use Ancient Pixie, replace it with Exploder Dragonwing. Honestly, you could replace stuff like Galaxy Cyclone or Tilted Try with more meta cards, like Solemn Judgement / Called by the Grave / Forbidden Droplet, I just like using them because Skull Meister can function as a searchable but slightly weaker version of Called by the Grave, and I have a Royal Tilted Try (and it gives Ancient Pixie actual functionality), so I just like running it.  The main deck mostly consists of Resonators (Tuners) and 4* cards with search potential (WotBF, Wildwind, Stygian Street Patrol). Ascator is there in case you get a brick hand and only have him, so you can go into Chaos Ruler and potentially make a comeback. Ash Blossom and Maxx C are there just as basic hand traps. Red Reign is useful should you only have one Synchro on the field, or if you want to use it mid-turn before you start summoning other cards. Chain and Mirror are mostly there for low-level Resonator spam and for Chaos Ruler plays.  For an example of gameplay: https://youtu.be/0Yh9rMZ4hxA
