deck_excerpt: A característica assinatura dos monstros "Ancient Gear" é impedir a ativação de cards de Magia/Armadilha durante seu ataque.
deck_description:
"Mecanismo Antigo", conhecido como "Antique Gear" (Yu-Gi-Oh! GX, Rudolph Heitmann em Yu-Gi-Oh! 5D's e pessoal da Academia de Duelos, como Yuri, Dennis McField, Jean-Michel Roget e os membros da Força Obelisco, em Yu-Gi-Oh! ARC-V). Todos os membros deste arquétipo são monstros da TERRA, exceto o "Gigante do Mecanismo Antigo do Caos".

Os decks "Ancient Gear" se concentram em invocações de tributo ou invocações de fusão. A característica assinatura dos monstros "Ancient Gear" é impedir a ativação de cards de Magia/Armadilha durante seu ataque. Isso permite que monstros "Ancient Gear" ataquem sem medo de serem parados por quaisquer cards de Magia/Armadilha. Devido à prevalência de efeitos monstruosos que podem ser ativados durante a Batalha, monstros mais novos também impedem sua ativação.

(Eles não são imunes a cards de Magia/Armadilha, no entanto).

Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

List of video games
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles action figures
List of characters
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles is an entertainment franchise created by American comic book authors Kevin Eastman and Peter Laird. It follows Leonardo, Raphael, Donatello and Michelangelo, four anthropomorphic turtle brothers trained in ninjitsu who fight evil in New York City. Eastman and Laird conceived the characters as a parody of elements popular in superhero comics at the time. In 1984, they founded Mirage Studios and self-published the first issue of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles; it was a surprise success. They licensed the characters to Playmates Toys, who developed a line of Turtles action figures. About $1.1 billion USD of Turtles toys were sold between 1988 and 1992, making them the third-bestselling toy figures ever at the time. The action figures were promoted with an animated series, which premiered in 1987 and ran for almost a decade. In some European regions, the word "ninja" in the name was replaced with "hero" for its violent connotations. Three live-action films were released in the 1990s; the first film became the highest-grossing independent film up to that point. In 2009, the franchise was purchased by Viacom, now Paramount Global. Viacom commissioned a new comic series, two new live-action films, and new animated series.

deck_excerpt: Guide to the main combo of the deck included
deck_description: I spent a little to get myself an appliancer deck and then walked into ranked on platinum with it to see how well it goes. Surprisingly it was actually pretty nuts.  This build is engineered to be essentially a blind second otk deck using accesscode and unchained abomination, the deck is pretty nuts in action.  The combo for accescode and abomination (socketroll/copybokle and electlyrical world):  Activate world  grab socket or copy (whichever you don’t have)  summon socket  copy socket  summon third socket with the original sockets effect  link for cell  recycle socket  socket effect  link one of the non link appliancers for kappa  kappa revive the other appliancer  link soket and the other appliancer for virus swordsman  Summon zero day  link for berserker using the codebreaker stuff you have  beserker effect summon the other stuff  pop spells and traps if any  link cell with swordsman for abomination  link berserker and zero day for accesscode  pop and attack for game.     If you run into me on Master Duel my tag is Crysgoyle (I liked the idea of a crystal gargoyle, and amorphage is apparently an illegal name due to words or something)  My ID is 495-405-702  if you want to find me  Have a good one!

deck_name: MasterDuel N/R Tier 1 Gadget Machine Toolbox
deck_excerpt: Basically number XYZ spam featuring some of the strongest cards in the format.  This list is similar to others, but cuts somewhat unnecessary cards fo
deck_description: Use Gadgets and Infinitrack cards to maintain tempo and set up extremely powerful XYZ monsters.  Ideal hands will end on a mixture of Draglubion, Heart-Earth Dragon, and Seven Sins backed up with the omni-negate of Numbers Protection.  Even in unideal hands, you can end on strong staples like Virus Swordsman or Malevolent Sin.  Landing any Number card will enable Numbers Protection.  This is especially notable when you consider that people often save trap staples like Torrential or Compulse for when you commit to an XYZ, at which point you can activate a set Numbers Protection and negate.  One important feature of this list is that it is only running one Chaos Heart-Earth.  Since Draglubion can attach a material from the GY, this frees up a space in the extra deck for cards that can help you in a pinch, like the extra copy of Malevolent Sin or the Berserker of the Tenyi.  I have also chosen to exclude the rank 7 Infinitrack as it never seemed to be useful in testing.

Handtraps: Play enough handtraps to stop your opponent from building a board, do not play board breaking cards like droplet etc. because that it worse than playing more cards to stop the opponent to build his board.

deck_excerpt: A Mix of Elemental Heroes, Vision Heroes, Destiny Heroes cards with great support cards to search for them and support cards to help you negate your o
deck_description: I explain each card effect in the above video and how to build combo attacks using them no matter what hand you draw. This Deck is fun to play and battle your opponent's strongest decks.  This Deck comprises Elemental Heroes, Vision Heroes, and Destiny Heroes. The main objective is to summon your Elemental and Destiny Fusion Monsters for the strongest effects and High Attack power.  The only weakness this Deck has is against negate cards since Heroes by themselves don't have to negate effects, and very few of them have counter to monster negation tactics. Still, this is a good competitive deck against decks in the Silver and Gold ranking.  I also added a few support cards if you plan on using Destiny Hero Plasma which is a great card to play when going first as he negates your opponent's monster effects, and with D - Force, he is an unstoppable beast.

deck_excerpt: This is my hero deck. Its pretty good and I won a local tournament with it a few weeks ago. If you think it could be better tell me i would love to im
deck_description: This is a hero deck I spent a year working on. I've only gotten a hand that I couldn't play once. Even with that hand I could negate them from doing anything.  With this deck you could get a bad hand and still do something to help you win. The best board I've was able to make would and the  best board for this deck would be with Destiny HERO - Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer, Masked HERO Dark Law, Evil HERO Malicious Bane you can do so much to win and if you can also add Vision HERO Trinity to that board that's game every time. Because Masked HERO Dark Law get them away from graveyard effects and just messes with there graveyard in general and, with Destiny HERO - Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer send it to the gave plus an opponent card you can do some major damage to your opponent. Then when you add Evil HERO Malicious Bane You can destroy all monsters your opponent controls with ATK less than or equal to Evil HERO Malicious Bane, also it gains 200 ATK for each monster destroyed that way. plus if you can get Vision HERO Trinity out whos ATK doubles making it 5,000 ATK. If you don't have / cant afford Destiny HERO - Destroyer Phoenix Enforcer or Elemental HERO Liquid Soldier then you will want to get Destiny HERO - Dangerous and two Effect Veiler and only one The Warrior Returning Alive that will keep the deck at the same amount of cards and give you another hand trap This deck can always do something to help even when it doesn't look like the best hand in the world. Defiantly give it a try and if you know a good way to improve on it let me know im always down to make my hero deck better.

deck_excerpt: Strong Rogue Pick for N/R Format
deck_description: https://youtu.be/7H7gUbYp_Ak

FTK  combo:  save the normal summon for dogra  summon batosbuster  summon halqifibrax  ->  summon synchro magnet  summon cupid pitch  ->  decrease to level 1  summon benten / idaten  summon tool dragon  ->  (search dogra via cupid pitch and charging cell via tool dragon)  summon reprodocus  summon dogra below reprodocus  make dogra psychic with reprodocus and equip charging cell  now dogra can be used infinitely  arc light, omega and reprodocus in extra deck means infinite field / GY recycling and infinite ritual monster / spell searches  batosbuster is a 2k machine and can be used as tribute to summon idaten / benten / och / ophiel  benten + idaten = m7 which can be used as tribute to summon batosbuster  that means any ritual mosnter can be summoned infinitely  summon scarlight with batosbuster and och / ophiel  summon other 4 monsters  use scarlight to burn for 2k  rinse and repeat     I never played drytron before so I'm sure the deck list can be improved.

deck_excerpt: What i think to be one of the best ice barrier decks out there, if not a good starting basis to get your very own ice barrier deck started! Good amou
deck_description: This is the ice barrier deck i have been playing for a while, Theory crafted over a few months The general strat is to get the stealth kragen out turn one using the revealer, Speaker, silent sea nettle and in a pinch you could use the deep sea city effect on a tuner or prior of the ice barrier. or if you get really lucky you can get out the crystal wing synchro dragon turn one, with usually a surface, hexa spirit and either a silent sea nettle or speaker. using the effect of hexa, making it level 3 then summoning gungnir, mid combo you can use its effect to destroy before getting out the crystal wing synchro dragon. I have found alot of success using the stealth kragen to prevent combos from being played and if that manages to get through you always have the ice barrier trap card as well as the torrential tribute and fury of kairu-shin to help out too. trishula you can get out any time with minimal combo of just using revealer, speaker and the effect of revealer to get speaker out. although it is possible with general wayne too you have a solid removal tool in santa claws as a smaller kaiju, now it does draw on end phase so best to remove. Kaijus i found are too high atk for any of our cards to do much, but it is well enough to be slapped down to prevent the effect! this deck is about recycling the cards used in the graveyard, so don't be scared to discard a few, as most turns you can get everything back out of the grave for what you used to synchro summon!  Side note, you don't always have to synchro summon, you can just keep defender of the ice barrier out as well as another ice barrier card to prevent them from attacking, especially if it is something scary!  Enjoy this deck, the ice barrier aren't as bad as everyone seems to think, with strong control and lock down.

deck_excerpt: Flood the field with Danger! and Dark World monsters. Churn through the deck and make Link-4s without even ever normal summoning.
deck_description: "oh it's 50 cards" shadup... this lets me run more bricks Gates of Dark World over Allure since barricadeborg blocker can tutor it, Dragged Down to The Grave over Dark World Dealings since if you're not stupid you can just set the stuff you don't want them to discard. It's also way more chad and a major flavor win with Called by the Grave  Can probably use more handtraps, this deck is pretty all-in on the combo. Again, 50 cards to maintain density of stuff you want to discard but also not just fold to any sort of interaction. Imperm is the handtrap of choice because you can "hide" it from your discard by setting it. You could argue for more, but this deck doesn't really need Halqi lines  Crossout Designator exclusively for Droll and Lockbird, that card shuts this deck down instantly, but I'm sure you can find other cards to use with Crossout. Prohibition is there for a similar reason, but it's just another thing to find with Barricade Blocker if you think the game is going to go that long.  I considered two Apollousa since this deck makes her extremely easily but ultimately decided Abyss Dweller is way better.  Number 46 because I'm poor and don't want to buy something more expensive than that for the Numeron engine, you can probably run something you can actually go into.  I considered number 68 but ultimately decided I wanted powercode talker. He's fantastic with accesscode and isn't terrible on his own either (although he's mostly a link climber and food for accesscode)  As with any deck, season to taste, this probably isn't the best build of this deck, but it's my take on it.

deck_excerpt: Generic Banish deck with some Dangers and Clashing Souls
deck_description: Core Strategy Get to Soul Absorption (multiple copies stack) with draw power cards and Danger monsters Once Soul Absorption is on field start using the multi-banish cards -Eater of Millions: up to 15 from extra deck, you choose (leave one of the Shinranui's if you have Link Apple, or a rank 8 if you think you'll need it) -Pot of Desires: Banish 10 from top of deck -Gizmek Orochi: Banish 8 from top of deck -Soul Release: Banish 5 from either GY -Link Apple: Banish 1 at random from extra deck -Allure of Darkness: Banish 1 from hand Proceed to summon monsters to either stall or beat over for game -Gren Maji Da Eiza: beatstick gets bigger with your banished cards -Rank 8s: made with Dangers or Gizmek Orochi -Eater of Millions: once per turn battle stall -Any monster equipped with Moon Mirror Shield: perpetual battle stall Clashing Souls abuse Activates during damage calculation, the player whose monster is destroyed in that battle has their whole field sent to grave -If you have been using Soul Release you have enough LP to outpay your opponent to make your monster bigger with the effect of Clashing Souls -If you are battling with a monster that has moon mirror shield equipped you monster will be bigger no matter what -large ATK monsters can make the LP cost too high for the opponent to pay

deck_excerpt: A fairly competent going second deck that's able to deal lots of damage really quickly and OTK your opponent.
deck_description:
So I used this deck for Season 3 of Ranked Duels in Master Duel and made Platinum 3. It's a fairly competent going second deck that can break through an opponent's first turn board and deal lethal damage on your first turn. The whole goal is to use your going second cards to pick the opponents field apart, summon Raviel or Hamon with the Sacred Beast engine, and use the Dangers to swarm the field and deal 8000 damage on your turn. Now this is a going second deck, so in an ideal world you'll go second every time. I'll go over each card and some main combos and what to do if you're ever made to go first. Also your notice the small 10 card extra deck, this is exactly here to counter the Banquet Of Millions OTK whenever people get off that deck feel free to bring it up to 15 with whatever generic Links you like.

The Main Deck:

Chaos Summoning Beast - This card is how you get the Sacred Beasts out simple as that, this card is pretty easy to find and activate since it's effect tributes itself. Though it is very susceptible to Called By The Grave so keep that in mind. You can also banish this card from the graveyard to add Fallen Paradise to your hand, so this card is very important. Luckily it's super easy to search with the Sacred Beast cards. Finally do keep in mind this card's effects are all on a hard once per turn so if it get's negated, that's it. Dark Beckoning Beast - This card finds whatever you need for your Sacred Beast combos, it's a great searcher and allows you to normal summon Chaos Summoning Beast once you have everything you need. Like with Chaos Summoning Beast this card is a hard once per turn and is pretty susceptible to interruption so keep that in mind. Dark Summoning Beast - This card isn't super special, you can banish it from the graveyard to search a Sacred Beast and it can tribute itself to summon a Sacred Beast from your hand or the deck, but then you can't attack. It's really just useful for it's search effect or the rare occasion where you have to go first. Raviel, Lord Of Phantasms - Your preferred win condition, you cheat it out with Chaos Summoning Beast and it hits really hard. It has an handy effect where you can tribute a monster you control to increase it's attack by that monsters original attack which helps you push for lethal. It also allows you to special summon a token when your opponent normal summons, but that rarely comes up. Also this monster has no inherent protection, so try not to have it on the field without Fallen Paradise as well or it won't last too long. Hamon, Lord Of Striking Thunder - The back-up plan, you also cheat this card out like Raviel. It is able to burn your opponent for 1000 damage if it destroys a monster and sends it to the grave and that can help push for game. But usually Raviel is better at that. However, Hamon is good if your being made to go first and you can stick it on the field in defense with Fallen Paradise up. Then your opponent has to find a way to overcome it's 4000 defense with Fallen Paradise's protection since when this card is in defense your opponent can only target it with attacks. Also same as Raviel this it is very vulnerable without Fallen Paradise. Danger!? Jackalope? - Pretty much all the Dangers are here for the same reason, they easily swarm the field for link plays and help you cycle through your deck quickly to find what you need. Jackalope's discard effect is really good with Raviel as you can summon Bigfoot or Thunderbird off it and turn the defense position Danger into attack points for Raviel. Danger!? Tuschinoko? - Tuschinoko probably has the weakest discard effect besides Thunderbird but it still does guarantee a body for a link play or extra damage so it's better than nothing. Danger! Nessie! - The searcher of the Dangers find whichever one you need in the situation you find yourself in. Danger! Thunderbird! - Probably the weakest discard effect unless your facing exactly Eldlich then it can help clear out their backrow or force them to activate it prematurely. Other than that it's a big body to tribute for Raviel. Danger! Bigfoot - Definitely the Danger you want to see the most, a big body for closing out games and a pretty good effect on discard. Popping a face up card is always nice. Kaijus -Not going to give each Kaiju their own entry they all have the same purpose. They're here to blow up the opponent's board with Interrupted Kaiju slumber or get annoying boss monsters off your opponents field on their own. They also all have big bodies for Raviel's effect. Keep in mind there are only 4 in the deck so you don't really want to draw too many or search them off of slumber's effect or you'll turn slumber off. Maxx "C" - The necessary evil of Master Duel right now. It's the only hand trap I play in the deck and I shouldn't need to say why. Make your opponent chose between giving you a bunch of cards and you blow them out or ending their turn early and you blow them out. I hope this card get's banned soon, and once it's done I'd probably replace it with Ash Blossom. Fallen Paradise - This field spell is crazy. Gives all the Sacred Beast targeting and destruction protection limiting your opponents options to get rid of them. Then once per turn if you control a Sacred Beast you can just draw 2 Cards, which will definitely help you OTK your opponent. Opening Of The Spirit Gates - This is a searcher just like Dark Beckoning Beast, lets you find whatever Sacred Beast combo piece you need when you activate it. However it has some other neat effects. You can discard a card to special summon a 0 attack fiend from the graveyard, combos really well with Chaos and Dark Summon Beasts. Then if you control a Sacred Beast you can add a continuous spell from the graveyard to the hand, which really only let's you recycle other copies of it and rarely comes up. Allure Of Darkness - Let's you draw cards and you play lots of dark monsters. Pretty good card in this deck. Interrupted Kaiju Slumber - Dark Hole that let's you get a Kaiju on both your field and your opponents. Always give them Gameciel. You can also banish it from the graveyard to search a Kaiju, but you can't do that the turn you use this card so it rarely comes up. Lightning Storm - Great going second card for blowing up all your opponent's monsters or their backrow, whichever is going to be a problem. Pretty self explanatory choice. Forbidden Droplet - This is a newer card in the deck, but it's really here because of exactly Rhongomyniad. Otherwise it's just helpful for negating really annoying monster effects, halving attack points, and setting up your graveyard.

The Extra Deck:

Linkuriboh - It's basically here to let you send Chaos Summoing Beast to the graveyard for whatever reason. Otherwise it's on field effect can be useful in you find yourself in a pinch. Salamangreat Almiraj - An easy way to send Dark Beckoning Beast to the Graveyard, with a decent on field effect as well. Knightmare Cerberus - Let's you pick off special summoned monsters in your opponent's main monster zone. Knightmare Phoenix - Let's you pick off spell and traps. I:P Masquerena - This card is really for when you're going first or your opponent stopped your Sacred Beast plays. Set it up with enough Material to make an Accesscode on your opponents turn and hope for the best. Barricadeborg Blocker - Let's your recycle Spirit Gates or Fallen Paradise if they get destroyed. Curious, The Lightsworn Dominion - This card helps you when you get a really bad starting hand. Let's you just mill whatever you need to the grave. Get a Chaos Summoning Beast so you can summon it with Gates, or banish to find Fallen Paradise. Or send Dark Summoning to find a Sacred Beast. Just hope you don't get unlucky with the random mills. Knightmare Unicorn - Just get rid of one of anything your opponent has you don't like. And a great card to make Accesscode with. Accesscode Talker - If all else fails this card can win games by itself and it's really easy to make with all the swarming potential you have. Gives it self a big attack boost and can pop cards on the opponent's field. This is definitely Plan C but sometimes you get put in a position where this is your only win condition. Underworld Goddess Of The Closed World - A good card for stealing cards on your opponents field, a bit harder to use than a Kaiju but can definitely catch opponents off guard. And it's on field effects can win you games against certain decks.

The Ideal Starting Hand:

In a perfect world you always go second and you want to open like this. At least 1 of either of Dark Beckoning or Spirit Gates, At least one of Chaos Summoning, Dark Summoning, or a Sacred Beast. And some Dangers or other cards to break your opponent's board. Let's go over some combos: Let's say your starting hand is: Dark Beckoning Chaos Summoning Bigfoot Kaiju Slumber Jackalope Maxx "C" Once your turn comes probably start with Kaiju Slumber to wipe the board and get some Kaijus on the field.  Summon Dark Beckoning and search Spirit Gates. Activate Spirit Gates and search your preferred Sacred Beast. Then use Dark Beckoning's effect to summon Chaos Summoning. Then banish from the graveyard Chaos Summoning to search Fallen Paradise. Activate Fallen Paradise and draw 2 cards then just use your Dangers to amass enough presence and make links you want to win the game. Now let's say your starting hand is: Dark Beckoning Tuschinoko Bigfoot Kaiju Slumber Jackalope Maxx "C" Just Dark Beckoning isn't ideal but with Curious you can still go full combo. Summon Beckoning to find Spirit Gates and use Spirit Gates to find a Sacred Beast. Then use your Dangers to get enough Material for Curious and mill Chaos summoning to the Graveyard. Then you can use Spirit Gates to discard a card from your hand to get Chaos Summoning on the field and summon a Sacred Beast, then banish it for Fallen Paradise and push for game. These Scenarios assume you never used your Maxx "C" but this is just some of the combos you can do in the deck. I definitely recommend just playing some games with the deck, there's a lot of combos you can do to win the game really quickly.

Going First:

If your opponent makes you go first then it's time to cry lol, but in all seriousness this deck isn't great going first. The best you can really do is try and stick Hamon in defense with Fallen Paradise up and/or I:P with enough material for an Accesscode or Unicorn. There's just not many options for a strong board going first so avoid it if at all possible.

Conclusion:

Well that's the deck, I'd love any advice or tweaks I could make to it and I'm completely open to answering any questions you might have about the deck. You can follow me on Twitch at: https://www.twitch.tv/sirzero14 to see me play this and other decks in my arsenal.
None

deck_name: Festival Master Duel N/R,    Banish Psychics deck
deck_description: https://youtu.be/zWjT06KamHI

Hello everybody, while you are wondering which deck to play, i strongly recommend this Metalfoes deck. Let's go to some analysis: Strengths
  • Heavymetalfoes Electrumite is there to use. It is simply a card that can help you to quickly activate Astrograph Sorcerer effect, which means that you can add 1 card that was destroyed that turn. Moreover, you can get to draw another card. Especially, except for the draw effect of Electrumite, the others are not once per turn. You can simply recycle it with the support of Metalfoes Mithrilium
  • Metalfoes Alkahest can steal one effect monster (they will be frustrated lol)
  • The effect of Metalfoes monster in your main deck can help you search all  Metalfoes spells and traps easily, and you will have more chance to fusion summon
  • Endymion and Mythical Beasts monsters can help Magicians' soul activate its effect
  • Magical Abductor can help you search Magician's Soul or any pendulum monsters providing you can provide enough Spell counter for her
  • Magicians' Soul can help you draw card(s) when you are brick, or you can send Metalfoes Combination and Metalfoes Fusion to get some card advantages
  • Super Polymerization can shut down your opponent's combo easily lol...
Weaknesses
  • Too dependent on starting hand
  • If you cannot summon Heavymetalfoes Electrumite... Game over
  • The average atk of this deck is not so good (main dmg from the piercing effect of Metalfoes Orichalc and Accesscode Talker)
Summary You need to have practice to master a deck, and this deck will take you lots of time to do that because the combos depend on your hand and your thinking way. Thanks for spending time reading and having a look at my deck. I welcome all suggestions from you guys.

deck_excerpt: After trying different numerom decks, this is the best one.
deck_description:
You always want to go second with numeron decks. The strategie is simple; first you summon numeron network on the filed, you can search this card with( numeron wall, planet pathfinder and terraforming) then special summon 4 numeron monsters from your extra deck. Then use memories of hope( if you have it in  your hand) to draw 4 cards.  Attack your opponent monster and you won. If your opponent is somehow still alive, summon one link monster( you can choose any link monsters depending on your situation) and end your turn. The best link monster to summon in most situation is

Apollousa, Bow of the Goddess (  you can negate your opponent monsters effect 4 times.)

You can easily destroyed you opponent board  and get rid of their boss monsters with the kaijus, raigeki, lightning storm and harpie's feather. You also have other cards like ash and infinite impermanence to interrupt your opponent plays. Also magical mallet for consistency. card destruction you use it when your opponents has too many cards in their hand.   Now when your opponent decided to go second. It the same procedure  as when you go second, you summon 4 numeron then you summon apollousa and negate your opponent monsters effect.

deck_excerpt: 60-card Small Adventurer Enforcer Prank-Kids / Indiana WCQ Regional Top 4
deck_description: Category: Tournament Meta Deck  Tournament Meta Decks are current-level Meta Decks that are capable of going up against the best of the best. These are curated lists that cannot be uploaded by regular users.  Creator: Joseph Francis Dietrich Tournament: Indiana WCQ Regional - March 26th 2022 Placement: Top 4

A few tips:
  • Always try to activate Exosister Vadis when your opp goes to move something from GY to hand/deck/field/remove from play.
  • Exosister Kaspitell/ZS - Utopic Sage can make a easy Number F0 - Utopic Future->Number F0: Utopic Draco Future.
  • If your stuck with Exosister Stella and Exosister Elis: Always try to bait out a negate with Exosister Stella first as if those are the only two you have you wont be able to get both activations of +800LP.
  • If your building this: you can pick any 3 of the Familiar's (Jigabyte/Nefarius/Ranryu/Inari) Just make sure you play 1 of each due to them only being able to have 1 of themselves on the field.
Combo for Draco Future: Requires: ZS-Ascended sage + Any Exosister + Familiar/Exosister Pax/Exosister Elis
  1. Special ZS-Ascended Sage.
  2. Normal summon any Exosister.
  3. Activate Exosister Pax search Exosister Elis [Note: Using Exosister Stella's effect may draw out a negate. Best to try Exosister Elis]
  4. Special summon Exosister Elis.
  5. Using ZS-Ascended sage and either Exosister XYZ summon ZS-Utopic Sage.
  6. Search your deck for Hyper Rank-Up-Magic Utopiforce using ZS-Ascended Sage. (Mostly to remove a possible dead draw)
  7. Activate ZS-Utopic Sage to special summon ZS-Ascended Sage from deck.
  8. Use the second ZS-Ascended Sage and the second Exosister to XYZ summon Kaspitell[If you want a Exosister monster search] or better yet Exosister Mikailis to banish one of your opponents cards from field or GY and a Exosister Spell/Trap search.
  9. Activate your Exosister Mikalis and search a Exosister Spell/Trap.[Generally you want Exosister Vadis to threaten opp turn/set up for next turn]
  10. XYZ summon Number F0: Utopic Future using ZS-Utopic Sage and Exosister Mikailis/Kaspitell.

To do this I usually get Phul onto the field with Meteonis Drytron and a level 4 Megalith, then use Phul's ability to summon Phaleg from the Hand/Deck. I also recommend having at least 1 Drytron in your hand so you can recycle Metenois for more Ritual Summons.

deck_excerpt: Beast-Type beatdown Starter Deck concept, not meant to be optimal, just meant for casual or sealed play
deck_description: Beatdown your opponents by summoning strong Beast-Type monsters like Berserk Gorilla and Ape Fighter. If you're backed into a corner then the triple threat of Green Baboon, Yellow Baboon, and Crimson Ape can help, and for the real bomb you have Master of Oz with its massive 4200 ATK stat. The Spells and Traps are also all about beefing up your Beasts and damaging your opponent as fast as possible.  This deck is just meant to feel like a Starter deck, it isn't meant to be good, but hopefully it's fun in casual or sealed sort of setting

deck_excerpt: An EARTH Attribute deck focused on using non-effect monsters and possibly hindering the opponent's effect monsters.
deck_description: Use powerful EARTH Attribute monsters to rundown your opponent, they may not have effects but they have high ATK! Use Skill Drain or Lose 1 Turn to hinder opposing effect monsters, or possibly activate Tyrant's Throes to ruin their entire deck! Support your Normal Monsters with things like Unexpected Dai and Justi-Break, then use them to Summon strong Extra Deck monsters like Gem-Knight Zirconia and Scrap Archfiend! Defender of the Labyrinth can even revive them later if they get destroyed!

Start a strong offense with Warrior monsters, powered up by Comrade Swordsman of Landstar and Ferocious Flame Swordsman, then use the effects of Gearfried the Red-Eyes Iron Knight and Red-Eyes Slash Dragon to take advantage of your many Equip cards and overwhelm your opponent! If things get real tough you can bet it all on Time Wizard, or try to hold out until you can Ritual Summon the very powerful Lord of the Red!

deck_excerpt: A solid Structure deck with a couple ways to play it if you know the cards
deck_description: Video Link down below: ( https://youtube.com/watch?v=rWbMx7KpfJQ&feature=youtu.be ) What if I told you we could get nice things? What if I told you that these said nice things came in a form to be called one of the best structure decks since the pandemic? Well either we are truly in luck or we are just opted to not get set to the curb like we would've gotten as always. Alba Strike is the endgame of lore building, and competitive viability that US (the players) have at least tried to maintain in an age of darwinistic vitality. However for a $10 structure deck, it's veeeeerrry solid. As usual, we are given at least 40 cards, but there is something interesting with this one. Besides Pot of Extravagance and Dark Ruler No More (which the latter of the two I did not play for this demostration), We are given 5 (Yes 5) powerful fusion monsters that actually do things. Also you have your familiar faces like Dogmatika Fleurdeis, the Knighted and Fallen of Albaz. However what was unexpected was that they added pieces from Dragon Link in this Structure Deck: Mainly Starliege Seyfert, White Dragon Wyvernburster, and Black Dragon Collapserpent. The support in this set that truly took this structure deck home however was the support for the "Branded" sub-archetype. For one, we got the new fusion spell, Branded Fusion (which allows you to fusion summon a fusion monster using a "Fallen of Albaz" monster), and the new searcher Springans Kitt (Which Special Summons herself if you control a Fusion monster listed as "Fallen of Albaz", then if successful can search out a "Branded Spell/Trap that from your deck or that is Banished or in your GY). Tri-Brigade Mercourier is another new piece which acts as an archetype based negator, and if banished can search out Fallen of Albaz or a monster with the name listed in its text. Paradise Branded is basically just Magical Meltdown; but only activates it's search effects after you fusion summon your monster, and only with a "Fallen of Albaz", or a monster with the name in it's text (you still got that sweet anti-negate protection though, so that's nice). As a sweet bonus, I mentioned earlier we get 5 powerful fusion monsters that were only expected to be released in core sets. First comes the original three of the lineup: that being Albion the Branded Dragon, Brigand the Glory Dragon, and Sprind the Irondash Dragon. However 2 news pieces of Branded support have been added into the structure for the sake of "lore" (or to increase sales the trust of structure decks had been falling off). That being Mirrorjade the Iceblade Dragon, and Lubellion the Searing Dragon (with the latter of the two having synergy and compatibility with Albaz himself).
Cyber dragon
Write your deck strategy here...aa

deck_excerpt: Six Samurai can counter the meta.
deck_description: Six Samurais. An infamous deck from way back in the days of old. Appearing first in Strike of Neos as a cute little beatdown deck but had something unique about them, if one was to be destroyed by battle you can choose a different six samurai monster instead which gave the deck a fighting chance against the might of Gladiator Beasts, and Lightsworns at the time. This deck also gave birth to some of the most infamous cards out there in the form of Legendary Six Samurai Shi En which is a soft once per turn spell/trap negate meaning if you had two or three of this chad out you could do 3 negates and combo that with Naturia Beast and Barkion at the time and the deck became feared. The next cards being the ever so loop heavy love couple of Legendary Six Samurai - Shinai as well as Legendary Six Samurai - Mizuho. The big enablers of the infinite bushido counter loop amassing almost infinite counters to abuse with Mizuho also being a soft once per turn allowing you to just keep reviving your Shinai or Kizan for field clearing or FTKs with Amazoness Archer or Cannon Soldier. The third being Legendary Six Samurai - Kizan which is just a free non once per turn special summon from hand giving you access to free field spam and letting you go into a ton of synchro, XYZ, and Link plays. The final card being the infamous and still hated to this day GATEWAY OF THE SIX which every single time a six samurai monster is normal or special summoned place two Bushido Counters on it which if you build up enough counters lets you make an unbeatable almost unbreakable monster floodgate board but enough gushing about this deck. Time to say what the main field you want is.     The main end field you want for this deck is- Apolousa with 4 counters, two Shi Ens for two spell/trap negates, a Great Shogun Shien (I believe this card is amazing this format with Adventure and Despia running around and he has priority so Despia Players can now cry when they can't resolve their Branded in Red, Branded Opening, and Branded Fusion all in the same turn), a Naturia Beast because of Non Once Per Turn spell negation so you can laugh in the face of Despia and Adventure package players when they can't resolve their Rite of Amersur (I don't know how to spell it), Faithful Adventure and for Despia their Branded Fusion, Theater, Red and Opening. The last monster slot can be anything if you play your cards right. I typically like to have either Break Sword or Shadow Shien in the last slot. The ideal spells would be Gateway and 2 Dojo or at least 1 Dojo and bith have a good number of counters on them in case I want to push for game and the last spell being a Divine Sword Phoenix Blade just as an additional power up to a warrior I control. OH I FORGOT TO MENTION. Another ideal monster for the last monster zone can be Secret Six Samurai - Rihan just as a surprise summon and because it is a banish opponents monster contact fusion (also because I think it would be based as fuck to summon)     In the end, my build is just I consider to be more negate heavy. Hope you find this enjoyable to read and are more informed.

deck_excerpt: This deck can burst the field with a ton of small birds to bring out the you big boss monsters in Empen, Mist Valley Apex Avian, and Raiza the Mega Mo
deck_description: The whole strategy revolves around seeing at least one of your little birds and a the field spell. Once you are able to activate map (and usually reveal a Robina or Eglen, to be able to grab Barrier Statue of the Stormwinds without wasting a summon/search) and go into Empen, you are easily able to grab the Dreaming Town trap card and set up with a skill drain in Empen, and a near perfect floodgate with Stormwinds. The second Stormwinds is definitely a scum move, but for problem decks that can full combo after the barriers destruction, it might be necessary to bring the second Stormwinds to the field. You can use  the effect of Dreaming Town on their main phase (ideally after their normal summon) to grab Robina -> Stormwinds,  to still further prevent them from making their plays possible. The deck has many fun combos to explore, and has infinite ways to get to the same board state. This deck is versatile, and at the ratios provided, I believe it has the lowest potential for a brick, and the highest potential to win. Remember. Deck thinning, is game winning.

deck_excerpt: Take control of your opponent with Vampire World.
deck_description: A versatile deck that can play multiple ways. Set up your Doomking negate with the Zombie World package. Also use glow up bloom to add Voivode to hand then kaiju summon Voivode using 2 of their monsters when Sucker is active, spawning 2 of their monsters to your side of the field and  rank 8 into Zombie Vampire with 3 materials (then overlay AA-Zeus!)  The main goal with the deck is to take control of your opponents monsters that might annoy you and keep them out of their reach. The deck makes great use of graveyard effects and can combo like crazy.  This deck is completely BONKERS to be honest! The only problem I've had really is a very slight consistency issue but I'm always open to trying other cards in here. Possibly Allure of Darkness.

deck_excerpt: Another take on Drytron post Eva ban. No Vanity.
deck_description:
First - Basic opening:
  1. Alpha + Zeta in hand/field
  2.  ss Alpha --> search Benten --> ss Zeta (tribute Benten) --> search Meteonis --> search Diviner (or other Fairy depending on starting hand).
  3. ns Diviner --> Arc Light to GY --> search Lord of the Red (or Quadrantids if LotR in hand)
  4. xyz Mu Beta1 --> Gamma to GY
  5. ss Benten --> ss Gamma + Alpha/Zeta --> search Valrkyria --> Meteonis from GY to hand (target Gamma/Aplha/Zeta) --> ss Valkyria (banish Arc Light)
    1. xyz Mu Beta2 --> ss LotR --> xyz F0's --> ss Baronne --> set Solemn/Designator. end phase
    2. link Dagda (Valkyria+Diviner) --> xyz Mu Beta2 --> activate Meteonis+Activate Dagda --> set Scythe --> ss LotR  --> ss F0's --> set Solemn/Designator. end phase
    3. link Dagda (Gamma + Alpha/Zeta) --> ss Baronne --> activate Meteonis+Activate Dagda --> set Scythe --> ss LotR  --> set Solemn/Designator. end phase
Going second: Pray and use hand traps/ Dark ruler/ Droplet   Deck can be somewhat versatile and is definitely fun. Lots of different openings that end the duel quickly. However, prone to handtraps and less to bricking. Side (and main) deck suggestions are very welcome! Happy dueling.

deck_excerpt: Os monstros "Salmangreat" têm vários efeitos relacionados à batalha e recursão GY.
deck_description:
"Salamangreat" (転生炎獣サラマングレイト Saramangureito) é um arquétipo de monstros FIRE Cyberse usados por Theodore Hamilton (Soulburner) em Yu-Gi-Oh! VRAINS.

Os monstros "Salmangreat" têm vários efeitos relacionados à batalha e recursão ao GY. Um tema comum entre muitos de seus monstros é que eles funcionam melhor quando invocados com outro monstro de mesmo nome. O exemplo mais simples e poderoso é "Salamangreat Gazelle" que envia qualquer carta "Salamangreat" do Deck para o GY, e também pode Special Summon da mão se um monstro "Salamangreat" for enviado para o GY. Muitos dos efeitos do arquétipo também envolvem embaralhar cartas do Cemitério no Deck, reviver e descartar cartas, então a manipulação do Cemitério com sucesso dá ao Deck muito potencial.

deck_excerpt: The best Ancient Warriors Deck 😎.  This deck is built to set up easy OTK's.
deck_description:
First things first this is a go second deck, it can work if you go first but it isn't as fluid. The main strategy of this deck revolves around Three Visits, hence its position as deck master, ideally you want to get Ancient Warriors Saga - Three Visits out on your first turn then play one of your ancient warriors monsters. If you have Ancient Warriors Saga - Masterful Sun Mou in your hand then this should be the monster you play after Three visits. There are two possible strategies depending on the variables stated above: Normal hand - not containing Sun Mou If you have Tenki in your hand then you can use it to draw Sun Mou, if not then continue as follows. Play Three visits then play an ancient warriors monster from your hand, this will activate Three visits which you can use to summon either Sun Mou or Ancient Warriors Saga - Rebellious Lu Feng. If you draw Sun Mou then see below, however, if you draw Lu Feng then he should be your main piece for the rest of the game. Sun Mou hand Play Three visits then play Sun Mou this will start a chain here are the steps:
  1. Use Sun Mou as the catalyst for Three Visits
  2. Use three visits to add one of your special monsters to your hand these include:
    • Ambitious Cao De (Recommended, if not in hand)
    • Valiant Zhang De (Recommended, if not in hand)
  3. Use Sun Mou's ability selecting Three Visits as the tribute
  4. Use this ability to add Rebellious Lu Feng to your hand if not already, if you already have one in your hand then choose one from the list above.
  5. Now you can activate the graveyard ability of Three Visits and use it to summon Cao De if you have and if not then Valiant Zhang De.

deck_excerpt: Mass negation and destruction effects. Great for Advanced Players who can read the board and know the decks they are facing. In depth tutorial.
deck_description: This is a work in progress!  Quick introduction to me! My name is MoboFett, and I have been in and out of yu-gi-oh since I was ~6. My first deck was summoned skull and I fell in love with the deck, but eventually lost my cards. Around a 3 years ago my little brother had me get back into yu-gi-oh because my love for it when we were kids sparked his enjoyment for it. I struggled to find a deck I truly enjoyed and eventually found the Invoked archetype, and it quickly became a favorite. With a lot of testing and enjoyment from this deck, I then dug for means to make the deck compete with top tier decks and came up with the following. I hope to ever evolve this deck, and I hope this deck helps someone fall in love with the game,  This is a control deck with a lot of negation/destruction.  Generally you want to go first, but you can easily make this a 2nd turn deck.  Going first! You are looking to bring out some form of negate, and the strongest form of negation in this deck is Mechaba (This does not mean it is limited to just him.) The ideal starting hand includes Aleister the invoker, Dogmatika Ecclesia, the Virtuous, Invocation, Magical Meltdown, and Shaddoll Fusion. First bait out the hand traps with magical meltdown as this will only bring an Aleister to hand and prevent the negation of fusion summoning. If you notice they don't have hand traps then proceed to summon Aleister, and get another invocation ( you will appreciate this when you realize people will negate everything you do.) with Aleister, special summon  Artemis, use invocation to bring out Mechaba, then activate Eccclesia to special summon her to the field in defense postion and use her effect to search for dogmatika Punishment. You now 4 negates on the field (I'll explain momentarily.), and a free cannot be destroyed by battle with extra deck monsters. During your opponents turn you can then bully them with Mechaba, if they still try to do something use Dogmatika Punishment to destroy 1 of their cards, send N'tss to the grave and enjoy destroying one card on top of the punishment destruction, you can then use Fleurdelis as a hand trap to negate the effect of one face up monster your opponent controls. This deck typically will roll if the opponent does not understand your combos.     Going 2nd is the same idea except you need to get maximus on field, to send psy-frame lor omega and N'tss to the GY and you have destruction and recycling with N'Tss. When I am more available I will extend this for more combos. I do not know how to add the tab that shows negates and boss monsters for decks as this is my first deck submitted.

deck_description: This is go first deck that end with a super powerful broken boss monster(s) (Can still be kill by Kaiju) to stop your opponent from conducting the basic function of the game. PRO: - Literally end on THE Synchro boss monster, 3 onmi-negate ( Shooting Majestic Star Dragon , Cosmic Blazar Dragon & Shooting Quasar Dragon/Crystal Wing ). - Roughly 70% consistency start hand, as long as you able to Synchro into Junk Speeder and you can run combo from there. - 95% Win end board unless they play Lava Golem or Sphere Mode (Which is super rare for most decks). 3-7 negates (3 Handtrap/Trap from T.G Hyper Librarian draw and 1 from Majestic Mirage SS SMSD to reuse his effect) by the end of your turn. CON: - If Junk Speeder effect gets negated, you are over and no possible come back unless you run a second Junk Speeder AND survive with one defense monster. - Super weak to handtrap/negate as every combo is super essential to bring out big gun - While being quite consistent, dead hand is totally dead hand and all you can do is set a monster hoping they don't play Train OTK deck.

deck_name: (Updated Post October 2022 Banlist) The Weather Painter Deck
deck_excerpt: The Weather Painter Deck with control put in mind and access to some nasty extra deck monsters.
deck_description:
The idea of this deck is to gain easy access to Rainbow and Moonbow with the new support as soon as possible. After that it is to lock down the board with the use of Skill Drain, and Macro Cosmos. Originally, I had in place 2 copies of torrential tribute, and 2 copies of Summon Limit. I have relegated the Summon Limit to the extra deck when you know you are going first in a game 2 or game 3 scenario. Torrential Tribute was completely removed from this decklist due to the fact that Tearalaments now exist. There are other options available that include Solemn Strikes and/or some Solemn Judgement cards instead if so desired.

The main cards you want to see and utilize is Weather Painter Snow, Snowy Canvas, and Weather Forecast. These cards are integral in how you pump out your end-board to take control of the game. Some cards are included to directly access the cards you desire in case you draw a brick. Pot of Prosperity is the new replacement for the original searcher for this deck (Piri Reis Map) since the new reprint of the Pot of Prosperity has allowed it to be much more affordable. This will provide you a much more consistent search without the drawback of cutting your life points in half and being Ash'd at the beginning of main phase 1. Terraforming allows access into a copy of your Weather Forecast field spell.

As other recent deck postings have stated before, this deck archetype was very slow in comparison to other decks in the current state of Yugioh. The archetype allows you to out-grind your opponent after setting up a board with Rainbow and 3 omni-negates. If you can't get through it then you are fighting a losing battle and you won't be able to beat it.

Post-DIFO support (Konami, please give us Weather Painter Red!): The new support is very welcome as it allows the deck to be quicker to establish control of the board. Moonbow itself allows it to freely float into Rainbow if it gets destroyed while being a bit niche as it allows your main Weather Painter monsters connected to its arrows to have the effect to temp banish your opponent's monsters until the next standby phase. If any of your Weather Painter monsters are banished when Moonbow is link summoned you can summon one of those Weather Painter monsters. Weather Forecast is an absolute unit of a card as it puts this deck on turbo mode to push out Rainbow/Moonbow, hopefully on turn 1 via the ability to use your Weather Painter spell/trap cards to link into Weather Painter Rainbow/Moonbow and then add in a normal summon of a Weather Painter monster to one of the arrows to gain their effects.  With the ways things are there are multiple ways to support this archetype. The deck is not very strong going second so it is a good idea to have something to interrupt your opponent. Dimension Shifter allows significant disruption with the current high tier decks floating around that utilize the graveyard. Droll and Lock Bird can be an option to be put in this deck to limit the amount of resource gain your opponent can make. I chose to go with Effect Veiler to have access into a solid monster negate and an easy option into a big Accesscode Talker via the integration of the Selene package using an Aussa Charmer link monster. One other that comes to mind is also playing kaijus with a single copy of Interrupted Kaiju Slumber. If your opponent slams a big monster on the field that can interrupt your plays, kaijus can come in clutch and knock your opponent's plans around and allow you to more freely get Rainbow out and re-establish control of the board.

Extra Deck: The extra deck is as follows to have 3 Rainbow and 2 Moonbow. If the need arises you can create Moonbow and on destruction float into a copy of your Rainbow. I feel that 3 copies of Rainbow and 2 copies of Moonbow is pretty balanced. The XYZ monsters are fairly straight forward. The idea is to sling out a Zeus through Fortune Tune and Downerd Magician.

Non-Weather Painter Link Monsters: 1 x Selene, Queen of the Master Magicians 1 x Accesscode Talker 1 x Aussa the Earth Charmer, Immovable 1 x Knightmare Phoenix 1 x Knightmare Unicorn 1 x Underworld Goddess of the Closed World.

Knightmare Phoenix is to protect Rainbow before climbing into something like Underworld Goddess of the Closed World. One other card that came to mind in the creation of this deck was a specific extra deck monster, Topologic Zereboros. I had not included it in the extra or the side as I felt it could be a bit too situational but interesting nonetheless. If you utilize Macro Cosmos and/or Dimensional Fissure early on to have your opponent banish a lot of their cards, then it can be seen as beneficial to summon a monster that gains attack for each card banished. Along with that, Topologic Zereboros has the ability to blanket banish wipe out the board with a summon to one of its arrows and summon itself back to be a big boss monster. I am curious what others might think of the card and how it may interact with this deck but if it is too situational then I feel good regardless as to where I left the extra deck in its place. It is my first time submitting a deck here and I am curious what others might think of this deck setup and how it can be improved. Keep in mind I am an older player that got back into the game a few months ago after originally stopping in 2005 so I know I may have included some cards that are not as great as other cards that can be included in this deck and my descriptions may not be as well articulated as others.

This deck is a fun deck but is freaking consistent...  Plus, as you play drytron fafnir, magicians' soul is really good to generate card advantadge, plus, being a searchable extender for i:p masquerena. deck_excerpt: A mostly standard Utopia-Onomat deck modified to summon a 9 material Rhongomyriad
deck_description: For this deck description, I'm going to assume you know how to play the standard Utopia/Onomat deck, so if you don't check out any Utopia guide or my guide for the Kali Yuga variant: https://ygoprodeck.com/plat-1-utopia-deck/  Also, I do not recommend building this deck unless you already have/play a standard Utopia deck, Rhongo is likely to be hit at some point by some sort of ban imo and youll need three copies of the structure deck for the three astral & zexal field.   With that out of the way, "Starting" Board: The "start" point of this board is gonna be 1 Zexal Field, 1 Ascended Sage, 2 Warrier Cards, and any 1 other monster card. Usually the two warriers are gonna be two of the onomat cards and the other monster will be the third or youll have two onomat cards and one astraltopia. Combo: Ascended Sage + Non-Warrior Monster -> Utopia Double (do not activate when prompted) w/Number 75 attached by Zexal Field + Barian Force (or a Warrior card as long as you leave two on the field after the summon) Utopia Double - Number 75 -> Utopia -> Utopia Prime Utopia Prime + Barian Force -> Number C101 -> Number CXyz CXyz Copies Number 75 in the graveyard 2 Warrior Monsters -> Rhongo Attach CXyz to Rhongo by copied effect from number 75's At this point you'll have a 9 material Rhongo on the board and the only thing that can really defeat you is direct burn attacks by spell/trap cards Other than the cards mentioned in the combo, the rest is gonna be either hand traps, cards to get the necessary cards into your hand, or cards for the back-up standard Utopia combos. Also, the use of into the void as a draw card isnt strictly necessary. You can also replace it with other options such as upstart goblin, chicken game, or pot cards (though I wouldnt recommend the ones that banish cards)   Now go forth and get this accursed card banned

deck_excerpt: Call me a meta sheep, but I signed in to Master Duel and built the best damn deck in the format a day, whatcha gonna do?
deck_description: Master Duel is wild.  So, the deck is a pretty simple, straightforward Tri-Brigade deck with a small Zoo splash. I'd call the deck aggressively midrange: Appollousa - Pass really shouldn't be as good as this is, but Revolt is an insane card. You also have some pretty wild combos, and often they rely on only 1 or 2 cards to have high impact, meaning we can jam good interruptions to fill out the roster. The Zoo engine is primarily for Zeus, which rounds out the going second plays, but being able to fill the GY with Beast-adjacent monsters for Tri effects is super clutch, and with Drident and Chakanine you'll often actually just use this engine to make Ferrijit while filling the GY. It does increase consistency quite a lot while improving your going second hands in general. The deck is the best deck in the format in my opinion, and it isn't even close - there are no extremely bad matchups, provided your interruptions are clutch, and even if you misplay bad the deck often has the pure power to push through for game anyways. You have to watch out for Trap based strategies when you're going second, and you have to really worry about strategies that can gain an enormous amount of advantage throughout a turn, like Prank-Kids for example, but the deck feels almost unstoppable going first, and pretty damn good going second.  Master Duel is a BO1 format, and that impacted the card choices. It is also a Maxx "C" format, which kind of makes a bunch of ulties basically mandatory. I feel like that actually serves this deck well, as Evenly is not commonly maindecked, not nearly as often as Harpies or Lightning Storm, which both can be obnoxious but are a far cry from a perfect answer. Evenly also isn't a perfect answer in and of itself. Hand traps are also kind of lower impact - Gamma doesn't mean much, Ash usually means less, and while Maxx "C" can be backbreaking the deck can make some plays without giving up too many free cards, which helps, depending on the matchup.  So, card choices.  3 Fire Formation - Tenki. This card is freaking nuts. So, with 3 of these and 3 Fraktall, +1 Rescue Cat we have 7 1 card starters for our Tri plays. But also, these double as more copies of our 4 Zoo monsters. I think they should probably limit this card, Tri is already pretty powerful without it, and this is the card that low-key pushes the Zoo builds way over the top. Rescue Cat is a better combo than just Fraktall, but in terms of mitigating the risks of interaction, I'd always rather see a Tenki or a Fraktall.  4 Zoo Monsters - 2 Thoroughblade, 1 Whiptail, 1 Ramram. The theory behind this is pretty simple - if I have to see 2 Zoo monsters, I'd almost always like to see Thoroughblade first, to mully while setting things up for a Chakanine. This is genuinely the maindeck zoo effect you will use most often. However, Ramram's Trap protection effect is clutch, if niche, and probably the best of the Zoos for when you're ending on Drident turn 1 just for its defense points. Whiptail makes the Zoo pile have another removal option built-in, but in reality I've used the "attach as material" effect more often than that. You could make a case that it should be 3 Thoroughblade or 3 Whiptail or 3 Ramram first IMO, depending on the meta. I think Thoroughblade is the best of them, but I like the utility of searching out the Zoos that are relevant.  3 each of each Tri (and a Kitty) - I've already talked a little bit about how Fraktall + Tenki + Cat gives 7 starters, but I really do feel like you have to max out on your  Tri monsters. With Almiraj pretty much any 2 Tris end up being full combo, so having high numbers of all of them are good. Also, you're sending lots of Tris to the GY, and banishing cards from the deck with Pot of Desires, so I do genuinely go through ALL of my tri names in a single game, sometimes.  3 Revolt - The best card in the deck. It is searchable off of Bearbrumm, and that's nice, but you'd almost always rather open it than search it, since Bearbrumm has some tough restrictions and also puts a card back into the deck. This is basically a Dinomiscus, except it generally adds 1 or more cards to your hand while setting up your GY instead of discarding a card. Nutty. Also, you can fire it off in response to Spell/Trap removal, to gain all that advantage and get ahead on the board. This card is wild.  2 Pot of Desires. You could maybe argue that I should be running 3, but tbh I've always found that even in decks where the first Desires is fairly "free", the second is usually not, and the third is dead. Yeah, you kind of want to open it more, but not at the cost of interaction or actual combo cards - the best part about the card is still that it is Ash bait. Still, this is a deck where Desires #1 is basically completely free almost all of the time, and where the second is often still pretty damn good, especially if you sequence your searches correctly. This is one of those silly cards, where on the one hand maybe they should limit it like in the TCG, but on the other hand you might actually be doing decks that run it a favour by limiting it. I like 2.  So, it's a Maxx "C" format, so we're on 3 Maxx "C" plus 3 Ash, plus 2 Called By for hand traps. Maxing out on the "C" seems obligatory - sometimes the card is a little bad or kind of dead, but it is game-winning when it resolves most of the time. The rhetoric for these numbers is simple - with 5 ways to answer Maxx "C" I am more likely to answer the Maxx "C" than they are to draw it, and by relying on Ash and Called By, these are really solid interruptions even if my opponent isn't on the insect. Meanwhile, I like free wins. Sometimes I draw 0 cards and the card still feels good. 3 Imperm fill out the hand trap suite, because Imperm is a hand trap that doesn't die to Called that is good for pushing through on your opponent's turn or your own, can't be negated by things that answer monsters effects, and is great as a generic Trap card to boot. If you're encountering more Maxx "C" than I am you could consider Crossout, but Crossout does require deckbuilding to be more centralized than it seems to be just on the ranked ladder - I'd be more inclined to play it in Tri in a competitive Master Duel event, but for laddering, it seems really hit-or-miss.  Lastly, we have a few tech options. I actually like Cosmic main a lot of the time even in BO3, but some kind of Spell/Trap disruption seems completely essential in BO1, and I think Cosmic is the best of the bunch. Solemn Judgment is kind of a pet card of mine, while Strike ends chains better, Judgment is just a good all-around answer that hits back-breaking Spells/Traps, while also answering most things that would hit the field in general. It feels really good here, since we're Apollousa spam and slightly weak to Lightning Storm, Harpies. I've used this on Twin-Twisters, I've used this on Harpie's Duster, I've used this on Boss Monsters, I've even used it on occasion just to kill Rotas in the absence of Ash. Very flexible card.  I think the Extra deck is pretty much completely optimized. You'd like 2 Bearbrumm or 2 Ferrijit or 3 Shuraig, but in reality, Accesscode Talker, Double Dragon Lords, and Almiraj are going to give you more ultility in the first 2 cases, and more consistency in the third case.

deck_name: Cubic Deck - Crimson Nova Trinity Turbo (Master Duel) - April 2022
deck_excerpt: Crimson Nova Trinity Turbo Deck - Cubics 2022 (Master Duel)
deck_description: A Cubic deck made for trying to get Crimson Nova Trinity out as fast as possible.  Prisma can act as a replacement for a Crimson Nova. This works in tandem with cards like Cubic Dharma, where you could discard Cubic Karma, bring the Crimson Nova that Prisma threw away back into your hand, and then banish the discarded Cubic Karma for the third (second technically, but Prisma changes its name) Crimson Nova. Then just use any poly card you have. Greater Poly is the best IMO because of the Piercing Defense, but the first effect if making it unable to be destroyed by card effects is largely useless because Crimson Nova Trinity already can't be destroyed OR targetted by effects. Super Poly is there just for shits and giggles to potentially make Starving Venom or any other Fusion you could throw in there. Fusion Conscription is there to search for Crimson Nova. Emergency Call can search for Prisma. Summoner Monk can summon Duza at the cost of a spell (you want to discard Cubic spells, especially Karma, since they have secondary GY effects). Duza can then throw ANOTHER Cubic card to the GY, which you would want to be another Karma (or any other Cubic spell/trap you want if you already have what you need to summon Crimson Nova Trinity).  Most of the Extra Deck (specifically Fusionist and Sanwitch) are there as fodder for Pot of Extravagance. Starving Venom can potentially be made, Tapir is for stalling, Zeus is there if (for some reason) you attack with Tapir, Linkuriboh is there for more stalling, Pentestag for piercing, and Verte in case you don't draw any Poly cards.  Crimson Nova Trinity is definitely the best card in the deck, and you should be going for it, but you don't necessarily NEED it to win. Crimson Nova on its own is already an amazing card and can dish out OTK's easily. Vijam can stall insanely well, and Cubic Causality can make stalling even easier, with both cards essentially making your opponents' monsters useless by putting Cubic Counters on them. That means no attacking, no effects, just sitting there doing nothing.
vjp

deck_excerpt: Meta Gizmeks with Drytron, Swordsoul, along with Lyrilusc, and World Legacy.
deck_description: May have more uploads in the future, but for now; this is what I have came up with after a year of working on it! Side deck will need more attention, and extra deck is the best it can be, until more cards get release. The reason it is 42 and not 40 is because of Orochi. Having a 40 card build is very small when he's in the deck, also I will be adding a Drytron summon/effect list. By the Gizmeks having 50 in their attack it can be very hard calculating, however here are two to start with: Crystron + Deskbot = Drytron effect. Another one is Makami + Arakami = Drytron effect and summon. I did not add Pot Of Desires because I do not like the card, plus with Orochi your deck thins out very quickly! That's why Small World is a great addition to the deck! That card plus Naganaki make very good resources! Also with Naganaki and PSY-Framelord Omega; facedown banish cards does not effect you as much, so replacing Infinite Impermanence with Evenly Match would not be a bad idea. Another thing to keep in mind is that the babies (Inaba, Naganaki, Taniguku, and Arakami) banish face up. That is why Burial from a different Dimension is in the deck. Pot Of Acquisitiveness was in the deck, until I realize it is best to have your cards either in your hand, field, grave, or banish. In the deck is fine, but not as fine when you need a combo, or card. Also, Burial can target your opponents banish, so if your playing against a deck that use banish cards, or a card that targets banished cards you can chain it with Burial. Also Burial is up to 3 monsters while POA (Pot Of Acquisitiveness) is 3 monsters, so keep that in mind. The board I try to land on is Mecha Phantom Beast Auroradon, Hearld of Arc Light, and F.A Dawn Dragster. It is not the best broad, but it is the best we got, until Konami give us more support, or better generic extra deck monsters. All in all, it is very bittersweet when playing this deck. Every Gizmek has two effects and one of those effects are great! while the other one is not so much! Like the card Gizmek Inaba for example, seems like this card is suppose to be your starter, yet Konami made it have a "when this card is normal summon" instead of "If this card is special summon or normal summon" or "If this card is normal summon". I have yet to miss timing with Inaba, but one day it will happen! And when it does I might explode! Also, why special summon in defense!? If you're going to make me normal summon why can't I control how the other monster will be summon!? Another thing is that you can not combo with it with Naganaki. That would have made this deck VERY good! but a man can dream! you can combo Inaba with Yata. It is a weird combo, but it is one. Also, Inaba first effect is not once per turn, so keep that in mind. The second effect of Inaba hardly comes up because it uses the monsters "original attack" would have been better if it just said monsters attack, but a man can only dream. I gave up playing SowrdSouls for this because I wanted a deck of my own to play in meta. I never liked machine monsters, but Gizmeks name and look always got to me. Although, I spent a year putting in time, and money to make my dream of winning a YCS with a deck hardly no one plays, I am uploading this deck profile just in case I can not do it. My dream is not about me winning the YCS with a deck hardly no one plays, but for anyone can win a YCS with a deck hardly no one plays. I know! Better said than done, but hey! A man can dream!
vjp
To win
